title: Chancellor Rishi Sunak announces UK budget 2021
content:
Rishi Sunak announced a series of economic measures for the UK on Wednesday in the House of Commons, amid significant challenges from the COVID-19 pandemic, which has resulted in over 700,000 job losses and a 10% shrinkage of the economy.

The Chancellor confirmed an extension of the furlough scheme, which provides 80% wage support for employees unable to work due to pandemic-related restrictions, extending it until September. Under the updated plan, businesses will be required to contribute 10% of wages in July and 20% in August and September as the scheme winds down. Additionally, support for self-employed individuals will continue, with another grant available from February to April.

Other measures to support workers include an increase in the minimum wage to £8.91 per hour starting in April, and the continuation of a £20 weekly increase in Universal Credit benefits through September.

Sunak also announced changes to the tax structure, revealing that corporation tax will rise to 25% in April 2023. He emphasized that this would remain the lowest rate in the G7, with only businesses making profits over £250,000 being taxed, which accounts for just 10% of companies. Firms with profits below £50,000 will maintain a 19% corporation tax rate. He confirmed that income tax, national insurance, and VAT rates will not change, with duty on alcohol and fuel remaining frozen.

For the hospitality sector, VAT will remain at a reduced rate of 5%, and the threshold for business rates relief will increase from £45,000 to £100,000 this year. Additionally, new tax incentives were announced for designated areas including locations in Liverpool City Region, which aim to reduce customs costs and encourage investment.

title: International Criminal Court to investigate war crimes in Palestine
content:
On Wednesday, the Chief Prosecutor of the International Criminal Court (ICC) announced the opening of a formal investigation into alleged war crimes in Palestine. This investigation will be led by a British lawyer set to succeed Fatou Bensouda as chief prosecutor on June 16.

Bensouda stated that the decision to initiate the investigation followed a thorough preliminary examination by her office, which spanned nearly five years. She committed to a "principled, non-partisan approach" and assured that the case will be treated "independently, impartially, and objectively, without fear or favor." The preliminary examination, conducted in December 2019, concluded that "war crimes have been or are being committed in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip."

The investigation will center on alleged war crimes occurring since June 13, 2014, shortly before the Israeli military operation in Gaza. Bensouda indicated that the investigation’s priorities would be determined in due course and identified both the Israeli Defense Forces and the Palestinian militant group Hamas as potential perpetrators.

Since becoming a member of the ICC in 2015, Palestine has long accused Israel of war crimes. Conversely, Israel, which is not a member of the ICC, asserts that the court lacks jurisdiction over Palestinian territories, arguing that Palestine is not sovereign.

Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu denounced the ICC's decision, calling it "the essence of anti-Semitism and hypocrisy." He criticized the court for seemingly ignoring other nations, such as Iran and Syria, that are also accused of committing grave offenses. "Without any jurisdiction," Netanyahu said, "it decided that our brave soldiers, who take every precaution to avoid civilian casualties against terrorists who deliberately target civilians, are the war criminals." He vowed to "fight for the truth until we overturn this scandalous decision." Israeli Foreign Minister Yair Lapid referred to the ICC's decision as "morally bankrupt and legally flawed."

A spokesperson for the U.S. State Department stated, "We will continue to uphold our strong commitment to Israel and its security," asserting that the ICC lacks jurisdiction in this matter. The Israeli ambassador to the U.S. emphasized continued collaboration with the American government.

The U.S., a non-member of the ICC, previously imposed targeted sanctions on the prosecutor's office during Donald Trump’s presidency and has urged current President Joe Biden to maintain these sanctions, calling the ICC investigation "illegitimate" and "politically motivated." The United States also opposes the ICC's investigation into American actions in Afghanistan.

The Palestinian National Authority, which governs parts of the West Bank, welcomed the decision as "a long-awaited step" toward justice and accountability, urging nations not to politicize "these independent proceedings."

Hamas spokesperson Hazem Qassem, who has previously asserted the legality of rocket attacks on Israel under international law, praised the ICC decision as "a step forward to implement justice" for the Palestinian people. He expressed the hope that it would lead to accountability for the occupation.

Estimates from the United Nations indicate that approximately 2,200 Palestinians, including 1,500 civilians, lost their lives during the 2014 Gaza conflict, known in Israel as Operation Protective Edge. Israeli estimates indicate that at least 73 Israelis, including six civilians, were killed in the same operation.

The Israeli government has reportedly engaged in public relations and diplomatic efforts to thwart the investigation, according to the Associated Press.

title: Two Jordanian ministers caught breaking lockdown measures, resign
content:
The Jordanian Ministers of Interior and Justice resigned yesterday after being found in violation of anti-coronavirus measures.

Both Interior Minister Samir Mobeideen and Justice Minister Basel Kharabsheh were discovered attending a public banquet, breaching social distancing and maximum capacity guidelines that their ministries are responsible for enforcing. The current limit is set at 20 people. This incident occurred just days after new restrictions were implemented, which include stay-at-home orders, a military-enforced curfew, and a fine of approximately 100 Jordanian Dinars (about US$140) for individuals not wearing face masks.

Prime Minister Bisher Al-Khasawneh accepted their resignations, which were formalized in one of two Royal Decrees issued by King Abdullah II. Reports indicate that the second decree appointed the Deputy Prime Minister for Local Administration to oversee the Ministry of Interior and the State Minister for Legal Affairs to manage the Ministry of Justice.

A recent surge in coronavirus infections has resulted in at least 4,627 deaths and over 300,000 confirmed cases in Jordan, a nation of ten million, according to Reuters. Officials have attributed the rise in cases to the public's failure to adhere to restrictions, leading to dozens of arrests for breaching stay-at-home orders. Additionally, hundreds of businesses have been shut down as part of enforcement efforts, Reuters further reported.

title: Wales widens smoking ban, includes at hospitals, schools and playgrounds
content:
**Wales Expands Smoking Bans in Public Spaces**

Today, Wales announced an extension of its smoking ban to include hospitals, schools, and playgrounds, with violators facing a £100 fine. This makes Wales the first region in the UK to implement such a comprehensive ban.

This new measure builds on existing restrictions, including a ban on smoking in enclosed public spaces since 2007 and a prohibition on smoking in cars with children since 2015. 

Governed by the left-wing party, the Welsh government stated that the purpose of the ban is to discourage smoking among both adults and children by making it appear less normalized, while also encouraging those who smoke to quit.

To reinforce the smoke-free initiative, two hospitals in southern Wales have implemented a button-activated speaker system to remind visitors of the ban. A similar system was trialed in 2016, featuring messages recorded by local schoolchildren.

Eluned Morgan, the Minister for Mental Health, Wellbeing, and the Welsh Language, expressed pride in the new legislation, asserting that "[t]his legislation will benefit the health of future generations in Wales, as fewer children will be exposed to smoking." She emphasized the need to "combat the harmful effects of smoking."

However, the government faces criticism from smokers' rights groups. Simon Clark, Director of the Forest organization, argued that the ban is excessive, stating, "There is no evidence that smoking in the open air poses a risk to anyone else's health, including children." He further contended that targeting smokers in high-stress situations, such as hospital visits, is particularly unfair.

Wikinews reached out to Eluned Morgan's office for further insights on the ban:

**What is the core objective of this law?**
The legislation aims to protect individuals from harmful second-hand smoke exposure, assist those trying to quit, and reduce the likelihood of children starting to smoke.

**What is the envisioned future of Wales in terms of smoking if the law succeeds?**
We aim to create more smoke-free public spaces, promoting healthier lifestyles. Plans to extend the smoking ban to the outdoor areas of cafes, restaurants, and town centers are underway.

**How do you address criticisms regarding government overreach?**
The law is designed to safeguard public health, diminish second-hand smoke exposure, and deter smoking amongst youth.

**Do you believe individuals have the right to smoke?**
While smoking is an individual choice, it remains the leading preventable cause of early death in Wales, hence the need for legislation to mitigate its effects and promote healthier choices.

**Where can smokers smoke?**
The smoke-free law applies strictly to designated areas specified in the legislation.

**Does the ban on smoking in playgrounds apply at all times, even when children are not present?**
Yes, all public playgrounds in Wales will be smoke-free at all times, irrespective of the presence of children. Restricting smoking in areas frequented by young people helps to normalize healthier behaviors and decrease the likelihood of youth smoking.

By enforcing these regulations, Wales hopes to create a healthier environment for future generations.

title: Fundraiser Captain Sir Tom Moore dies aged 100 with COVID-19
content:
On Tuesday, Captain Sir Tom Moore passed away in a hospital in England after battling COVID-19. Last year, he garnered widespread admiration by raising nearly £33 million for the National Health Service (NHS) by walking 100 laps around his garden to celebrate his 100th birthday. Moore was also a World War II veteran, having served in the British Army.

His daughters shared the news of his passing, stating, "The last year of our father's life was nothing short of remarkable." They added that he was "an incredible father and grandfather, and he will stay in our hearts forever."

Born in West Yorkshire, England, Moore joined the Army in 1939. After serving, he became an instructor at the Armoured Fighting Vehicle School in Bovington, Dorset. He relocated to Bedfordshire in 2007, where he lived with his family.

In April 2020, Moore started walking laps in his garden with the goal of raising £1,000 for the NHS during the COVID-19 pandemic. His efforts soon gained immense popularity, ultimately raising millions and setting a Guinness World Record for the most money raised by an individual through a charity walk. He also collaborated with singer Michael Ball on a duet that reached number one on the UK charts, making Moore the oldest artist to achieve this milestone. On his birthday, April 30, he was appointed an honorary colonel by the British Army, and in July, he received a knighthood from Queen Elizabeth II in recognition of his accomplishments.

UK Prime Minister Boris Johnson paid tribute to Moore, calling him "a hero in the truest sense of the word" and highlighting how he "embodied the triumph of the human spirit." Labour Party leader Keir Starmer said, "Britain has lost a hero." A spokesperson for Buckingham Palace announced that the Queen would send a private message of condolence to Moore's family. In his honor, flags at places like 10 Downing Street were flown at half-mast.

Moore had previously battled skin cancer and suffered a hip fracture in 2018. He credited his hospital care with inspiring him to support the NHS, referring to the medical staff as "marvellous." He is survived by two daughters and four grandchildren.

title: Wikinews 2020: An 'Original reporting' year in review
content:
**2020: A Year of Milestones for English-Language Wikinews**

Reflecting on a productive year for the English-language Wikinews, we review over two dozen original reports contributed by our writers in 2020.

In celebration of International Women’s Day, an all-female crew operated the Mysuru-Bengaluru train in Karnataka, India. Locomotive pilots B Shiva Parvathi and Rangoli Patil covered 139 km en route to the state capital.

Mysore Divisional Railway Manager Aparna Garg informed Wikinews that only 10% of their workforce consists of women, totaling around 650 individuals out of approximately 6,900 employees. The ten-day campaign commenced on March 1, marking the theme "Each for Equal," designed to promote gender equality within the Mysore Division.

During our interview, Garg addressed the societal challenges women face in the Indian Railways. "For a woman to succeed, the journey is far more arduous than it is for a man. They often need to work twice as hard before gaining recognition," she remarked. Garg emphasized that women juggle multiple responsibilities, balancing work and household duties, which places them under immense pressure. Her observations indicated that despite these challenges, women show exceptional dedication.

Garg suggested that societal attitudes need to shift, starting at home, to support women in their professional paths. She stressed the importance of educating male colleagues and family members to foster a culture of respect and support.

As the SARS-CoV-2 virus spread globally, panic buying ensued, with consumers hoarding essentials like toilet paper. In response, Woolworths and Coles in Australia limited purchases, initially setting a cap of four packs per transaction, which later reduced to one or two. Both retailers increased order frequency and stock to meet consumer demand after experiencing shortages.

In March, Wikinews interviewed Iranian chess player Dorsa Derakhshani about her career and experiences. Banned from representing the Iranian national team in 2017 for not wearing a hijab during competition, Derakhshani’s brother also faced sanctions for competing against an Israeli opponent. Currently studying in the United States, she reflects on her inspirations, including Judit Polgár, and discusses the significant barriers faced by women in Iran's chess community.

In a fascinating study published in March, researchers examined social harm aversion in lab rats, uncovering brain regions pivotal in such behavior. The study demonstrated that rats preferred not to harm their peers even when it benefitted them, revealing deep-seated social instincts.

Astronomers from the European Southern Observatory reported the discovery of the closest known black hole to Earth, found in the V590 Monocerotis system, located approximately 1,010 light-years away. The team, led by Thomas Rivinius, revealed that this system is the first visible to the naked eye to contain a black hole.

In the buildup to the 2020 U.S. presidential election, Wikinews conducted interviews with multiple vice-presidential nominees from various parties, including the Constitution, Libertarian, and Green parties. Each candidate spoke about their political philosophies, campaign strategies, and the influence of the COVID-19 pandemic on their operations.

A notable event occurred in August when a major water main break in White Plains, New York, disrupted supplies citywide. Emergency crews worked swiftly to restore water service, with repairs completed by the evening of the incident.

In the realm of sports, Caloundra Rugby Union defeated Wynnum 45-24 in an intense match during the Sunshine Coast Rugby Union season. Both team coaches highlighted the competition's physical nature and the improving dynamics of the teams involved.

As the U.S. presidential race intensified, Wikinews continued to interview candidates from various parties, summarizing their key positions on critical issues such as climate change, social media freedom, and international conflicts like that in Armenia and Azerbaijan.

In a significant technological shift, the announcement by Red Hat to transition CentOS to CentOS Stream in December led to widespread disappointment among long-time users, prompting the community to seek alternatives. This prompted the development of Rocky Linux, named after the original founder of CentOS.

Lastly, the implications of extraterrestrial research sparked intrigue as a study explored the ability of Earth-based life, such as E. coli, to survive in entirely hydrogen or helium-rich atmospheres, potentially broadening the scope for life detection on exoplanets.

Together, these stories illustrate not only the challenges faced by women and minorities in various fields but also the resilience of communities and individuals around the globe in navigating unprecedented times.

title: East Gippsland, Australia shire council passes motion against nuclear weapons
content:
A local government body in Australia, which oversees towns such as [Town A], [Town B], and [Town C], passed a motion on Tuesday endorsing the prohibition of nuclear weapons. This motion was inspired by the [Global Campaign Name], which advocates for the implementation of the [Treaty Name]. The council's resolution requests that the Australian Prime Minister be contacted to express their support for the treaty.

During Tuesday's council meeting, Councillor Tony Crook introduced the motion, with Councillor Jane Greacen seconding it. Crook acknowledged that the council's influence over nuclear weapons is limited but emphasized Australia's role in the nuclear fuel cycle, stating that nuclear weapons "have brought untold misery to communities around the world." In contrast, Councillor Arthur Allan opposed the motion, arguing that nuclear weapons are a "federal issue" and that the motion amounted to a "non-binding resolution."

Deputy Mayor Mark Reeves voiced his support for the motion, characterizing it as a matter of "moral standing" and reflective of community values. He humorously noted, "Nobody's said to me — 'You know what we need? A really good intercontinental ballistic missile in the shire.'" Conversely, Councillor Trevor Stowe dismissed the motion as "feel-good stuff" and an "absolute waste of time."

The vote ended in a tie: Councillors Crook, Greacen, Reeves, and Mayor Mendy Urie supported the motion, while Councillors John White, Kirsten Van Diggele, Allen, and Stowe opposed it. Councillor Sonia Buckley abstained from voting. Mayor Urie cast the deciding vote in favor of the motion.

Historically, the Australian government has boycotted discussions on the prohibition treaty, arguing that "a ban treaty risks undermining the [non-proliferation treaty], which Australia rightly regards as the cornerstone of the global non-proliferation and disarmament architecture." However, the opposition [Opposition Party Name] has pledged to sign and ratify the treaty if they come to power.

title: Uruguayan Language Academy rejects FA sanction against Edinson Cavani as 'poverty of cultural and linguistic knowledge'
content:
On Friday, the Uruguayan Academy of Language issued a statement denouncing the three-match ban and $100,000 (£137,000) fine imposed on football player Edinson Cavani by the English Football Association (FA).

The sanction was handed down on Thursday following a comment Cavani made in response to a fan who praised his performance. Specifically, Cavani used the term "negrito," which the FA deemed "insulting, abusive, improper, and harmful to the reputation of the game," classifying it as an "aggravated breach" due to its reference to color, race, and/or ethnic origin.

The Uruguayan Academy contended that terms like "negro" (black) and its diminutive "negrito"—similar to terms such as "gordo" (fat) or "gordito"—are often used in a friendly or affectionate manner. The statement, signed by the academy’s president, emphasized this point.

In addition to the Academy's defense, the Argentine Academy of Language, which shares a variety of Spanish with Uruguay, called upon the FA on December 22 to exonerate Cavani, reinforcing the notion that his intent was not racist.

On Friday, the hashtag #graciasnegrito became a trending topic on Twitter in both Argentina and Uruguay, as fans showed solidarity with Cavani in light of the sanctions he received. 

In summary, the Uruguayan Academy criticized the FA's decision, attributing it to a "lack of cultural and linguistic understanding."

title: International Criminal Court rules its jurisdiction includes Palestine
content:
The International Criminal Court (ICC) ruled on Friday that its territorial jurisdiction extends to areas of Palestine, a decision that has drawn criticism from Israeli and U.S. officials.

In a 2-1 ruling, the ICC judges stated that their decision was based on Palestine's membership in the court's founding treaty. They clarified, however, that the ruling does not address the statehood of the disputed territory or its borders. Citing a 60-page legal brief, the court confirmed that its jurisdiction includes territories occupied by Israel since 1967, specifically Gaza and the West Bank.

Chief Prosecutor Karim Khan endorsed the ruling for its "judicial clarity," while noting that the Office would analyze the decision before determining its next steps. In December 2019, Khan previously indicated that "war crimes have been or are being committed in the West Bank, including East Jerusalem, and the Gaza Strip," naming both the Israeli Defense Forces and the Palestinian group Hamas as potential offenders.

Palestinian Prime Minister Mohammad Shtayyeh hailed the ruling as "a victory for justice and humanity." Similarly, Hamas and various Palestinian officials, along with the international organization Human Rights Watch, commended the decision.

In contrast, Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu condemned the ruling as hypocritical, asserting that "when the ICC investigates Israel for fabricated war crimes, this is pure antisemitism." He vowed to contest what he described as "this perversion of justice" with all available means.

Israel further criticized the ICC for overstepping its jurisdiction in political matters, arguing that its parameters should not extend to borders that remain unresolved in peace negotiations. The Israeli military insists it has mechanisms in place to prevent misconduct, though these have faced past criticism as being inadequate.

The U.S. government also expressed opposition to the ruling. Spokesperson Ned Price stated that, while President Joe Biden aims to improve relations with Palestine, the U.S. opposes both the recent ruling and Palestine's designation as a member of the Rome Statute. Price reiterated that when Palestinians sought to join the Rome Statute in 2015, the U.S. did not recognize them as a sovereign state, and thus they should not be eligible to participate in international organizations or entities, including the ICC. He emphasized that the court's jurisdiction should apply only to nations that consent to it or are referred by the UN Security Council.

Both Israel and the U.S. have signed but not ratified the Rome Statute and do not recognize the court's jurisdiction. The Israeli government's expansion of settlements in disputed territories has drawn widespread condemnation from the international community, where approximately 700,000 settlers now reside.

title: Disney to shut down Blue Sky Studios, animation studio behind 'Ice Age'
content:
Yesterday, US-based entertainment giant Disney announced plans to shut down Blue Sky Studios, the animation studio behind the popular movie franchise.

"Walt Disney Studios has made the difficult decision to close filmmaking operations at Blue Sky Studios after careful consideration of current economic realities," the company stated. As a result of the closure, the studio will halt production on a movie adaptation of a project originally scheduled for release next year.

Located in Connecticut and founded in 1987, Blue Sky Studios was acquired by Fox in 1999 and came under Disney's control in 2019 when it purchased Fox's assets for approximately $71 billion. Blue Sky was known for its work on the "Ice Age" series, the "Rio" films, and other successful projects, including the Academy Award-nominated "Ferdinand."

Disney also operates two other major animation studios, Pixar and Walt Disney Animation Studios. In recent years, the company has faced several challenges, including the closure of various divisions during the COVID-19 pandemic. Last year, Disney announced plans to lay off around 32,000 employees, many from its theme parks, and sold its mobile video game unit. The company reported a $2.8 billion net loss in the fiscal year 2020.

title: New Zealand announces new Matariki public holiday
content:
The New Zealand Government announced on Thursday the establishment of a new public holiday, Matariki. This holiday signifies the beginning of the New Year and coincides with the rising of the Matariki star cluster in the night sky.

Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern emphasized the significance of this day, stating, "This will be a day to acknowledge our nation's unique, shared identity, and the importance of our heritage. It's going to be something very special, and uniquely New Zealand." Ardern also pointed out that the new holiday will help bridge the over four-month gap between public holidays in June and October.

The date of Matariki will vary each year as it is based on the Maramataka, the Māori lunar calendar, but it is expected to fall on a Monday or Friday, according to Ardern. To aid in the planning and celebration of this holiday, a Matariki advisory group has been established. Minister for Māori Crown Relations — Te Arawhiti explained that this group’s role is to provide advice on future holiday dates, celebration methods, and to develop educational resources surrounding Matariki.

The inaugural Matariki holiday is set to take place on Friday, June 24 of next year.

Ardern's administration made the Matariki holiday a key election promise, and secured victory in last year's elections with a strong majority. This outcome marked the best performance for any political party since New Zealand adopted a mixed-member proportional representation system in 1996.

This initiative is not the first attempt to declare Matariki a public holiday. In 2009, a Member of Parliament introduced a bill for a Matariki holiday, which was supported by the then-opposition Labour Party. However, it faced opposition from the governing party and ultimately failed, with 59 votes in favor and 63 against.

title: Arkansas becomes first US state to criminalise treatment for transgender minority
content:
On Tuesday, lawmakers in Arkansas, a Republican-controlled state, became the first in the U.S. to enact a ban on specific medical treatments for transgender youth under 18, regardless of parental consent. This law is set to take effect no earlier than July 30, which is 91 days after the legislative session's recess.

The bill, known as the Save Adolescents From Experimentation Act, was initially vetoed by Governor Asa Hutchinson on Monday but was subsequently overridden in the Senate with a 25–8 vote and in the House with a 72–25 vote. It prohibits healthcare professionals from providing hormone treatments, surgeries, or any related referrals to minors under 18.

Arkansas Representative Robin Lundstrum, who sponsored the bill, stated, "They need to get to be 18 before they make those decisions." The legislation also affects minors already receiving such treatments, with penalties including the loss of medical licenses for noncompliance.

The bill received praise from conservative groups like The Family Council, while Governor Hutchinson expressed concern that it reflects "a product of the cultural war in America." He added, "I hope my veto will encourage my Republican colleagues across the country to resist the temptation to place the state in every decision made by parents and healthcare professionals."

In response, a coalition representing 67,000 pediatricians nationwide condemned the legislation, arguing it denies essential medical care to young people. Dr. Madeline Deutsch, the medical director of San Francisco’s LGBTQ Health Program, remarked that there is a "general consensus among professionals" about the efficacy of transition-related treatments, while Dr. Robert Garofalo from a children's hospital in Chicago criticized the bill for "perpetuating the very things we know are harmful to trans youth."

Holly Dickson, executive director of the Arkansas chapter of the American Civil Liberties Union (ACLU), criticized the supporters of the bill for ignoring widespread bipartisan opposition, calling it a "discriminatory crusade against trans youth." She announced plans for a lawsuit to challenge the law in court, stating, "Blocking trans youth from the care they need simply because of who they are is not only wrong, but it’s also illegal."

The passing of this ban follows previous anti-transgender measures in Arkansas and other states, including a bill signed by Hutchinson on March 25 that prevents transgender girls and women from competing in sports aligned with their gender identity. Dickson described that measure as "discriminatory and shameful."

Following this latest legislative action, pro-LGBTQ rights advocates noted that over 100 bills targeting transgender individuals have been proposed across more than 20 states.

title: North Korea withdraws from Tokyo Olympics, citing COVID-19 concerns
content:
On Tuesday, the North Korean government announced its withdrawal from the postponed Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics, citing the need to "protect athletes from the global public health crisis caused by COVID-19," according to the Associated Press. This marks North Korea's first official absence from the Olympics since it boycotted the Seoul Games in 1988, as reported by CBS News.

South Korean media noted that this is the first instance in which North Korea has pulled out of a major international sporting event due to concerns over an infectious disease. While several North Korean athletes did not participate in the 2016 Summer Olympics due to similar worries, the nation ultimately did compete in those Games.

South Korean President Moon Jae-in had hoped for a unified team between the two Koreas, similar to the unified Korean Peninsula team that competed at the 2018 Winter Olympics, as stated by Al Jazeera.

Despite North Korea's claim of having no COVID-19 cases, Park Won Gon, a professor of North Korean studies, pointed out that the country has exhibited "coronavirus-related caution" since declaring an emergency anti-virus system in January of last year. He expressed skepticism about North Korea's ability to secure enough vaccine supplies for its population by July, when the Tokyo Olympics are scheduled to occur.

In November, it was reported that North Korea had placed approximately 81,000 people in quarantine, excluding soldiers, and that by October 22, around 32,011 individuals had been isolated. A source informed Daily NK that over 300 people had died in isolation centers in the country.

Jeff Kingston, director of Asian Studies at Temple University, characterized this decision as a "setback for diplomacy" in remarks to CBS. He also reported that Seoul expressed disappointment at North Korea’s withdrawal, which removes an opportunity for the South to engage in dialogue with North Korean leader Kim Jong-un. Recently, Kim Yo-jong, North Korea's vice department director of the Central Committee and sister of Kim Jong-un, warned that "the peaceful spring days of three years ago are unlikely to return." She criticized South Korean leaders as “all born with stupidity,” accusing them of being “dumb and deaf, bereft of judgment,” following joint U.S.-South Korea military drills in March.

This announcement follows North Korea's testing of two ballistic missiles on March 24, which former admiral Yoji Koda described as "just the beginning of North Korean fervor."

Historically, North Korea has participated in boycotts of the Olympics in Tokyo and Los Angeles.

title: North Korean Research Institute for Nutrition Care of Children director slams UN's report on child malnutrition due to COVID-19
content:
On Tuesday, a statement was released by North Korea criticizing a United Nations report that revealed approximately 100,000 children in the country are suffering from malnutrition. The report attributed part of this malnutrition crisis to the COVID-19 border closures.

The director of the Research Institute for Nutrition Care of Children, a part of North Korea's health ministry, called the UN report "a sheer lie," claiming it is "seriously distorted" and represents "a black-hearted act of hostility aimed at tarnishing the image of our country." The statement emphasized that despite challenging conditions, the nutrition of children is a top priority in North Korea. It accused "self-styled experts" at the UN of deliberately misrepresenting the situation to suggest that serious malnutrition among children exists in the country.

The UN's report, published on March 10, drew upon observations from UN Special Rapporteur Tomas Quintana, who noted that the COVID-19 pandemic contributed to a rise in starvation due to declining economic activity. The report also highlighted alleged public executions of individuals caught violating anti-epidemic measures, including one case in Pyongyang involving a man accused of engaging in "illicit trade" with China.

An unnamed non-governmental organization cited in The Korea Times stated that "approximately 440,000 children and pregnant and lactating women will not receive necessary nutrition, with around 95,000 acutely malnourished children lacking access to essential treatment, and approximately 101,000 kindergarten-aged children not receiving adequate care."

North Korea has implemented stringent border restrictions to curb the spread of COVID-19, which have led to shortages of critical supplies, including medicine. A report from Reuters, citing Russia's diplomatic mission to North Korea, indicated that these shortages have prompted an "exodus" of foreign diplomats from the country.

title: Three injured in a school shooting in Idaho, US; sixth grader in custody
content:
Two students and a school employee were injured in a shooting at Rigby Middle School in Idaho on Thursday. A sixth grader was taken into custody following the incident.

According to Sheriff Steve Anderson, the student—who is enrolled at the school—fired a handgun from her backpack both inside and outside the building. A teacher intervened and successfully disarmed the student. Police were dispatched to the school around 9:15 AM local time, and the suspect was subsequently taken into custody by the local sheriff's office.

Dr. Michael Lemon, trauma medical director at Eastern Idaho Regional Medical Center, reported that the three injured individuals suffered non-life-threatening injuries to their extremities. The school employee has since been treated and released. Additionally, a warrant has been issued in connection with the incident involving a residence in Idaho Falls.

Classes have been canceled for Friday throughout the district. Local school superintendent Chad Martin expressed the gravity of the situation, stating, "This is the worst nightmare a school district could ever face. Our hearts and prayers go out to the victims, their families, and everyone involved." Twelve-year-old Yandel Rodriguez, a student at the school, recounted, "Me and my classmate were just in class with our teacher doing work, and then suddenly, there was a loud noise followed by two more loud noises. Then there was screaming."

title: Country singer Morgan Wallen's recording contract cancelled following use of racial slur
content:
On Wednesday, US country music artist Morgan Wallen was indefinitely suspended from his recording contract with Big Loud Records following the leak of a video in which he used a racial slur. Wallen addressed the incident in a statement to TMZ, saying, "I used an unacceptable and inappropriate racial slur that I wish I could take back. There are no excuses for using this type of language, ever. I want to sincerely apologize for using the word. I promise to do better."

Big Loud Records, which also distributes Wallen's music, supported the decision and stated, "Such behavior will not be tolerated." This move came alongside the removal of Wallen's music from several radio stations, including the largest radio station group in the United States. Despite the controversy, Wallen's newly released album, titled "One Thing at a Time," reached number one on the Billboard 200, maintaining that position for three consecutive weeks.

Wallen also encountered issues on streaming platforms. While his music remained available on some services, his songs were reportedly removed from key playlists on Spotify, including the top 50 Hot Country Songs and several of the platform's featured country playlists.

title: Maroochydore pick up first win in round 5 Australia's Sunshine Coast Rugby Union 2021 season
content:
In the fifth round of Australia's Sunshine Coast Rugby Union on Saturday, Maroochydore achieved their first victory of the season, defeating the University of the Sunshine Coast with a score of 27-15.

"Getting a win was definitely crucial for us as a club," said Maroochydore coach Ben Radmall. "The initial weeks were tough, and we faced a disappointing loss to Wynnum last week, which we expected to win. It's great to finally lift that burden. The boys are excited, but there’s still plenty of room for improvement, which is encouraging for us."

Maroochydore entered halftime with a 10-point lead, having successfully scored one converted try and a penalty goal. They maintained their advantage despite conceding three tries during the match.

"I think the boys realized they were in a contest and gained some belief in that second half, which was fantastic," Radmall noted.

On the other side, University coach Brand Tronc expressed frustration over the team's failure to adapt to the game's demands.

"We attempted to play a different style, but it didn't suit us," Tronc said. "We need to show up and put in the work. We have to be willing to fight in the trenches with other teams. We can't always dictate the game. The boys need to toughen up and be ready for whatever challenges come their way."

title: Wikinews interviews Donald Mackay, UKIP candidate for 2021 Airdrie and Shotts by-election in Scotland
content:
Voters in the Scottish constituency of Airdrie and Shotts will head to the polls on May 13 to select a new Member of Parliament (MP) for the United Kingdom House of Commons.

The seat became vacant following the resignation of the outgoing MP, who was a representative of the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP). The MP is stepping down to contest the upcoming Scottish Parliament election on May 6. Previously, the SNP's Gray secured the seat in the last election with 45.1% of the vote, outperforming the second place candidate, Helen McFarlane of the Scottish Labour Party, who garnered 32.0%.

Among the eight candidates vying for the position is Donald Mackay, the leader, secretary, and immigration spokesman for the United Kingdom Independence Party Scotland (UKIP). According to UKIP's website, the party has campaigned since its inception in 1993 for the United Kingdom to exit the European Union, claiming that their efforts pressured former Prime Minister David Cameron into holding a referendum on June 23, 2016. Following the resignation of UKIP's leader in 2019, Peter Walker of The Guardian noted that the party was polling at less than 1%, having largely been replaced by Nigel Farage's new Brexit Party. Recent polls conducted by Panelbase and Deltapoll showed UKIP at 0.499% and 1%, respectively, while the Brexit Party was polling between 8% and 11%.

Wikinews interviewed Mackay about key political issues concerning the electorate. 

**Why did you decide to run in this by-election?**
"UKIP is a mainstream party and should have a candidate in all elections."

**What are your thoughts on how the coronavirus pandemic has been handled by Westminster?**
"It has been managed very poorly. Lockdowns that destroy small businesses are not the solution."

**What do you think needs to be done to improve transport services in the Airdrie and Shotts constituency?**
"I have no real comment on this."

**Do you support the idea of a second independence referendum?**
"I am a Unionist. While I believe the people of Scotland have the right to pursue political independence, I think Scotland is already somewhat independent with its own government and I would prefer to see Scotland as a vital part of the United Kingdom."

**Do you think the Conservative government is doing enough to combat climate change?**
"I am skeptical about climate change and am not particularly interested in it."

**As the leader of UKIP Scotland, what does your party stand for?**
"Our party stands for: the abolition of the Scottish Parliament, a total commitment to freedom of speech, and an end to lockdowns and restrictions on individual freedom of movement."

**Your party's 2020 manifesto references "Cultural Marxist social engineering of society." Do you still support that term, considering it has been labeled an antisemitic conspiracy theory?**
"I would hesitate to use the phrase 'cultural Marxism,' but I firmly oppose the politicization of our schools, public sector, police, and even football teams."

**How does your party differentiate itself from the Reform Party, which also opposes the EU?**
"As far as I know, Reform UK does not advocate for the abolition of the Scottish Parliament."

**What is a local issue you feel is being overlooked?**
"There is a need for sensible investments to make Airdrie a more appealing place to live and work."

**If elected, what is one legal change you would like to implement?**
"I would primarily focus on removing any restrictions on freedom of speech and thought."

title: Wikinews interviews Jonathan Stanley, Scottish Unionist candidate for 2021 Airdrie and Shotts by-election in Scotland
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Jonathan Stanley, Scottish Unionist Candidate for the 2021 Airdrie and Shotts By-Election**

Voters in the Scottish constituency of Airdrie and Shotts will head to the polls on May 13 to elect a new member of parliament (MP) for the United Kingdom House of Commons.

The outgoing MP, Neil Gray, a member of the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP), is resigning to compete in the Scottish Parliament election on May 6. Gray secured his seat with 45.1% of the vote in the last election, defeating the Scottish Labour Party’s Helen McFarlane, who garnered 32.0%.

Among the eight candidates vying for the constituency is Jonathan Stanley, representing the Scottish Unionist Party. Stanley was selected for this seat in September after news of Gray's nomination emerged. He is also a candidate for the Holyrood elections, running as a list candidate for the Unionist party.

Wikinews spoke with Stanley about pressing issues both nationally and locally in Airdrie and Shotts.

For context, Stanley provided links to opinion pieces and press releases that informed his responses. The first opinion piece focuses on housing and suggests measures such as restricting housing access to individuals who have resided in the UK for ten years, imposing a 20% tax on houses sold to foreigners, and abolishing tax relief for "buy-to-let" mortgages. The second piece critiques a law passed by the Scottish Parliament, arguing that it undermines personal freedoms and compromises families' privacy and security in their homes.

The two mentioned press releases pertain to COVID-19, advocating for widespread flu and COVID-19 vaccinations and the closure of UK borders to non-medical flights from China at the pandemic's onset, as well as additional measures for the public during the crisis.

**Key Points from the Interview:**
- **Reasons for Running:** Stanley advocates for a unionist approach that prioritizes vulnerable communities. He highlights concerns regarding the potential closure of Monklands A&E and the impact on local jobs due to the decision by Teleperformance to shift to remote work.
- **Pandemic Response:** He criticizes the government's handling of the pandemic, describing it as ineffective and economically damaging, while underscoring the lack of health professionals in cabinet positions.
- **Transport Services:** Stanley calls for urgent road repairs in Airdrie and Shotts, arguing that approximately 90% of passenger journeys are made by car, and stresses the need to support local taxi drivers better.
- **Support for a Second Independence Referendum:** He firmly opposes the idea, maintaining his stance as a representative of the Scottish Unionist Party.
- **Climate Change Policy:** Stanley contends that the Conservative government should focus on promoting technological solutions to climate change, rather than adopting austerity measures, and advocates for increased nuclear energy usage.
- **Status of Pro-Union Parties:** Emphasizing collaborative strategies, he highlights that only the Scottish Unionist Party seeks cooperative efforts with established parties.
- **Departure from UKIP:** Stanley explains his exit from UKIP due to concerns over sectarianism and divisive tactics, and expresses his commitment to inclusive unionism through the Scottish Unionists.
- **Local Issues:** He identifies the need to maintain services in local district hospitals, asserting that their centralization might endanger emergency care in rural areas.
- **Legal Reforms:** Stanley aims to support legislation that provides patients with the right to seek treatment from alternative providers and to restrict public bodies from engaging in unregulated legal actions against employees or clients.

This interview highlights Jonathan Stanley's perspectives and priorities as he campaigns in the upcoming by-election.

title: Wikinews interviews Neil Manson, SDP candidate for 2021 Airdrie and Shotts by-election in Scotland
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Neil Manson, SDP Candidate for the 2021 Airdrie and Shotts By-election in Scotland**

Voters in the Airdrie and Shotts constituency of Scotland will head to the polls on May 13 to elect a new member of parliament (MP) for the United Kingdom House of Commons.

The seat is currently held by ***Neil Gray*** of the pro-independence Scottish National Party (SNP), who is resigning to contest the Scottish Parliament election scheduled for May 6. In the last election, Gray secured 45.1% of the vote, 13.1% more than the second-place candidate, Helen McFarlane of the Scottish Labour Party, who received 32.0%.

Among the eight candidates vying for the position is ***Neil Manson***, the Scottish regional chair of the Social Democratic Party (SDP). Manson, who joined the SDP in 2019 after reading the party's New Declaration outlining its principles, has described his career as extensive across international markets in both the manufacturing and energy sectors.

Wikinews spoke to Manson about key issues impacting Airdrie and Shotts during this by-election.

**Why did you decide to run in this by-election?**
"The SDP is experiencing a genuine resurgence across the UK as people become disillusioned with current party politics and seek alternatives with honest policies rooted in our families and communities—nowhere more so than in Scotland. As Regional Chairman for Scotland and a long-time resident who raised my family in Airdrie, I'm a passionate advocate for the SDP."

**What are your thoughts on the handling of the coronavirus pandemic by Westminster?**
"Leading the nation through the pandemic has been a complex task, and there have undoubtedly been missteps by both the Westminster and Holyrood governments. While I believe critique can be constructive, excessive negativity doesn't help. We supported the initial lockdowns, but I have been skeptical of the ongoing 'Stop-Go' approach which did not effectively control the virus and risked undermining personal liberties, prolonging economic downturn and societal challenges."

**What improvements do you propose for transport services in the Airdrie and Shotts constituency?**
"Our primary pledge is to nationalize the rail system, with an immediate focus on enhancing bus services, especially through increased funding for regional and rural bus travel."

**Do you support the idea of a second independence referendum?**
"No. Constitutional matters are reserved, and the UK Parliament's agreement to a referendum previously resulted in the Scottish people's decision to remain in the United Kingdom. Any discussions of change need to occur at Westminster first."

**Is the Conservative government doing enough to combat climate change?**
"Environmental issues have suffered from too much rhetoric and insufficient action under current and past governments. While the SDP is committed to meeting global environmental obligations, we advocate for sustained changes through encouraging behavioral shifts across industries and society."

**How does the SDP differentiate itself from the SNP?**
"We fundamentally disagree with the SNP's self-description as social democrats; we see them as populists. The SDP embodies true social democratic values consistently—not just during elections. We're devoted to Scotland's success within a strong United Kingdom, benefiting all its citizens."

**Do you support the establishment of an English Parliament?**
"Yes, I believe this would help heal divisions across the UK and counter the perception of Westminster as a solely English Parliament, with the devolved regions governed from a distance. Such a framework could reduce apathy and accountability gaps that parties like the SNP exploit."

**What does public welfare mean to you?**
"The SDP prioritizes the common good in Britain's national interest. We aim to represent the welfare of all British people, advocating for a Social Market Economy where public sector and market policies can coexist beneficially without ideological distortions."

**What local issue do you feel is being overlooked?**
"I am concerned about the future of sports and leisure facilities in our towns. Many of these facilities face risks due to Scottish Government funding cuts to local councils, and ensuring access for all ages is essential for physical and mental health, particularly as we recover from the pandemic."

**If elected, what legal change would you pursue?**
"I would advocate for the repeal of the controversial SNP Hate Crime and Public Order Act, which could criminalize speech deemed 'hateful.' We believe the bill is ambiguous and lacks adequate safeguards, despite a recent campaign highlighting that 87% of Scots value free speech. It also raises significant concerns regarding the erosion of sex-based rights. The SDP's policy on Transgender and Biological Sex-based Rights affirms our belief in biological sex and supports clear, plain English discussions on these topics in health and reproductive care."

title: Chinese NPC to take control of Hong Kong electoral system
content:
On Friday, Chinese officials unveiled a proposal that would mandate rigorous vetting of electoral candidates from Hong Kong before they can participate in elections. The plan stipulates that only "patriots" loyal to the People's Republic of China will be permitted to run for office. This development follows two years of protests against the Chinese government, during which 47 pro-democracy candidates, activists, and campaigners have been imprisoned under national security laws.

During the annual work report, Premier Li Qiang emphasized the need to "resolutely guard against and deter" foreign interference. He addressed around 3,000 members of the National People's Congress (NPC), where a draft decision was introduced, influenced by Vice Chair of the NPC's standing committee. The proposals include amending the election process, which would grant a committee, responsible for electing the chief executive, greater authority to "directly participate in the nomination of all legislative council members" and establish a "qualification vetting system" for all candidates.

Political scientist Willy Lam, speaking to Agence France-Presse, noted that the proposed vetting committee would likely disqualify candidates perceived as disloyal to the Chinese government. Following the announcement, Beijing's liaison office claimed support for the changes has been expressed by "individuals from all walks of life" in Hong Kong.

Last year, national security laws were enacted that increased the Chinese government's ability to prosecute Hong Kong residents and bar them from running for office. As of Thursday, 47 pro-democracy activists and potential candidates remained in custody following an informal primary election that prosecutors alleged aimed to "overthrow" the government.

The situation escalated on Monday when approximately 1,000 protesters gathered outside a Hong Kong court, calling for the release of what they termed "political prisoners," according to The Guardian. Many of those arrested faced charges under new laws, with 32 individuals denied bail partly due to the stringent requirements of the national security laws. In contrast, 15 defendants who faced opposition from prosecutors were granted bail.

title: Three earthquakes hit off New Zealand's coastal areas, residents warned to avoid coast
content:
On Friday, swathes of New Zealand were advised by the government to avoid beach and shoreline areas following three significant earthquakes near the Kermadec Islands, approximately 105 km off New Zealand's east coast.

The first earthquake struck at 2:27 AM local time, reaching a magnitude of 7.1 at a depth of 10 km. This tremor was felt across the North Island and parts of the South Island. Following this, two additional quakes, recorded at magnitudes of 7.4 and 8.1, occurred near the Kermadec Islands, as reported by New Zealand's National Emergency Management Agency (NEMA). According to Radio New Zealand, over a dozen aftershocks were recorded, some measuring as strong as 5.4.

NEMA issued an early warning at 9:45 AM regarding potential land and marine impacts, stating that flooding was expected along the coast from East Cape to Wellington, as well as on New Zealand's East Coast. However, this warning was later revised. By 2:48 PM, the tsunami warning was lifted, although updated notifications cautioned residents about "strong and unusual currents and unpredictable surges" that could persist for up to another 24 hours, urging them to remain vigilant and take extra precautions.

In a message on social media, New Zealand Prime Minister Chris Hipkins expressed concern, stating, "Hope everyone is OK out there – especially on the East Coast who would have felt the full force of that earthquake." At a press conference, Minister for Emergency Management Kieran McAnulty announced that all residents of Ōpōtiki had been evacuated, commending the community for their calm response, saying, "People have done the right things in the regions by picking up and packing up and staying calm."

title: NASA's helicopter Ingenuity survives its first night at Mars
content:
On Sunday, NASA announced via Twitter that its man-made helicopter, Ingenuity, successfully endured its first freezing night on the surface of Mars. Ingenuity is part of the Perseverance rover's mission, which primarily focuses on exploring Mars and gathering rock samples in the search for signs of past life.

Ingenuity was previously housed in the belly of Perseverance, the car-sized rover that landed on Mars on February 18. While attached to the rover, Ingenuity was kept charged and warm. On Sunday, Ingenuity exited the rover, allowing Perseverance to move away and expose Ingenuity's solar array to direct sunlight.

The NASA Jet Propulsion Laboratory released a statement declaring that this marks the first time Ingenuity has survived a night autonomously while being directly exposed to the Martian atmosphere. The statement noted that the success confirmed the effectiveness of Ingenuity's insulation, heaters, and battery capacity to endure the frigid conditions, which can drop as low as -90 °F (-130 °C). The helicopter utilized energy from its solar array to power a small heater, safeguarding its electronics from the extreme cold.

Mars has only 1% of Earth's atmospheric pressure, meaning that Ingenuity's rotors must spin about three times faster to achieve flight on Mars than they would on Earth, according to ABC News. The helicopter has been designed to be lightweight, weighing approximately 1.8 kilograms (4 pounds), to facilitate takeoff. Tim Canham from NASA highlighted that "the processor on the helicopter is about 100 times more powerful than the processor on the rover itself."

The next phase includes a scheduled blade movement test for today, as reported by CNN. If this test is successful, Ingenuity could proceed with its first flight test, potentially occurring by Sunday. If successful, this would represent the first powered, controlled flight on another planet. Over the next 31 days, five additional flights are planned. If these flights succeed, Ingenuity will further explore its environment, collect rock samples, and capture images of its observations, while also monitoring its temperature and battery recharge performance.

The Perseverance rover is set to transmit images captured by Ingenuity back to Earth just a few hours after they are taken. NASA reported that the rover traveled a distance of 471 million kilometers to reach its destination in Jezero Crater.

title: Wikinews interviews Adrian Mizher, independent candidate for Texas' 6th congressional district special election
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Adrian Mizher, Independent Candidate for Texas' 6th Congressional District Special Election**

On March 23, Wikinews reached out via email to several candidates running for the Texas special election on May 1, aimed at filling the vacancy left by the late Republican Congressman Ron Wright. Among those who responded, Adrian Mizher agreed to discuss his campaign and policies over the phone on March 30.

Mizher presents himself as a senior loan closer for a banking subsidiary based in Texas. He has lived in the state for five years and has spent a total of 16 years in the area over the last 24. A graduate of the University of New Mexico, Mizher grew up in Philadelphia and has also resided in Albuquerque, New Mexico. He aims to "fight tirelessly for fidelity to the Constitution and promote our Conservative values," advocating for issues spanning from the economy to immigration.

An Inside Elections poll released on March 18 indicates that Republican candidate Susan Wright, the widow of Ron Wright, leads with 21% support, followed by Democrat Josh Winegarner at 17% and Republican Jake Ellzey at 8%. With a margin of error of ±4.6%, the district is categorized as “lean Republican,” having voted 51% for Donald Trump in the previous presidential election, a decrease from 54% in 2016.

**Wikinews: Could you introduce yourself and share your background in politics?**

**Adrian Mizher:** My name is Adrian Mizher. I don't have a history in official politics, as this is my first campaign. However, I have closely followed political matters all my life, so I consider myself knowledgeable about current issues and historical events. I graduated in 2001 with a bachelor's degree in accounting and later became a teacher for five years before transitioning into banking, where I've worked for the last 16 years. I am married and have three children.

**Wikinews: What do you see as the powers and duties of Congress?**

Congress has specific responsibilities outlined in Article I, Section 8 of the Constitution. Primarily, it is tasked with managing the federal budget and ensuring adherence to Constitutional limitations, a duty I believe is being neglected.

**Wikinews: Why do you think Texas will elect an independent candidate in this election?**

I believe that once people understand my viewpoints, rooted in the Constitution and our Founding Principles, they'll recognize that my approach reflects true conservative values. Many Republicans who we elect do not consistently act conservatively once in office. My choice to run as an independent stems from a desire to clarify my message beyond simply labeling myself as Republican, which often risks misinterpretation.

**Wikinews: Can you share your thoughts on the late Congressman Ron Wright?**

I had great respect for Ron Wright; he was an exemplary Congressman who fulfilled his commitments and represented our district well. His passing is truly unfortunate.

**Wikinews: What pressing issues would you address in Congress if elected?**

My primary aim is to reduce the size and scope of the federal government, as it is currently overly involved in our lives and beyond its constitutional boundaries. Additionally, I would advocate for election integrity—ensuring the public's trust in the electoral process is crucial. Immigration reform is also vital; we should simplify the process to encourage legal immigration while remaining vigilant about our borders. 

**Wikinews: Your website mentions the need for a sovereign nation controlling its borders. Can you elaborate?**

We welcome immigrants who contribute positively to our society. The immigration process should be straightforward, focusing on public safety and the willingness to integrate into our society. I envision a system where those wanting to immigrate can do so easily and responsibly.

**Wikinews: How would you handle the vaccination rollout if elected?**

While I believe vaccination distribution isn't primarily a federal responsibility, I would support rapid vaccine distribution while allowing state and local governments to manage the specifics.

**Wikinews: What is your view on President Biden?**

I see President Biden as adhering to a left-wing agenda that prioritizes political expediency over effective governance.

**Wikinews: What about former President Trump?**

President Trump accomplished several positive initiatives, particularly in foreign policy and economic deregulation. However, I wish he had communicated his values more effectively, which could have broadened his appeal.

**Wikinews: How do you view the ongoing border crisis?**

Both parties politicize the border crisis, failing to take decisive action. We need to treat immigration requests in a straightforward manner while strengthening our border control without placing blame solely on one administration.

**Wikinews: How would you address the February power crisis in Texas?**

While I experienced the crisis firsthand, I believe it's primarily a state issue. I would encourage state officials to take appropriate measures to prevent future occurrences while resisting the urge to expand federal oversight unnecessarily.

**Wikinews: What sets you apart from other candidates promoting conservative values?**

I regard myself as a vocal advocate for conservative values, committed to clearly articulating these principles to dispel misconceptions about what conservatism embodies.

**Wikinews: How has COVID-19 influenced your campaign?**

COVID-19 has not significantly altered my campaign approach, as I have no reference point for campaigning without it.

**Wikinews: If you are not elected this time, what are your plans for the future?**

At this moment, I do not have a specific plan for the future.

**Wikinews: Lastly, which historical figure do you admire most?**

I hold great admiration for Abraham Lincoln for his remarkable growth throughout his leadership. Ronald Reagan also inspires me due to his ability to connect with people.

**Wikinews:** Thank you for your time, Mr. Mizher.

title: Wikinews interviews candidate for Minneapolis mayor Philip Sturm
content:
**Title: Wikinews Interviews Minneapolis Mayoral Candidate Philip Sturm**

Wikinews reached out to Philip Sturm, a candidate in the upcoming mayoral election for Minneapolis, Minnesota, scheduled for November 2. Alongside this election, voters will also select two members for the Board of Estimate and Taxation and nine members for the City Council. Sturm shared insights into his campaign and policies during the interview.

Philip Sturm is a U.S. military veteran who served from 1999 to 2003, stationed in Japan before participating in operations during the U.S. invasions of Afghanistan and Iraq. According to his campaign website, Sturm has experience in "manufacturing and operations" and has been involved in civic engagement, including serving as co-chair for the Democratic-Farmer-Labor Party in District 62 in 2005 and being a member of Veterans for Kerry. His community involvement also includes volunteering as a special deputy in the Minneapolis Police Department, participating in emergency management workgroups, and serving on the 9/11 and Global War on Terror Remembrance Task Force.

Sturm is running against incumbent Jacob Frey, who won the last election in 2017 with 44.69% of the vote and has already announced his bid for re-election.

**Sturm's Background**

Sturm introduced himself as a 40-year-old married man, originally from Tennessee but raised in Minnesota. He moved to Minneapolis in 2003 after being honorably discharged from the military, where he had trained as a combat engineer. He has worked in the chemical and manufacturing industries and has volunteered for community service to learn more about public safety and emergency management.

**Motivation to Run for Mayor**

Reflecting on the civil unrest in 2020, Sturm stated he felt compelled to take action after witnessing a lack of effective leadership during times of crisis, believing that the city has been poorly managed by those he describes as "credentialed yet fundamentally incompetent."

**Military Service Overview**

Sturm joined the military in 1999 and trained in San Diego as a combat engineer. He served overseas in Afghanistan and Iraq during pivotal operations and was involved in humanitarian efforts amid military actions.

**Campaign Vision**

Sturm advocates for a departure from the current political establishment, arguing that Minneapolis needs leadership that embraces empirical decision-making and accountability. He aims to dismantle the culture of militarism within the police and seeks reforms that will ensure they operate as part of the community, rather than in opposition to it.

**Economic Disparities and Housing Policy**

Sturm emphasizes the need for tax reforms to address economic disparities in the city. He supports initiatives to strengthen housing protections for tenants and believes stable housing and food security are essential for improving educational outcomes for low-income students.

**Political Support and Future Plans**

Throughout his political history, Sturm has aligned himself with progressive candidates in Minnesota, including Bernie Sanders and Tim Walz. He underscores the importance of living wage initiatives and seeks to foster partnerships between local industries and educational institutions to enhance job opportunities within the community.

**Conclusion**

In summary, Philip Sturm presents himself as a candidate who wants to challenge the status quo of Minneapolis governance and pursue policies that address systemic inequalities. As the election approaches, Sturm's campaign will focus on community engagement, police reform, and economic justice in a city navigating ongoing challenges.

title: Challenge shield introduced for Australia's Sunshine Coast Rugby Union
content:
A-grade rugby union teams on Australia’s Sunshine Coast in Queensland will compete for a new challenge shield starting this season. The reigning Sunshine Coast Rugby Union A-grade premier, Noosa, received the SGQ Shield as inaugural holders during Thursday's season launch, with their first defense scheduled against Caloundra on April 24.

"The next time Noosa plays at home, they will defend the shield, and the team that holds it will face challenges at each subsequent home game," explained Mike Aronsten, Manager of the Sunshine Coast Rugby Union Competition. "The shield can only be challenged during home games, mirroring a format used in New Zealand," he added.

Additionally, the senior women's teams on the Coast will have their own challenge shield. They will compete for the Matai Shield, which was claimed last season by Caboolture after defeating Noosa in the Grand Final. Caboolture is set to defend the shield for the first time on May 15.

"Good luck to all the girls, and thank you to Matai for making this happen," said Caboolture A-grade coach Jason de Kock upon accepting the shield.

title: French Prime Minister announces suspension of all flights to, from Brazil over coronavirus variant concerns
content:
Today, in the French National Assembly, Prime Minister Jean Castex announced the suspension of all flights to and from Brazil due to concerns over Lineage P.1, a highly contagious variant of the COVID-19 virus believed to have originated in Brazil.

Castex's announcement was met with "scattered applause," according to the Associated Press. He stated, "The situation is getting worse, and we have decided to suspend all flights between Brazil and France until further notice." A report indicated that as of March 16, Lineage P.1 represented only 0.5% of all COVID-19 cases in France. However, opposition politicians have urged the government to take further preventative measures. A member of the Socialist Party described the suspension as "necessary and a very good decision."

Observations from the Brazilian health institute suggest that Lineage P.1 spreads more rapidly among younger populations. The Foundation reported an alarming increase in COVID-19 cases among Brazilians in their 30s, 40s, and 50s, with rates climbing by 565%, 626%, and 525% respectively since early January, alongside a 316% increase in the overall population. This variant is reportedly 2.2 times more transmissible and has a 25–61% higher ability to reinfect individuals previously infected with other strains. According to RT TV, the Brazilian variant features two significant mutations: N501Y, which enhances transmissibility, and E484K, which potentially reduces the efficacy of vaccines and natural immunity from prior infections.

France is currently experiencing its third wave of COVID-19, with over 99,000 related deaths reported and more than 5,900 patients in intensive care units as of yesterday, the highest number since mid-April of last year. The situation appears to be worsening, with 41,000 to 60,000 positive tests reported over the Easter weekend. The total number of COVID-19 cases in France has reached at least 5.1 million, the highest in Europe. As of recent reports, 7% of the population has been fully vaccinated, while 21% have received their first dose. Since April 3, "restrictive measures" have been implemented nationwide, affecting travel, movement, and in-person education, and a curfew from 7 PM to 6 AM is currently in place in metropolitan France.

While variants originating from Brazil and elsewhere account for less than 4% of infections in France, the variant from the United Kingdom is responsible for approximately 80% of cases. Health Minister Olivier Véran commented, "We are seeing a decline in these variants because they are less contagious than the British one."

title: Magnitude 7.3 earthquake off Fukushima, Japan causes about 50 injuries
content:
A magnitude 7.3 earthquake struck off the eastern coast of Japan yesterday at 11:08 PM local time (14:08 UTC), with a depth reported to be between 55 and 60 kilometers. As of late yesterday, the BBC reported that approximately 50 people sustained injuries due to the quake, and nearly one million homes experienced power outages. The tremor was notably felt strongly in Tokyo.

The Japan Meteorological Agency (JMA) recorded at least fourteen aftershocks following the initial quake. Initially, the JMA reported the earthquake's magnitude at 7.1, which was later revised to 7.3. A spokesperson from the JMA warned that areas where the tremor was most intense face an increased risk of structural damage and landslides. In response to the event, Japan’s Prime Minister urged residents to remain indoors and prepare for potential aftershocks.

No tsunami warning was issued; however, some coastal residents opted to evacuate to higher ground. One evacuee shared with the BBC, "[e]ven if people say we don’t need to worry about a tsunami, I won’t buy it [...] I learned from my bitter experience 10 years ago, and that’s why I evacuated."

The JMA suggested that this earthquake may be an aftershock of the devastating 2011 earthquake, which had a corresponding tsunami that claimed over 18,000 lives. This month also marks the tenth anniversary of that disaster, which caused radiation leaks at the Fukushima Daiichi Nuclear Power Plant. Prime Minister Suga stated that "there have been no anomalies reported from any of the nuclear facilities" following the recent earthquake.
