title: Greek lawmakers approve contentious campus police legislation
content:
The Greek parliament approved controversial legislation on Thursday aimed at establishing a campus police force and a disciplinary council to address violence at universities. The decision, passed by a vote of 166 to 132 in a 300-member parliament, faced strong opposition from many students and professors who argue that it threatens freedom of expression.

Key provisions of the legislation include the formation of a campus police division, restrictions on entry to university grounds, and the creation of a "disciplinary council" with the authority to suspend or expel students.

A government spokesperson referred to university campus violence as "timeless" and stated that "[t]he police will drive out extremist political groups and safeguard the infrastructure, finally making the university a safe place."

Before the vote, Greek Prime Minister Kyriakos Mitsotakis, the leader of the center-right New Democracy party which initiated the legislation, questioned, "Where else in the world do we see images [...] of historical buildings being vandalized?"

Greek universities have a history of unrest, dating back to a 1973 student revolt against the military dictatorship from 1967 to 1974, which was violently suppressed, resulting in the deaths of at least 26 people. Another protest in 1990-91 against educational reforms linked to Mitsotakis' father led to the death of a teacher. More recently, in October, a university rector was taken hostage by masked individuals.

In 2019, the government lifted a long-standing restriction that had effectively barred police from entering university campuses. Critics of the new police measures argue that they infringe upon freedom of expression—a claim the government dismisses as "ridiculous." Recent demonstrations have seen protesters chanting "Bread, education, and freedom," a slogan echoing the 1973 uprising against the junta. In January, police employed tear gas to disperse a protest challenging lockdown restrictions.

Opposition to the proposed campus police force has also emerged from academia, with Professor Dimitris Kaltsonis stating, "There is no need for special police to control the campuses." The University and College Union (UCU) expressed solidarity with Greek colleagues opposing the initiative on Twitter, calling it "alarming and not in line with best practice."

Some demonstrators have called for "more doctors, fewer police." Eurostat data from 2016-2018 indicated that Greece had the second-highest number of police officers per capita in the European Union, which a spokesperson for the Ministry for Citizen Protection labeled as "inaccurate." The spokesperson emphasized that while the government is focusing on improving the quality of education, "[p]olice on campuses is not a choice but a necessary move."

The government has allocated €23 million in funding for law enforcement to better address contemporary challenges, including COVID-19 and external threats.

The left-wing opposition party has criticized the legislation, alleging it aims to render universities "sterile and unfree."

title: US President Biden signs US$1.9 trillion COVID-19 relief package
content:
On Thursday, President Joe Biden signed a $1.9 trillion stimulus relief package into law, providing individuals earning up to $75,000 annually with direct payments of up to $1,400. The legislation received approval from the House of Representatives with a narrow 220–211 vote on Wednesday and was passed by the Senate along party lines with a 50–49 vote using budget reconciliation.

The relief package allocates $300 billion for unemployment benefits through September and increases the child tax credit to $3,600. Additionally, it provides $350 billion in funding for state and local governments, as well as $14 billion dedicated to vaccine distribution. Schools will receive $130 billion to facilitate safe reopenings, while small businesses are set to benefit from $50 billion, and the restaurant industry will get $25 billion in support.

White House Press Secretary Jen Psaki announced that U.S. citizens could expect to see their first round of direct deposit payments in their bank accounts by the weekend. During a primetime address, President Biden emphasized the ongoing efforts to combat COVID-19, which was declared a pandemic by the World Health Organization last year. On Friday, Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris plan to travel to Atlanta, Georgia, to promote the new legislation across the country.

title: New South Wales government announces 'Bradfield' as name for third city of Greater Sydney
content:
Yesterday, the New South Wales (NSW) government in Australia officially announced the name "Bradfield" for its planned third city. 

Bradfield will be situated to the west of Sydney and in proximity to the Western Sydney International Airport, which is currently under construction. The city is named in honor of John Bradfield, the esteemed engineer behind the Sydney Harbour Bridge and the original railway network of Sydney. This decision follows a public consultation held last year.

In a press release on the New South Wales government website, Premier Gladys Berejiklian emphasized the importance of the chosen name, stating, "Bradfield was a renowned engineer who designed and oversaw the construction of both the Sydney Harbour Bridge and Sydney's original railway network." She added, "The name Bradfield is synonymous with delivering game-changing infrastructure and sets the right tone for an area we have referred to as the 'Aerotropolis Core' until now."

The planned city will cover an area of more than 1 square kilometer (100 hectares) north of the suburb of Badgerys Creek. Premier Berejiklian described Bradfield as a "high-tech manufacturing and research hub" that is expected to create approximately 200,000 jobs. She explained, "This area will be transformed into a thriving city center, home to advanced manufacturing, research, science, and education, and we want Bradfield to be as iconic as Sydney and Parramatta." She added that current paddocks will eventually develop into a bustling city center offering premier job opportunities.

Minister for Planning and Public Spaces also highlighted the extensive community involvement during the naming process. "The number of suggestions the community put forward during the 'Name the Place' consultation was overwhelming, and we're thrilled with the level of participation this project attracted," he remarked. "We appreciate everyone who shared their thoughts, and we will consider the remaining suggestions as names for streets, parks, and other landmarks in the new city."

According to a report from Sydney Metro, the Western Sydney International Airport is scheduled to open in 2026, along with the accompanying metro system.

While some social media users have expressed concerns about the hotter climate in the area, Wikinews analyzed mean maximum temperatures for Sydney, Parramatta, and Bradfield, revealing average annual temperatures of 23.13°C, 23.8°C, and 24.04°C, respectively, based on data from 1996 to 2020.

Official records show that the City of Sydney was established in 1842 and covers an area of 26.15 square kilometers, while Sydney itself was first settled as a penal colony in 1788. Parramatta, founded in the same year, spans 84 square kilometers.

title: Ukrainian tow boat 'Chelyabinsk' collides with bridge at Baja, Hungary
content:
On Monday, a Ukrainian caravan collided with a bridge pillar on the river in Hungary. Although the caravan broke apart, it continued its journey downstream later that day. Fortunately, multiple sources confirmed that no casualties occurred.

The caravan, consisting of six grain barges being towed by the Chelyabinsk towboat, was navigating a route across the Danube when the incident took place around 12:54 PM (local time) near Baja.

The caravan strayed too far to the left of the navigable passage and struck a bridge pillar while attempting to turn right. Gyula Szabó, a nautical expert, attributed the collision to pilot error. An eyewitness reported to TV2 that strong winds also played a role in the accident.

Following the collision, the barges were salvaged by boats anchored at Baja. A police inspection revealed no leaks, and the reassembled caravan departed the scene later that same day.

In a statement to RTL Klub, nautical expert Dávid Pethő noted that this section of the river is particularly challenging to navigate with such a configuration. He added that the maneuver to cross the bridge needs to begin three kilometers upstream, leaving little room for error.

No significant damage was reported to the bridge, and cross-river traffic remained unaffected. The police classified the incident as an administrative offense.

title: India records 14 millionth case of COVID-19 amid new surge in infections
content:
India has reported a staggering 14 million COVID-19 cases, with new infections surpassing 200,000 on Thursday, leading to many hospitals operating at full capacity. 

The latest figure of 200,739 new infections is double that recorded during the previous peak in September. This surge has been attributed to a combination of factors, including the holding of large political rallies for local and state elections, religious gatherings, official complacency, and the emergence of highly transmissible new variants. Government officials have cited a "willful disregard" for health measures as a significant contributor to the crisis. A health officer remarked, "The number of unmasked individuals was notably higher last month. While caution has returned, many people still choose not to wear masks."

India surpassed Brazil to become the second-most infected country globally as of April 12, trailing only the United States. The spread of the new variant has compelled hospitals to take drastic measures, such as accommodating two or three patients per bed and repurposing over a dozen hotels and banquet halls in New Delhi into COVID-19 treatment centers. In states like Maharashtra, Madhya Pradesh, and Gujarat, there have been reports of oxygen shortages. The Ahmedabad Medical Association has urged the Gujarat state government for additional oxygen supplies, warning, "If this situation persists, the death toll will rise, and doctors may be forced to close hospitals due to lack of oxygen."

In response to the escalating crisis, the government has shifted its priorities from vaccine exports to domestic production, administering a total of 114 million vaccine doses—ranking it third globally after the U.S. and China. Additionally, India recently approved a third vaccine, developed by Russia, for emergency use. Despite concerns, the government maintains there is no oxygen shortage and attributes challenges in vaccine distribution to over-planning rather than a supply issue.

In New Delhi, authorities have implemented stay-at-home orders and closed non-essential establishments such as restaurants, malls, gyms, and spas, allowing limited operations for movie theaters. Mumbai has taken additional measures, shutting down most industries and public places and restricting movement as laborers flock to the city. A curfew is now in effect in Maharashtra’s epicenter, allowing only essential services to operate between 8 PM and 7 AM. Furthermore, the Central Board of Secondary Education (CBSE) has canceled Class 10 exams and postponed Class 12 exams.

The crisis has also taken a tragic toll, with 1,038 new deaths reported, bringing the national total to over 173,000. India now ranks fourth worldwide in COVID-related fatalities, following the United States, Brazil, and Mexico, placing immense pressure on local cremation centers and burial grounds.

title: People protest in Berlin against German Court overturning five-year rent cap
content:
On Thursday, Germany's Constitutional Court declared a five-year rent freeze, enacted in February of last year, illegal due to jurisdictional issues. This ruling allows landlords to raise rents, invalidating a law that had capped rent for approximately 90% of tenants in the nation. In response to the decision, protesters gathered in Berlin to demonstrate against both the court ruling and potential rent increases, with some demanding action from large real estate companies.

Demonstrators filled the streets of Berlin, particularly in the Neukölln and Kreuzberg districts, with reports indicating that thousands participated in the protests. The crowd marched from Hermannplatz to Oranienplatz and then to Kottbusser Tor, prompting police to close off several streets for the day. Organizers claimed that 25,000 people joined the protests, according to the Berlin Spectator.

Protesters carried signs with slogans such as "No more rent hikes!" and "Fair housing for all!" Many brought kitchen utensils, including lids from boiling pots, to make noise, leveraging the double meaning of the German word for lid, which also refers to a rent cap. Chants echoed through the streets, including the slogan, "If you take a cover from us, we'll come back with thousands."

The rent cap was initially introduced by a coalition of the Left and Green parties in the Berlin Senate, aiming to address the rising rental prices in the city. The appeal that led to the recent court ruling was filed by the Christian Democratic Union (CDU) and the Free Democratic Party (FDP).

The Berlin State Government's earlier ruling had set rents at their June 2019 levels from February 2020 until February 2025. A senator responsible for urban development expressed disappointment in the court's decision, emphasizing that the federal government or individual states now have the opportunity to establish laws to regulate rental prices.

title: US, UK, NATO to withdraw troops from Afghanistan
content:
On Wednesday, President Joe Biden announced plans for the United States to withdraw its troops from Afghanistan by September 11, marking the end of a 20-year involvement in the conflict. Similar troop withdrawal plans were also disclosed by the United Kingdom and NATO.

Former President Donald Trump had previously set a May 1 deadline for the withdrawal, and both the U.S. and its NATO allies are expected to commence troop reductions on that date. The scheduled end of the U.S. withdrawal coincides with the 20th anniversary of the September 11 attacks, which initiated the U.S.-led invasion of Afghanistan, the longest war in U.S. history.

Reflecting on the reasons for entering Afghanistan, Biden stated, "We went to Afghanistan because of a horrific attack that happened 20 years ago. That cannot explain why we should remain there in 2021." He emphasized the need to break the cycle of prolonging military operations in hopes of achieving ideal withdrawal conditions. Biden added, "I'm now the fourth U.S. president to oversee American troop presence in Afghanistan—two Republicans, two Democrats. I will not pass this responsibility on to a fifth."

Biden referenced a worldwide threat assessment that indicated the Taliban might gain ground militarily and argued that American troops should not serve as leverage in foreign conflicts, deeming such a situation an "indefinite" obligation. Afghan President Ashraf Ghani expressed via Twitter, "We will work with our U.S. partners to ensure a smooth transition."

Currently, there are about 2,500 U.S. troops deployed in Afghanistan as part of a NATO operation that includes approximately 9,600 personnel; NPR reports that around 1,000 special operations forces may also be present. Although combat operations by the U.S. and UK concluded in October 2014, this withdrawal marks a significant reduction in military presence.

Biden affirmed, "It's time for American troops to come home," emphasizing that the exit would be "responsible, deliberate, and safe." Although NATO and the UK will join in the troop pullout, the U.S. will maintain its "diplomatic and humanitarian work" in Afghanistan, according to the BBC.

NATO stated that its goal of preventing terrorists from using Afghanistan as a safe haven had been achieved, asserting, "There is no military solution to the challenges Afghanistan faces." A NATO statement reinforced this sentiment: "Our troops went into Afghanistan together, we have adjusted together, and now we are leaving together." German Defence Minister Annegret Kramp-Karrenbauer echoed this unity, asserting the importance of an orderly withdrawal.

U.S. Secretary of State Antony Blinken, during discussions in Brussels, expressed commitment to collaboration, emphasizing, "In together, adapt together, and out together."

In announcing the British drawdown, Defence Secretary Ben Wallace emphasized the importance of a stable future for Afghanistan while prioritizing the safety of current troops. "We must remember those who paid the ultimate sacrifice, who will never be forgotten," he stated.

After speaking with former President George W. Bush, Biden remarked on the shared respect for the valor and integrity of U.S. armed forces.

In the Senate, Republican Minority Leader Mitch McConnell criticized the withdrawal as "a grave mistake," warning that foreign terrorists would not cease their threats simply due to a change in U.S. policy. Another Republican lawmaker described it as "a huge propaganda victory for the Taliban and Al-Qaeda." Meanwhile, Democratic Senator Jeanne Shaheen cautioned that troop withdrawal should be based on the realities on the ground rather than arbitrary deadlines. Senator Elizabeth Warren supported Biden's plan, emphasizing that maintaining a troop presence does not enhance security. Former President Barack Obama also endorsed the decision, labeling it "the right choice."

The Director of the Central Intelligence Agency warned the Senate about potential threats posed by Al-Qaeda and ISIS in Afghanistan, noting a "significant risk" to U.S. interests.

title: Kim Yo Jong criticizes US-South Korean military drills
content:
On Monday, Kim Yo Jong, the vice department director of the Central Committee and sister of North Korean leader Kim Jong Un, issued a warning to the United States and South Korea in response to their recent joint military drills.

In a statement, Kim Yo Jong noted, "The peaceful spring days of three years ago are unlikely to return," referencing the inter-Korean meetings that took place in April 2018. 

She criticized the South Korean authorities, describing them as "all born with stupidity" and "dumb and deaf bereft of judgment." In light of the military exercises, which North Korea views as a threat, Kim suggested the possibility of closing various inter-Korean organizations, including the Kumgangsan International Tourism Bureau. "We are also considering dissolving the Kumgangsan International Tourism Bureau and other related organizations, as any cooperation and exchange with the South Korean authorities antagonizing us are no longer necessary," she stated.

Towards the end of her remarks, Kim emphasized, "If the United States wants to enjoy four years of peace, it had better refrain from causing a stir right from the start."

Yang Moo-Jin, vice president for public affairs at the University of North Korean Studies, told Arirang News that Kim's message indicates a willingness to engage in dialogue, provided South Korea demonstrates sincerity by avoiding escalation through joint military drills. Lim Eul-chul, a professor of North Korean studies, suggested that North Korea is reaffirming its long-standing position that talks will not occur unless sanctions against the regime are lifted. 

In an interview with Arirang News, a director at the Korea Risk Group described Kim's statement as typical, noting that similar messages have been issued each spring and advising against overestimating its impact. He characterized the message as "business as usual" and remarked that, by North Korean standards, it is relatively tame.

title: Wikinews interviews Democratic candidate for the Texas 6th congressional district special election Daryl Eddings, Sr's campaign manager
content:
**Wikinews Interviews Daryl Eddings, Sr. Campaign Manager Ahead of Texas Congressional District Special Election**

On March 23, Wikinews reached out via email to several candidates vying for the Democratic nomination to fill the Texas 6th congressional district seat, recently left vacant by the passing of Republican Congressman Ron Wright. Among those responding was Daryl Eddings, Sr., a federal law enforcement officer and decorated military veteran. On March 30, his campaign manager, Faith Chatham, provided insights into his campaign and policies during a phone interview.

Eddings' background is extensive. With 26 years in the military and over 30 years in federal law enforcement, he has served in roles such as an operations officer in aviation and has extensive experience responding to natural disasters and civil unrest. He is also the founder of Operation Battle Buddy, which aims to connect over 20,000 veterans and their families. Although born in California, he maintains deep roots in Texas.

His campaign runs amid a competitive election landscape. As per an Inside Elections poll published on March 18, Republican candidate Susan Wright, the late congressman's widow, leads with 21%. She is followed by Democrat Jana Sanchez at 17% and another Republican candidate at 8%, indicating strong Republican leanings in the district, which voted 51% for Donald Trump in 2020.

**Background of Daryl Eddings, Sr.**

Chatham described Eddings as a dedicated public servant with a remarkable military career, emphasizing his awards and honors. He has lived in Texas for years, nurtured a commitment to the region, and experienced the significant challenges facing its residents.

**Eddings on Responsibilities as a U.S. Representative**

Eddings believes a U.S. Representative's primary duty is to advocate for the needs of their constituents, lamenting that many currently in Congress serve narrow interests rather than the general populace. He stresses a commitment to the Constitution and is disturbed by political actions that undermine democratic processes, including attempts to restrict voting rights.

**Running in a Republican-Dominated District**

Chatham highlighted the shifting political dynamics in the district, which has been Republican-controlled since 1983. Recent trends show increasing Democratic support, particularly in Tarrant County, which has shown a shift toward purple territory. Eddings' connections, combined with a united Democratic front, position him as a serious contender.

**Views on Late Congressman Ron Wright's Governance**

Chatham critiqued Wright’s record, arguing he pushed policies that were detrimental to constituents. She expressed Eddings’ belief that Wright failed to address significant local issues like healthcare access and economic opportunities.

**Key Issues for Eddings If Elected**

Healthcare, affordable housing, education, and job creation are top priorities for Eddings. Chatham elaborated that his focus is not only on increasing minimum wage but also on creating well-paying jobs and promoting accessible education and training.

**Eddings’ Position on Current Political Climate**

Eddings shares concerns around partisanship and dark money in politics, advocating for transparency. He seeks to represent all constituents, regardless of political affiliation, and emphasizes that his dedication is to the people, not to partisan politics.

**Final Thoughts on the Campaign**

Chatham concluded that while Eddings is committed to addressing the community's needs and fostering unity, the impact of COVID-19 has significantly altered traditional campaigning methods. She acknowledged that engaging voters and building infrastructure in the district will be vital for Eddings’ campaign, no matter the outcome of this election.

This special election on May 1 presents Eddings with an opportunity to change the political landscape of a historically Republican district.

title: Serbian Orthodox Church elects new Patriarch Porfirije
content:
The Serbian Orthodox Church, the predominant Christian denomination in Serbia, elected Prvoslav Perić as the new Serbian Patriarch yesterday, filling the vacancy left by the death of Patriarch Irinej in November. Perić's formal enthronement is scheduled for today.

Ordained as a priest in 1985, Perić became Metropolitan in 2014. He will now lead a community of 12 million followers across former Yugoslav republics, including Kosovo, as well as dioceses in Australia, the United States, and beyond.

In the past, Perić has voiced conservative, pro-government sentiments, notably critiquing Serbian journalist and human rights advocate, Veran Matić, in December. He has also been a proponent of dismissing outspoken professors from the Faculty of Theology in Belgrade.

A current issue facing the Church involves property disputes in neighboring Montenegro. A law enacted in 2019 requires proof of ownership for properties built before 1918, yet the Montenegrin government continues to assert its claims over all Orthodox properties, most of which the Serbian Orthodox Church currently manages.

The Serbian Orthodox Church does not recognize Kosovo’s independence, aligning with the official stances of Russia and Serbia. Kosovo is home to significant religious sites in Orthodox Christianity and is regarded as a spiritual birthplace. Perić was ordained as a monk at a monastery in Kosovo.

The election occurred among 39 eligible bishops of the Holy Assembly of Bishops, who conducted a secret ballot at Belgrade's Cathedral. After deliberation, three candidates were selected, and Perić's name was drawn randomly, seen by believers as an expression of divine will.

A thanksgiving service was held immediately following the election.

Orthodox Christianity plays a crucial role in the cultural and public life of Serbia, Montenegro, and the contested region of Kosovo.

title: Winter storms hammer Texas, fatalities reported
content:
A series of winter storms have recently hit Texas, resulting in at least ten fatalities. On Wednesday, a second wave of severe weather affected utility services and water systems, prompting cities to urge residents to conserve water. Early reports indicated that more than 2.5 million homes and businesses were without power.

Tragically, one incident in Houston resulted in the deaths of a mother and her child, while a house fire in another city claimed the lives of a woman and three children. The storms have also disrupted the shipment of COVID-19 vaccines, according to reports. Residents were additionally advised to limit their electricity usage where possible. In Tyler, conditions on the roads became nearly impassable due to ice and snow on Monday and Tuesday.

Earlier this month, winter weather contributed to a massive vehicle pile-up in another Texas city, claiming at least five lives. Some victims were trapped in their vehicles for hours while waiting for rescue. During a press briefing, an emergency services official described the situation as a once-in-a-lifetime event.

title: Russian ambassador to US recalled over President Biden's comments
content:
The Russian ambassador to the United States was recalled on Wednesday following President Joe Biden’s remarks in an interview where he suggested that Vladimir Putin is a "killer" and stated that Russia would "pay a price" for its alleged interference in the 2020 U.S. presidential election.

U.S. intelligence officials released a report indicating that the Russian leader had authorized operations aimed at undermining Biden's candidacy. In the ABC News interview, Biden warned that if it is confirmed that Russia was involved in such actions, "then be prepared." When asked if he believes Putin is a killer, Biden responded affirmatively, adding that it is possible to "walk and chew gum at the same time" in areas where U.S. and Russian interests align.

This diplomatic tension follows the recent U.S. sanctions against seven senior members of the Russian government in response to the poisoning of opposition leader Alexei Navalny.

While acknowledging the need to work together on shared interests, Biden emphasized that he would be direct in his communications with Russia. Jalina Porter, a spokesperson for the State Department, reiterated a clear stance on the challenges posed by Russia, stating, "We remain clear-eyed about the challenges that Russia poses, and even as we work with Russia to advance U.S. interests, we'll also work to hold them accountable."

The State Department declined to comment on whether the U.S. would recall its own ambassador, who has been stationed in Moscow since 2020.

In a statement on the Russian Foreign Ministry's website, spokesperson Maria Zakharova confirmed that Ambassador Anatoly Antonov has been summoned to Moscow for consultations, expressing hope to "prevent an irreversible deterioration in relations" if the Americans recognize the risks involved.

title: European Medicines Agency calls AstraZeneca vaccine "safe and effective"
content:
The European Medicines Agency (EMA) announced on Thursday that the COVID-19 vaccine remains "safe and effective," following the suspension of its rollout by thirteen European Union (EU) nations. The agency emphasized that there is "no indication" of a link between the vaccine and blood clotting issues.

The EMA's review analyzed safety data from over 17 million vaccinated individuals in the EU and the UK, particularly looking into rare cases of blood disorders.

In a statement on its website, the Pharmacovigilance Risk Assessment Committee reiterated that "the benefits of the vaccine in combating the still widespread threat of COVID-19—which can also lead to clotting problems and can be fatal—continue to outweigh the risks of side effects." The committee found no connection between the vaccine, specific batches, or particular manufacturing sites and an increased likelihood of blood clots, though they did acknowledge a possible link to "very rare cases" of blood clots.

Despite receiving over 469 reports of blood clot incidents, including 191 from the EU, the EMA concluded that the overall number of reported cases following vaccination was lower than what would typically be expected in the general population.

In light of recent concerns, several European countries and others paused their vaccine rollouts after reports of blood clots and related fatalities in vaccinated individuals; Austria, for example, temporarily suspended certain batches.

During a press briefing on Thursday, the World Health Organization (WHO) reaffirmed its support for the AstraZeneca vaccine, with the Regional Director for Europe stating that while the exact causes of the incidents are still unclear, "the benefits of the AstraZeneca vaccine far outweigh its risks." The WHO plans to release a detailed report on its findings on Friday.

While individual nations can choose whether to heed EMA's recommendations, many indicated they would only resume vaccinations following the agency's guidance. France and Italy expressed readiness to "promptly restart" vaccinations if the EMA's upcoming results are positive, especially after an encouraging initial statement.

AstraZeneca has maintained that there is no increased risk of blood clotting associated with its vaccine. Among the 17 million people vaccinated in the EU and the UK, only 37 reports of blood clots were received—significantly lower than expected rates and similar to those observed with other authorized COVID-19 vaccines.

These recent vaccine suspensions have further complicated the EU's vaccination efforts, which are already suffering from notable supply shortages. French officials characterized their decision to temporarily halt the rollout as "not lost time," justifying the action based on a few "very unusual and troubling cases." Dr. Anthony Cox, a drug safety researcher at the University of Birmingham, described the situation as a "cascade of bad decision-making" across Europe.

title: Former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin found guilty of murdering George Floyd
content:
Yesterday, the Fourth Judicial District Court in Minnesota convicted former Minneapolis police officer Derek Chauvin of murdering George Floyd, a Black man. Chauvin was immediately taken into custody and faces a potential sentence of up to 40 years in prison.

Floyd died on May 25, 2020, after Chauvin, a white officer, knelt on his neck for over nine minutes, restricting his ability to breathe. Floyd, who was 46 years old at the time, was heard on video, recorded by a bystander, repeatedly saying, "I can't breathe." His death sparked widespread protests across the globe.

Chauvin, 45, faced charges of second-degree unintentional murder, third-degree murder, and second-degree manslaughter. His trial commenced on March 29, 2021.

In his defense, Chauvin's attorneys contended that his actions were "reasonable" and attempted to attribute Floyd's death to underlying health issues and the presence of illegal drugs in his system. The defense called various witnesses, including an expert on police use of force.

Conversely, witnesses for the prosecution—including a forensic pathologist and other medical experts—testified that Floyd died due to a lack of oxygen caused by Chauvin's actions, emphasizing that he used excessive force contrary to his training.

After deliberating for two days, the jury found Chauvin guilty on all counts. Three other former Minneapolis police officers—Tou Thao, J. Alexander Kueng, and Thomas Lane—are facing charges for aiding and abetting Chauvin and are awaiting trial. All four officers were terminated from the Minneapolis Police Department the day following Floyd's death.

title: Wikinews discusses DRM and DMCA with Richard Stallman after GitHub re-enables public access to youtube-dl
content:
**Title: Wikinews Interviews Richard Stallman on DRM and DMCA Following GitHub's Reinstatement of youtube-dl**

On November 16, GitHub reinstated public access to the youtube-dl repository, a software tool that enables users to download videos from various online platforms. This decision came after Mitchell Stoltz, a Senior Staff Attorney at the Electronic Frontier Foundation (EFF), sent a letter on behalf of the youtube-dl maintainers. The repository had been taken down on October 23, following a Digital Millennium Copyright Act (DMCA) takedown notice from the Recording Industry Association of America (RIAA).

Launched in July 2008, youtube-dl is a free and open-source program written in Python that allows users to download videos from many websites. The RIAA's takedown notice alleged that youtube-dl was designed to circumvent copyright protection systems under 17 U.S. Code § 1201, asserting that it could enable unauthorized redistribution of music videos. The source code for youtube-dl included test cases referencing various copyrighted songs, which the RIAA claimed violated copyright laws.

In response, Stoltz clarified in his letter to GitHub that the test files referenced in the source code were only used to verify the functionality of youtube-dl and did not contain permanent copies of the songs. He emphasized that streaming short clips merely to test the software's operation is legally acceptable. The EFF attorney pointed out that facebook-dl does not decrypt video streams that are protected by commercial DRM technologies.

Following the reinstatement, URLs to the copyrighted songs were removed from the source code and replaced with a test video uploaded by Philipp Hagemeister, the former maintainer of youtube-dl. Hagemeister had previously commented on the takedown in an interview with Wikinews.

youtube-dl operates as a command-line tool, utilizing “extractors” to manage video data from diverse sites. The EFF letter noted, “Any software capable of running JavaScript can derive the URL of a video stream,” demonstrating that YouTube’s instructions for accessing video streams are publicly available. The letter drew an analogy comparing this openness to the riddle found in "The Lord of the Rings": travelers must simply say the word "friend" to enter a door, illustrating that YouTube provides similar access to those who ask.

Hours after public access was restored, maintainers of youtube-dl expressed gratitude to GitHub and the EFF on GitHub, thanking them for supporting the project and enabling its continued development. Stoltz later tweeted that youtube-dl serves a vital purpose akin to that of a VCR, empowering users to control their consumption of freely available video content.

The project has a global user base and is widely employed for downloading Creative Commons and public domain material. It is also utilized by various citizen journalism platforms and serves purposes such as fair use and evidence preservation.

In a blog post titled "youtube-dl is back," GitHub acknowledged the project's potential for legitimate uses and stated that future DMCA takedown notices would be scrutinized by legal experts to ensure against unwarranted claims. In support of open-source developers, GitHub announced a $1 million donation to a developer defense fund.

Before the reinstatement, GitHub had taken public access control of multiple forks of youtube-dl, which remained blocked due to the RIAA’s DMCA notice.

During the downtime, Sergey M, one of the maintainers, hosted youtube-dl on GitLab. With GitHub's restoration of access, Sergey has made the GitLab repository private.

Wikinews then reached out to Richard Stallman, founder of the Free Software Foundation, to discuss the implications of DRM and DMCA 1201.

**Stallman on DRM and DMCA: Key Insights**

**What is DRM and whose rights does it protect?**
Stallman described DRM, or Digital Restrictions Management, as a system that limits user rights concerning copies of works. He argued that its purpose is to maintain power for content distributors rather than genuinely protecting creators' rights.

**What is your view on the RIAA's DMCA notice regarding youtube-dl?**
Stallman expressed that the notice distorted the law and emphasized the injustice of the DMCA, which facilitates oppression under the guise of copyright protection.

**Why was the DMCA introduced?**
He speculated that its primary motive was to grant more power to corporations while restricting sharing among individuals, particularly evident in its application against tools like youtube-dl.

**Is DRM essential for the DMCA's function?**
Stallman affirmed that DRM supports the DMCA's broader intent of repressing information sharing, highlighting that both components of the DMCA work to hinder the distribution of content.

**Impact of DRM on society:**
He noted that DRM centralizes control in the hands of a few corporations, stifling diversity and competition, and making alternatives to non-DRM solutions increasingly rare.

**Legislation and Reform Proposals:**
Stallman suggested outright abolishing anti-circumvention provisions in DMCA. He argued that harmful effects, particularly on the right to repair and software control, must be addressed to restore user autonomy.

Through this discussion, Stallman underscores the wider implications of DRM and DMCA on user rights and the digital landscape, advocating for change to empower users rather than corporations.

title: European Union to reduce carbon emissions by 55% of 1990 levels by 2030
content:
On Wednesday, the European Union (EU) announced an ambitious new climate goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by at least 55% from 1990 levels by 2030, with the aim of achieving zero net emissions by 2050. This marks an increase from the previous targets set in 2014, which aimed for a 40% reduction by 2030 and an 80-95% reduction by 2050. 

The new EU Climate Law was finalized after 14 hours of negotiations and includes the formation of a 15-member independent body tasked with advising on climate policy proposals. It also emphasizes increased investment in "carbon sinks." According to members of the European Parliament (MEP), these measures are expected to facilitate the achievement of a 57% net reduction target. However, this assertion has been challenged by Barbara Mariani, a senior policy officer for climate and energy, who argues that the proposed measures would only yield a 52.8% reduction in actual emissions.

In a press release from September 2020, the European Commission (EC) committed to presenting legislative proposals by June 2021, following extensive public consultation and impact assessments. These proposals will include limits on CO2 removal that counts towards the target, aimed at encouraging EU member states to reduce emissions rather than relying solely on carbon removal. The press release highlighted that adopting the new target in a timely manner would allow the EU to signal its elevated ambitions to international partners ahead of the Glasgow climate summit and set an example for other nations.

This new climate initiative also means that at least 30% of the EU's €1.8 trillion long-term budget will be allocated to climate-related measures. Notably, Poland has established its own climate strategy, opting not to commit to a broader pledge for climate neutrality. Instead, Poland has set a target to reduce emissions by 30% by 2030. The country currently derives 80% of its electricity from coal, but plans to shift towards renewable energy sources and develop its first nuclear power plant.

The EC president stated that this decision puts the EU "on a green path for a generation." However, some MEPs expressed disappointment, with one member stating, "we fought hard but achieved little," and describing the law as a "big disappointment." Wendel Trio, the Director of Europe, noted that the target of "at least 55% emission reduction by 2030" does not align with the EU's goal of limiting global temperature rise to 1.5°C by the end of the century, adding that the legislation felt rushed and insufficient for leading global climate action.

An MEP and chair of the European Parliament's environmental committee acknowledged the challenges in negotiating the language of the law, stating that while the Parliament was willing to pursue more ambitious targets, the "compromise found is ambitious: we are going to do two and a half times more in nine years than what we have accomplished in the last decade in Europe."

According to The Guardian, under current measures, the EU is on track to achieve a 46% reduction in emissions by 2030. The EC’s press release indicated that greenhouse gas emissions decreased by 25% from 1990 to 2019.

In contrast, multiple reports indicate that the United Kingdom has set a target to achieve a 78% emissions reduction by 2035.

title: Irish Finance Minister Donohoe criticises OECD's global minimum corporate tax rate
content:
On Tuesday, Ireland's Finance Minister Paschal Donohoe voiced concerns over negotiations facilitated by the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) aimed at establishing a global tax framework. He stressed that smaller nations like Ireland "must retain the ability to utilize tax policy as a legitimate tool to offset the significant, material, and ongoing advantages held by larger countries."

Speaking during a virtual seminar on international taxation, Donohoe emphasized that any new agreement should respect Ireland's established corporate tax rate of 12.5%. This rate has attracted major corporations such as Apple, Google, and Facebook, which collectively account for one in eight jobs in Ireland. In 2020, corporate tax receipts in Ireland reached €11.8 billion. Projections indicate that this figure will rise from €11.6 billion in 2021 to €12.5 billion by 2025, according to financial estimates.

Donohoe highlighted that Ireland's competitive tax rates help drive job creation and investment. While he is in favor of an agreement that promotes "appropriate and acceptable tax competition," he insists that any baseline rate be set below the 21% threshold proposed by the United States.

He urged recognition of the low tax rates in Ireland and other small countries, pointing out that larger nations benefit from "advantages of scale, location, resources, and industrial heritage." Defending the long-standing 12.5% rate, Donohoe argued it falls within the realm of healthy tax competition, fostering investment, growth, and innovation that align with Ireland's industrial strategy. According to The Guardian, current proposals could reduce Ireland's corporate tax base by 20%, leading to tax receipts estimated to be €2 billion lower than projected for 2025, according to the Irish Department of Finance.

Brian Keegan, the Director of Public Policy at the Irish Tax Institute, remarked that the issue at hand is "not about tax change; it's about political change." Meanwhile, Pascal Saint-Amans, head of tax at the OECD, noted that "a new dynamic is likely to lead us to a resolution," adding that the US's willingness to address concerns simplifies the complex negotiations.

An Irish Department of Finance spokesperson told CNBC on Monday that "political-level discussions on these issues have not yet occurred."

The Guardian has reported that many companies in Ireland pay considerably lower effective tax rates compared to their counterparts in other countries, with Apple paying as little as 0.005% in 2014. A European Commission ruling in 2016 mandated that Apple repay €13 billion in back taxes to the Irish government, but this ruling was overturned in July, with the court stating that "the commission did not succeed in demonstrating an advantage to the requisite legal standard."

title: Explosion after gas leakage in Madrid residential building kills four
content:
On Wednesday, an explosion at a residential building in central Madrid, Spain, resulted in the deaths of at least four people. Eyewitnesses reported detecting a strong smell of gas shortly before the blast occurred. The building, owned by a Roman Catholic Church, was completely destroyed in the explosion. Among the fatalities was David Santos Muñoz, an electrician who had been called to inspect the boilers.

At least ten others sustained injuries in the incident. Reports indicate that the gas odor was first noted around 2 PM local time, prompting the electrician's visit. Just minutes later, at 2:56 PM, the explosion occurred, claiming Muñoz's life along with at least three others. A nearby bar owner described the sound as "tremendous, as if a bomb had dropped," with another eyewitness likening the experience to an earthquake.

Fortunately, a nearby school and nursing home were largely unaffected; the nursing home experienced only minor damage, according to the city's mayor. No injuries were reported at either facility, as the school was empty due to recent closures following significant snowfall, and the nursing home was safely evacuated after the blast.

title: Italian ambassador to DR Congo, Luca Attanasio, killed in militia attack
content:
Yesterday, the Italian ambassador to the Democratic Republic of the Congo, Luca Attanasio, was killed alongside two others during an attack on a convoy traveling to Goma. Attanasio, who was 43 years old, reportedly sustained injuries and later succumbed to them in a hospital.

The assault took place near the town of Kanyamahoro at approximately 10:15 AM local time (08:15 UTC). According to the provincial governor, as reported by the BBC, the attack was carried out by six armed men who abducted the passengers and took them into Virunga National Park. The deaths were later confirmed by officials. The other victims were identified as military policeman Vittorio Iacovacci and a Congolese driver. No group has yet claimed responsibility for the attack, and Congolese authorities have suggested it may have been an attempted kidnapping.

Attanasio had a distinguished diplomatic career, serving in several countries including Morocco and Nigeria, and had been the ambassador to the Congo since late 2019, receiving accolades for his service.
