title: Seven Russians infected with H5N8 bird flu; first cases reported in humans
content:
Russian officials announced on Saturday that they have reported the world's first case of bird flu transmission to humans to the World Health Organization (WHO).

The head of the consumer rights protection agency and chief sanitary doctor, Dr. Anna Popova, stated that seven workers had contracted the H5N8 virus in December. She reassured the public by stating that "all seven are now feeling well" and that "the situation did not develop further." Dr. Popova added that they informed the WHO "several days ago, just as we became absolutely certain of our results."

While no human-to-human transmission has been detected thus far, Dr. Popova warned of the potential for mutations that could "overcome this barrier." She emphasized that this discovery provides "the entire world with time to prepare for possible mutations and react appropriately and promptly."

The WHO's European Regional Office indicated in an email that the reported cases were "asymptomatic" and that no transmission between humans had occurred, based on "preliminary information." They mentioned they are in discussions with national authorities to gather more details and assess the public health impact.

Genetic material from the infected workers has been isolated by Russian health authorities, who announced plans to develop tests for humans and an H5N8 vaccine.

Recent outbreaks of the H5N8 strain have been reported in poultry across China, Europe, the Middle East, and Russia.

Previous strains of bird flu have occasionally infected or killed humans, with most transmissions linked to direct contact with live or undercooked poultry.

title: World Trade Organization declares US tariff hike illegal, rules in South Korea's favour
content:
The World Trade Organization (WTO) ruled in favor of South Korea on Thursday, stating that the United States imposed excessive tariffs on certain South Korean products.

The eight tariffs, which cover large power transformers and four grades of steel, were implemented during the Barack Obama administration in 2012 and 2016. The U.S. government defended these high rates—ranging from 9.49% to 59.72% on steel and 60.81% on transformers—by invoking the "adverse facts available" (AFA) provision.

The AFA requires companies accused of dumping to provide detailed information; otherwise, they face significant anti-dumping and countervailing tariffs. After unsuccessful negotiations, South Korea officially filed a complaint with the WTO in February 2018.

A three-member WTO panel determined that the U.S. Commerce Department failed to clarify what specific information South Korean companies needed to provide and improperly dismissed some of the information submitted. Consequently, the tariffs imposed on Hyundai Electric & Energy Systems and others were deemed inconsistent with WTO regulations.

However, the panel did not support South Korea's assertion that U.S. authorities had an "unwritten measure" that encouraged the use of adverse facts to justify the elevated tariffs.

The United States has the option to appeal the decision within 60 days. However, it currently faces challenges due to restrictions imposed by former President Donald Trump, which have left it with fewer representatives than necessary for a quorum.

The European Union also participated in the case, highlighting the impact of U.S. practices on steelworkers in the UK, the Netherlands, and Italy.

Additionally, a 2018 ruling involving the United States and Canada found similar problems with the application of the AFA provision.

title: 'Rock and roll never dies': Italy wins Eurovision after 30 years
content:
Italy secured its third victory at the Eurovision Song Contest on Saturday, held at the Ahoy Arena in Rotterdam, Netherlands. The Italian rock band Måneskin triumphed with their song "Zitti e buoni," earning a total of 524 points from public votes and professional juries. French singer Barbara Pravi came in second with 499 points for her song "Voilà," while Swiss singer Gjon's Tears placed third with 432 points.

This year's competition featured 39 participating countries, with 26 countries, including host Netherlands and the Big Five (France, Germany, Italy, Spain, and the United Kingdom), competing in the grand final. The competition began on May 18. Notably, three of the Big Five, along with the host country, finished at the bottom of the rankings: Netherlands received 11 points, Spain garnered six, Germany secured three, and the UK ended up with zero points, all of which were from the public vote.

In 2019, Dutch singer Duncan Laurence won the Eurovision contest held in Tel Aviv with 498 points for his song "Arcade." This victory had positioned the Netherlands to host the competition in 2020, which was ultimately canceled due to the COVID-19 pandemic. This year, approximately 3,500 audience members attended, all of whom tested negative for the virus, according to Eurovision.

Iceland's Daði og Gagnamagnið was unable to perform live in both the semi-finals and the final after testing positive for COVID-19. A pre-recorded performance was aired instead, leading to a fourth-place finish with 378 points, just ahead of Ukrainian singer Go_A, who received 366 points.

During the initial jury voting, Switzerland topped the rankings with 267 points, while France followed closely with 248 points. Barbara Pravi expressed her excitement, stating, "I think it is crazy that two French songs are at the top, thank you!" The national juries from both Switzerland and the UK awarded their top points to France, with Pravi expressing her gratitude by clapping and blowing a kiss to the Swiss team.

In the audience vote, Italy received 318 points, securing their victory. Upon winning, Måneskin's lead vocalist Damiano David proclaimed, "We just want to say to all of Europe and the whole world, rock and roll never dies."

As this year's winners, Italy will host the Eurovision Song Contest next year. Italy previously won the competition in 1990. Måneskin is also the first band to win Eurovision since Lordi in 2006, as noted by the BBC.

title: Ahmedabad's Sardar Patel Cricket inaugrated after being renamed as 'Narendra Modi Stadium'
content:
On Wednesday, India’s President Ram Nath Kovind inaugurated the world’s largest cricket stadium, the Narendra Modi Stadium, located in Ahmedabad. Prime Minister Narendra Modi, who previously served as the Chief Minister of Gujarat, was instrumental in the stadium's conceptualization.

During his opening ceremony speech, President Kovind remarked, “This stadium was envisioned by Prime Minister Narendra Modi during his tenure as Chief Minister.” The event was attended by India’s Home Minister Amit Shah, Sports Minister Kiren Rijiju, and various members of the Board of Control for Cricket in India (BCCI).

Later in the day, the stadium hosted its inaugural international match, featuring India competing against England in a Day-Night Test match.

The newly constructed stadium has a seating capacity of approximately 132,000, replacing a previous venue that held 49,000 spectators and was named after Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, India’s first Deputy Prime Minister. The stadium is a key part of the planned Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel Sports Enclave in the city.

title: North Korea tests two missiles
content:
On Thursday, Japanese Prime Minister Fumio Kishida announced that North Korea had launched two suspected ballistic missiles into the sea near Japan. Japanese authorities reported that the first missile was fired at 22:04 UTC, followed by a second launch at 22:23 UTC. The missiles reportedly traveled distances of 420 and 430 kilometers, respectively, before landing in the sea.

In a commentary for Reuters, Harry Kazianis, senior director of Korean studies at the Center for the National Interest in Washington, D.C., suggested that this recent missile launch was likely a response to U.S. President Joe Biden's downplaying of North Korea's missile tests during the previous weekend. Kazianis remarked, "While Biden's comments and chuckle were clearly not intended to provoke a reaction, the North Koreans will use any pretext to escalate tensions, potentially pulling us closer to the dark days of 2017." President Biden stated, "According to our intelligence, it's business as usual. There are no significant changes in their actions."

Earlier this week, North Korea also launched two short-range cruise missiles into its western sea, an action that neither South Korea nor the U.S. deemed a violation of United Nations Security Council Resolutions, according to reports. Local experts quoted by Arirang News suggested that this particular missile test served as a warning to Washington, D.C., while remaining sufficiently restrained to avoid provoking a stronger response.

title: Tropical moisture ceases to cause severe floods in South East Australia
content:
On Tuesday, heavy rainfall that had significantly exceeded average levels in New South Wales (NSW), south of Queensland and north-east of South Australia, came to an end. Over the preceding five days, these torrential downpours led to widespread flooding and posed hazards to farms and homes, with some areas receiving up to a month’s worth of rainfall in just 48 hours—most notably, 150mm reported by the Bureau of Meteorology (BoM) on Monday and Tuesday.

The BoM indicated that the weather was beginning to improve, with rains shifting eastward; however, rising water levels and numerous active flood alerts remained a concern in affected areas. Meteorologists noted that while eastern regions might recover from floodwaters relatively quickly, areas west of the Great Dividing Range could face prolonged effects, potentially lasting weeks or even months before levels return to normal. Additionally, thick fog is expected this weekend as temperatures drop below the dew point, leading to mist formation, as per meteorologist warnings.

In NSW, ABC News reported multiple rescues of cows from rivers and rough surf, alongside a distressing incident where a homeowner's dwelling was swept away on their wedding day. A farmer on the Mid-North Coast lost both his house and livestock due to the severe weather. In residential areas, the Hawkesbury region continued to experience rising flood levels as of Monday. Ian Wright, a researcher at Western Sydney University, highlighted the dangers of flooding in Hawkesbury due to the challenging terrain and the substantial water flow from nearby rivers, referencing a related study.

On Monday, NSW Police rescued an 80-year-old woman trapped in a car on River Road in Wyong, Central Coast, moments before the vehicle was swept into the river. Local authorities urged residents to avoid flooded areas, and the BoM issued a Road Weather Alert for Sydney and its suburbs on Monday. Government agencies, including Simon Oliver, a disaster recovery officer from the Department of Primary Industries, announced plans to assist flood victims with emergency provisions, including fodder and support for displaced livestock.

The BoM anticipates improved weather conditions on Wednesday as a warmer, drier air mass moves in, accompanied by a coastal low. 

Since March 16, the Australian BoM has issued various severe weather, marine wind, hazardous surf, and flood warnings for the affected regions. Reports indicate that while the immediate effects of the severe weather may be waning, repercussions could still be felt into late March and early April.

title: Australia: Latrobe Valley historical societies ask for greater funding in budget submissions
content:
On Monday, Barbara Johnson, secretary of the Latrobe Combined History Group, addressed councillors in Victoria, Australia, advocating for an increase in grants for local historical societies. Since 1994, the area's six historical societies have received an annual grant of A$500 from the council for administrative expenses. In her presentation, Johnson emphasized the importance of these societies as "repositories of information for the council" and highlighted the necessity for them to "remain alive and viable" to provide essential services when needed. 

Johnson's address came during an unscheduled council meeting, which was called following the release of the council's draft budget on April 12. A 28-day period was allowed for submissions on the proposals contained in the draft. Johnson opted to elaborate on her written submission on behalf of the Latrobe Combined History Group during the meeting.

In her speech, Johnson pointed out rising communication costs, noting that postage expenses have doubled in recent years. While historical societies have attempted to cut costs by transitioning to digital communication, she stated that this still incurs expenses for internet access, software, and web development. Additionally, societies must maintain their equipment, with the Traralgon Historical Society facing annual expenses exceeding A$250.

Johnson highlighted how each society has had to adapt to increasing costs and demands, using the Traralgon Historical Society as an example. The society has reduced its bulletin production and ceased outsourcing this work to local businesses, which Johnson argued detracts from the local economy. She concluded by stressing that historical societies must endure to benefit future generations.

In her written submission, Johnson requested A$1,000 per society, confirming to Councillor Dale Harriman that this would increase the council's expenditure by A$3,000 compared to the current funding. Harriman acknowledged the significant contributions historical societies make to the council and the broader community, pointing out that the A$500 grant has not changed in seventeen years.

Harriman also inquired about the fees charged by historical societies for their services. Johnson cited an instance where Traralgon and other societies provided maps for identifying asbestos in residential homes, charging A$400 for this service. Harriman remarked that A$400 was "less than it would cost to actually chase up and find them."

The Latrobe Combined History Group, represented by Johnson, encompasses six historical societies from Moe, Morwell, Traralgon, and surrounding areas.

title: Olivia Rodrigo's song good 4 u debuts at No 1 on US Billboard Hot 100 chart
content:
**Olivia Rodrigo's "good 4 u" Debuts at No. 1 on the US Billboard Hot 100 Chart**

On Monday, Billboard announced that Olivia Rodrigo's new song "good 4 u" has debuted at #1 on the chart dated May 29. The Billboard Hot 100 ranks the most popular songs in the United States each week, taking into account sales, streaming, and radio airplay.

In the week ending May 23, "good 4 u" garnered 43.2 million streams, sold 12,000 downloads, and reached an audience of 3.8 million on the radio.

Released on May 14, "good 4 u" arrived just a week before the launch of Rodrigo's debut studio album, *SOUR*. The track marks Rodrigo's second No. 1 single, following her debut single, "drivers license," which also entered the chart at No. 1 in January. Notably, she is the only artist according to Billboard to have her first three singles—those promoted to both streaming services and radio—debut in the top 10, with "deja vu" debuting at No. 8 in April.

To celebrate the achievement, Rodrigo shared a meme of a sobbing cat with the caption, "GOOD 4 U IS NUMBER ONE![...] IM SO HAPPY AHHHHHH!" In her post, she also thanked collaborators like Alexander 23, who produced "good 4 u" alongside Dan Nigro, who co-wrote the track. This week’s Hot 100 chart also featured four other debuts in the top 10, all from Rodrigo's new album, *SOUR*.

title: Indonesian Navy declares crew of 53 dead after submarine sinks in Bali Strait
content:
**Indonesian Submarine Declared Sunk After Losing Contact During Training Exercise**

On Saturday, Indonesian authorities confirmed that the KRI Nanggala-402 submarine, which lost contact at 4:30 AM local time on Wednesday, has sunk and broken apart during a training exercise. The Indonesian Navy announced that all 53 crew members on board have been declared deceased, and wreckage has been located.

Air Marshal Tjahjanto reported that images received show various parts of the submarine, including the rear vertical rudder, anchors, outer pressure body, and dive rudder. 

The Navy indicated that the submarine is now officially considered sunk rather than merely missing, as earlier assessments suggested the oxygen supply would have run out by Saturday morning.

Items retrieved from the vicinity of the submarine include a bottle of grease, prayer mats, and a piece of metal pipe. Tjahjanto noted that the debris found near the last known location of the submarine consisted of its parts, which could not have exited unless subjected to significant water pressure.

Tjahjanto also pointed out that an oil spill was observed in the area, suggesting that the submarine might have experienced a leak due to descending too deep or when attempting to surface.

Search efforts are currently focused on pinpointing the exact location of the submarine, but authorities caution that salvage operations will be challenging because of the considerable depth.

The Singapore Navy's submarine rescue ship has assisted in the operation, deploying a robot that captured images of the wreck. Other nations, including Malaysia, the United States, India, and Australia, have also contributed resources to the search for potential rescue opportunities. The Indonesian ship KRI Rigel scanned the area where the submarine is believed to have sunk using sonar and other advanced equipment.

According to military chief General Andika Perkasa, the scans revealed that the submarine is located at a depth of 850 meters, well below its survivable limit of 500 meters. "The cracks began to form gradually in various parts as it descended,” Margono explained.

title: US President Biden recognises Armenian killing as 'genocide'
content:
On Saturday, U.S. President Joe Biden became the first sitting president to officially recognize the killing and deportation of ethnic Armenians by the Ottoman Empire during World War I as a "genocide." 

In a statement commemorating the 106th anniversary of the tragedy, Biden expressed, "[t]he American people honor all those Armenians who perished in the genocide that began 106 years ago today [...] We remember the lives of all those who died in the Ottoman-era genocide and recommit ourselves to preventing such an atrocity from ever occurring again." He further emphasized, "we remember so that we remain ever-vigilant against the corrosive influence of hate in all its forms."

During his presidential campaign, Biden pledged to support a resolution recognizing the Armenian Genocide. His commitment is in line with a 2019 resolution passed by the U.S. House of Representatives that formally acknowledged the killings as genocide. Additionally, a U.S. Senate resolution passed on April 9, 2019, vowed to commemorate the Armenian Genocide and to reject any efforts that would associate the U.S. government with denial of the genocide.

While Ronald Reagan referred to the "Armenian genocide" in 1981, no president has acknowledged it since. His predecessor, Donald Trump, described it as "one of the worst mass atrocities of the 20th century." Turkey, however, has historically denied that the events constituted genocide.

Armenia's Prime Minister expressed gratitude in a tweet, stating, "[t]he U.S. has once again demonstrated its unwavering commitment to protecting human rights and universal values." He described Biden's recognition as a "powerful step in acknowledging the truth." The director of the Armenian National Committee of America called the recognition "profoundly meaningful for our families."

In contrast, Turkish officials rejected Biden's declaration. A statement from the Turkish government condemned the president's remarks, claiming they were made under pressure from "radical Armenian circles and anti-Turkey groups." Turkish Foreign Minister Mevlüt Çavuşoğlu tweeted, "[w]ords cannot change or rewrite history. We have nothing to learn from anybody regarding our own past."

An anonymous source informed the AP that during a phone call on Friday, Biden informed Turkish President Recep Tayyip Erdoğan of his intention to make the statement. The U.S. President's Executive Office confirmed ongoing efforts by both nations to seek "effective management of disagreements," with NBC News reporting a focus on building a "constructive bilateral relationship."

title: Wynnum defeat Maroochydore in round 4 of Australia's Sunshine Coast Rugby Union 2021 season
content:
On Saturday, Wynnum "Bugs" secured a convincing 29-10 victory over Maroochydore in round four of Australia’s Sunshine Coast Rugby Union. The Bugs jumped ahead with two early tries before Maroochydore responded with a penalty goal, leaving Wynnum with a 10-3 lead at halftime.

"Full credit to the boys, especially the forward pack, which dominated throughout the match," said Wynnum player Nathan Urquhart. "They pushed forward, allowing us to spread the play out to the backs and exploit gaps with strong running. Our scrummaging was exceptional, which put them on the back foot and allowed the backs to shine."

Wynnum added three tries in the second half, while Maroochydore managed to score one in response.

"It was tough to watch,” commented Maroochydore coach Ben Radmall. "I think the boys may have underestimated the challenge after seeing Wynnum's performance against University last week. They might have thought it would be an easy game."

In other results, University triumphed over Caboolture with a score of 60-5, while Noosa retained the SGQ Shield by defeating Caloundra 29-14.

title: Football: Chelsea appoints Thomas Tuchel as manager following Lampard sacking
content:
On Tuesday, English football club Chelsea appointed Thomas Tuchel as their new manager, following the dismissal of Frank Lampard on Monday.

Tuchel, who previously managed Borussia Dortmund and Paris Saint-Germain (PSG), led PSG to two titles—the French Cup and the French League Cup—and guided them to the UEFA Champions League final last season. He is the first German to take charge of Chelsea.

In his first statement as manager, Tuchel expressed his enthusiasm, saying, "I cannot wait to meet my new team and compete in the most exciting league in football. I am grateful to be part of the Chelsea family." Following his appointment, Chelsea played to a 0–0 draw in their next match.

Due to UK regulations, Tuchel is required to self-quarantine for five days upon arrival. However, the English authorities granted him an exception to attend matches and training sessions, provided he tests negative for COVID-19 before entering the country.

Lampard's dismissal came after a downturn in form, with Chelsea sitting ninth in the Premier League and having won only two of their last eight matches.

Tuchel has signed an 18-month contract, with the option for an additional year.

title: Football: Chelsea sacks Frank Lampard as club's manager
content:
On Monday, Chelsea Football Club announced the dismissal of manager Frank Lampard following a troubling decline in the team's performance. The 42-year-old, who was appointed as manager in July 2019 after a successful 13-season playing career at the club, has seen the team win just two of their last eight matches, resulting in a drop to ninth place in the Premier League standings.

In a statement, Chelsea expressed that "This has been a very difficult decision, one that the owner and the board have not taken lightly." They acknowledged the challenge of parting ways with a club legend, stating, "There can never be a good time to move on from someone like Frank, but after extensive deliberation, it was determined that a change is necessary to improve performances and results this season."

Lampard shared his disappointment, saying he had hoped for more time to advance the club and propel it to the next level. Chelsea's owner, Roman Abramovich, commented on the difficulty of the decision, emphasizing his excellent personal relationship with Lampard and the respect he holds for him.

Last summer, Lampard invested over £200 million on seven new signings, including £71 million on a player from a prominent club and £45 million on another key acquisition. This season, Chelsea has accumulated only 29 points in the Premier League, trailing eleven points behind league leaders Manchester United.

title: Anas Sarwar wins leadership of Scottish Labour party
content:
Today, Anas Sarwar has been elected as the new leader of Scottish Labour in anticipation of the upcoming Scottish Parliament elections scheduled for May 6. Sarwar, a Member of the Scottish Parliament representing Glasgow, secured victory with 57.6% of the vote, surpassing his opponent, Richard Leonard, who received 42.4%, according to the BBC. The leadership election was initiated following Leonard's resignation.

In his acceptance speech, Sarwar addressed the people of Scotland, acknowledging the challenges that lie ahead for the Labour party. “I know Labour has a lot of work to do to win back your trust. If we're brutally honest, you haven't had the Scottish Labour Party you deserve. With rising injustice, inequality, and division, I’m sorry we haven’t been good enough. I will work day and night to change that, so we can build the country we all need,” he stated.

Sarwar has already received congratulations on his victory from a range of political figures, including allies and rivals, such as Labour Party leader Keir Starmer, First Minister Nicola Sturgeon, Scottish Conservatives leader Douglas Ross, Scottish Greens co-leader Lorna Slater, and Scottish Liberal Democrats leader Willie Rennie. 

**Headline:** Anas Sarwar Elected Leader of Scottish Labour Ahead of May Elections

title: Wikinews mourns loss of volunteer John Shutt
content:
**Wikinews Remembers Dedicated Volunteer John Shutt**

On Friday, Wikinews was saddened to learn of the passing of Dr. John Nathan Shutt, a devoted contributor to both Wikinews and Wikibooks, who died on Wednesday at the age of 56. Known in the Wikinews community as Pi zero, Dr. Shutt was the platform's top contributor by edit count and ranked third on English Wikibooks.

His elder sister, Barbara Shutt, informed Wikinews of his death in an email early Friday. She reported that their mother called emergency services after Dr. Shutt experienced difficulty breathing. Unfortunately, by the time the ambulance arrived, he was unconscious. Barbara noted that the doctors operated on him for two hours, but Dr. Shutt ultimately succumbed either to blood clots or a series of heart attacks.

Dr. Shutt was a highly active editor and administrator on Wikinews, contributing under the username Pi zero since September 2008. He became an administrator in July 2010 and a reviewer in August 2009. Over the years, he peer-reviewed and published more than a thousand news articles on the platform, with his last contribution made just a day before his passing. He accumulated over 160,000 edits and more than 120,000 log entries on English Wikinews.

In addition to his work on Wikinews, Dr. Shutt held reviewer and administrator privileges on English Wikibooks, where he contributed to several titles, including "Kotlin Programming" and "Algebraic Structures." He also created a sorting mechanism for the project's content.

Beyond his contributions to Wikimedia projects, Dr. Shutt occasionally blogged on his platform, "Structural Insight," and had a keen interest in constructed languages (conlangs). He was an avid reader, particularly enjoying the works of J.R.R. Tolkien.

Reflecting on his experiences with Tolkien's literature last year, Dr. Shutt shared, "I read *The Hobbit* when I was a teenager. I read it again a few months ago... It's a wonderfully written story—by a linguist and, in fact, a conlanger."

Dr. Shutt earned a Ph.D. in 2011 from Worcester Polytechnic Institute (WPI) in Massachusetts, where his research focused on Abstraction theory, the Kernel programming language (which he created), Recursive Adaptive Grammars, and Self-Modifying Systems, a project he worked on alongside Roy Rubinstein. He received both his bachelor’s and master’s degrees from WPI and had spent a year at Brown University for his postgraduate studies.

Throughout his career, Dr. Shutt maintained a connection with the programming community, notably collaborating with Andres Navarro and Oto Havle, who implemented the Kernel programming language in a project. He expressed a sense of pride in being mentioned by Michael MacInnis during a talk at the BSDCan conference regarding his work on Kernel.

Dr. Shutt, who lived in Massachusetts, is survived by his mother, Elsie Shutt; his sister, Barbara; his niece, Hannah; his brother, David; and his beloved cat, Pickles. He would have celebrated his 57th birthday next Friday.

The Wikinews community remembers Dr. Shutt for his significant contributions, dedication, and the lasting legacy he leaves behind.

title: Arizona bans abortion for genetic abnormalities
content:
On Tuesday, Arizona Governor Doug Ducey signed into law a controversial bill that prohibits abortions sought solely due to a fetus's genetic abnormality.

Senate Bill 1457, which faced significant opposition and was stalled on two occasions, successfully passed through both chambers of the Republican-controlled Arizona Legislature last week. The bill was amended twice to address concerns from some hesitant Republican lawmakers.

The new law establishes a Class 6 felony, the least severe designation, for seeking or performing an abortion based on "a genetic abnormality of the child." This is defined as "the presence or presumed presence of an abnormal gene expression in an unborn child," but excludes what is classified as a "severe fetal abnormality" deemed "incompatible with life." Additionally, intimidating someone into getting an abortion or soliciting financial assistance for this purpose is classified as a Class 3 felony.

The legislation also grants the unborn child's father, or a maternal grandparent if the mother is under 18, the right to sue. It applies Arizona law to "an unborn child at every stage of development," which could potentially expose individuals, including the pregnant person, to charges of murder, manslaughter, or child endangerment for actions leading to a miscarriage.

Further provisions of the bill include a ban on the delivery of abortion-inducing drugs through courier services, a restriction preventing public educational institutions from performing or assisting with non-life-saving abortions, and prohibitions on utilizing public or state funds for university research involving fetal remains or for organizations that provide abortion services. The law also mandates that all fetal remains must be either buried or cremated.

Governor Ducey, known for his anti-abortion stance, expressed in a statement, "There's immeasurable value in every single life, regardless of genetic makeup. We will continue to prioritize protecting life in our preborn children, and this legislation goes a long way in protecting real human lives." He emphasized that Arizona is committed to being a leader in pro-life advocacy.

Supporters of the bill, including Senator Nancy Barto, stated, "We need to protect our most vulnerable, especially those with treatable genetic conditions. They are beloved members of our community, integral to Arizona's identity." Cathi Herrod, president of the Center for Arizona Policy, commented, "Today, Arizonans win."

However, critics have condemned the legislation. Representative Palma stated her disappointment, highlighting that Arizona is disregarding the needs of doctors, women, and families for an extreme political agenda. Democratic Leader Reginald Bolding called it "disturbing and wrong" that the legislature is not focusing on policies to support women while instead restricting fundamental freedoms related to family planning.

In response to the bill, the United Campus Workers union urged university leaders, including the presidents of Arizona State University and the University of Arizona, to publicly oppose SB 1457, describing it as "a blatant attack on reproductive freedom."

title: Austrian Airlines cancels Moscow-bound flight after Russia refuses a reroute outside Belarusian airspace
content:
Austrian Airlines canceled cargo-passenger flight OS601 from Vienna to Moscow on Thursday after Russian authorities rejected a proposed flight route that would have circumvented Belarusian airspace.

The decision comes in the wake of heightened tensions following the grounding of a Ryanair flight in Minsk, Belarus, on Sunday due to a bomb scare and the subsequent arrest of opposition journalist Roman Protasevich and his girlfriend. In response, the European Union imposed sanctions on Belarus, prompting several air carriers, including Austrian Airlines, to avoid Belarusian airspace and airports.

An Austrian Airlines spokesperson stated that the airline "has suspended flights over Belarusian airspace until further notice," necessitating a change in the flight route from Vienna to Moscow. However, Russian officials did not approve the revised route.

The spokesperson referred to a recommendation from the European Union Aviation Safety Agency (EASA), which published a Safety Information Bulletin on May 25 urging operators to "avoid operations in [Flight Information Region] Minsk" unless absolutely necessary. The bulletin emphasized that third-party operators authorized by EASA should also adhere to this guidance when flying to, from, and within the EU until an international investigation into Protasevich's arrest is completed.

According to The Guardian, Air France also canceled a flight from Paris to Moscow for the second consecutive day due to similar issues, with at least four flights from Paris to Moscow reported as canceled, according to the BBC. An Austrian Airlines cargo flight bound for Vienna from China was similarly grounded over safety concerns.

The Guardian noted that British Airways modified its routes, receiving the necessary approvals, and that other carriers have made similar adjustments.

Austria's Foreign Ministry expressed confusion over Russia's stance, emphasizing that all flights heading to and over Russia should proceed without obstruction. In response to media inquiries, Russian Press Secretary Dmitry Peskov stated that the presidential administration does not control air traffic and suggested directing questions to "our aviation authorities."

The United Nations International Civil Aviation Organization convened an "exceptional session" on Thursday regarding the initial grounding incident, as Belarus is accused of violating the 1944 Chicago Convention, to which it is a signatory.

In a May 25 report by the BBC, several European airlines, including KLM, Lufthansa, and Scandinavian Airlines, announced their suspension of flights over Belarusian airspace. LOT Polish Airlines halted flights to and from Minsk, and Ukraine imposed a ban on all carriers flying over or into Belarus. Singapore Airlines has also begun rerouting its flights.

Belarus's national airline, Belavia, has faced numerous cancellations, including the revocation of its operating permit in the UK and the suspension of eleven routes to EU cities, along with flights to France and the UK until October 30, according to the BBC.

title: Georgian defense ministry announces return of military units from Afghanistan
content:
On Friday, military officials announced that Georgian troops had successfully completed their mission in Afghanistan. The personnel returned to Georgia, where they were welcomed at an airport by Deputy Commander of the Armed Forces, Brigadier General Joni Tatunashvili; Commander of the Western Command, Brigadier General Koba Grigolia; and other representatives from the Western Command.

Since 2004, over 20,000 Georgian servicemen have participated in international missions in Afghanistan, contributing to a total of 107 rotations at various levels, including combat and support roles, according to an official statement.

Prior to the complete withdrawal, Georgia had deployed approximately 860 servicemen in Afghanistan, according to local sources. The withdrawal of Georgian troops began on May 21.

This decision to withdraw aligns with a broader announcement made by U.S. President Joe Biden in April, indicating plans to conclude American involvement in Afghanistan by September 11, effectively ending a 20-year military engagement. Similar troop withdrawal announcements were made by the United Kingdom and NATO.

title: Ransomware attack hits over 200 US companies, forces Swedish grocery chain to close
content:
On Friday, a cyberattack initially targeting Kaseya, a software company, expanded to affect over 200 organizations across the U.S. via its network management software. Huntress Labs has attributed the attack to REvil, a Russia-based ransomware group. Upon discovering the breach, Kaseya advised its customers to immediately halt the use of its services.

According to NBC News, the ransomware first infiltrated about 40 of Kaseya's clients, primarily companies that provide internet services and manage infrastructure for thousands of businesses. Security researcher John Hammond from Huntress Labs stated, "It’s reasonable to think this could potentially impact thousands of small businesses." Kaseya alerted its customers of the attack late Friday afternoon and recommended they cease using its platform right away.

Reports indicate that REvil operates as a ransomware-as-a-service provider. BleepingComputer received a sample of the ransomware utilized in these attacks and noted that it demands a ransom of $5 million for the decryption of compromised files, although it remains unclear whether all victims received the same demand. Fabian Wosar, Chief Technology Officer at Emsisoft, reported that some affected customers were asked to pay $44,999.

Among the impacted entities is the Swedish grocery chain Coop, which had to shut down all 800 of its stores because its checkout systems were rendered inoperable due to the ransomware. Coop spokesperson Therese Knapp told Swedish Television, "We have been troubleshooting and restoring all night but have communicated that we will need to keep the stores closed today." Additionally, Swedish company Visma Esscom, which provides server management for businesses, was also using Kaseya software, according to Reuters. The attack also disrupted railway services in Sweden.

On Saturday, U.S. President Joe Biden directed intelligence agencies to investigate the origins of the attack. He remarked, "We're not sure who is behind the attack," adding, "The initial thinking was it was not the Russian government, but we're not certain yet." The U.S. government stated it is actively working to understand and respond to the recent supply-chain ransomware incident.

title: 130 countries at OECD summit agree to back global corporate tax rate
content:
**130 Countries Reach Agreement on Global Minimum Corporate Tax Rate at OECD Summit**

On Thursday, a significant majority of the 139 countries and jurisdictions participating in the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) summit on taxation backed an overhaul of the international taxation system. This agreement seeks to establish a global minimum corporate tax rate, effectively committing most of the world's economies to a two-pillar framework.

Notable jurisdictions that agreed to the primary components of the plan include regional entities such as Gibraltar, Hong Kong, and Montserrat, alongside recognized tax havens like Bermuda and the Cayman Islands. All G20 countries endorsed the agreement; however, several nations, including Barbados, Estonia, Hungary, Ireland, Kenya, Nigeria, Sri Lanka, and Saint Vincent and the Grenadines, opted out. Peru abstained from the vote due to its current lack of government, as reported by The Guardian.

The signatories represent over 90% of global GDP. According to an OECD press release, this framework is the culmination of nearly a decade of coordinated negotiations and critiques the "century-old international tax system" as "no longer fit for purpose." The plan has garnered support from U.S. President Joe Biden and follows a similar international taxation agreement reached on June 5.

Formally called the "OECD/G20 Inclusive Framework on Base Erosion and Profit Shifting," the plan adopts a two-pillar approach, with an implementation plan expected to be finalized by October.

Under the first pillar, multinational enterprises (MNEs) with global turnover exceeding €20 billion and profitability above 10% will be required to redistribute tax on over $100 billion in profit from their home jurisdictions to any market where they earn at least €250,000, depending on the market's GDP. The OECD has noted that the threshold for the first pillar may adjust to encompass MNEs exceeding €10 billion in turnover, subject to a review in seven years.

The second pillar includes two "Global Anti-Base Erosion Rules" enforcing a minimum top-up tax of 15%, along with a treaty-based "Subject to Tax Rule" set to take effect in 2023.

The OECD estimates that the implementation of both pillars could increase global corporate income tax (CIT) reserves by approximately 1.9% to 3.2%, or between $50 billion and $80 billion. When factoring in the U.S. tax on global intangible low-taxed income, the increase could range from 2.3% to 4%, equating to $56 billion to $102 billion. This move is also projected to combat tax avoidance, which the OECD claims costs countries between $100 billion and $240 billion in lost revenue annually.

However, the OECD has indicated a "relatively small" negative impact on investment and economic activity, estimated at just 0.1% of GDP in the medium to long term. Concerns have also been raised about potential constraints on governments' abilities to use tax incentives for policy purposes and the challenge of ensuring compliance.

Countries like Hungary and Ireland have publicly opposed the agreement, as they have historically maintained lower tax rates to attract foreign investment. Both countries, along with Estonia, currently implement corporate rates below the proposed minimum of 15%. In Ireland, the corporate tax rate stands at 12.5%, while Hungary's is as low as 9%, which could result in significant revenue losses if the new agreement is adopted.

OECD Secretary-General Mathias Cormann emphasized in the press release that this "historic package will ensure that large multinational companies pay their fair share of tax everywhere," while noting that it does not eliminate tax competition but establishes multilaterally agreed limitations.

President Biden indicated that this deal marks a step toward a "full global agreement to halt the race to the bottom," which U.S. Treasury Secretary Janet Yellen described as a futile competition. Meanwhile, the French Finance Minister hailed it as "the most important international tax agreement in a century."

Irish Finance Minister Paschal Donohoe voiced reservations about the agreement but affirmed Ireland's commitment to the process, assuring the global community of Ireland's participation in achieving a comprehensive and historic agreement. Hungarian Prime Minister Viktor Orbán labeled the proposal as "absurd," declaring that the nation's low rates serve to attract various companies to contribute taxes rather than establishing it as a tax haven.

Looking ahead, Italy is set to host G20 finance ministers and central bank governors for a "G20 High-Level Tax Symposium" on July 9.

title: Post match interview with Maroochydore Rugby Union Club's James Turvey on his 100 A grade games
content:
Few players achieve the milestone of one hundred top-grade games at their local football club, whether they play rugby or soccer. James Turvey of Maroochydore Rugby Union accomplished this feat on Saturday in a match against Noosa.

During his tenure at Maroochydore, Turvey has also represented the Sunshine Coast in the South Queensland competitions and has played for the Country Championship against regional teams.

Wikinews reporter Patrick Gillett spoke with Turvey after his team’s loss. 

**How's your body feeling after 100 A-grade games?**

"Yeah, still feeling good. I’m doing alright—not too sore."

**How do you feel about reaching 100 top-grade games?**

"I’m happy to have reached the milestone, but I’m a bit disappointed about today’s result. Still, reaching 100 games is a good achievement."

**Can you walk us through your journey to 100 A-grade games?**

"I started playing here about ten years ago. Initially, I didn’t play that many games because I was involved in representative football as well, which took away from my club games. Honestly, I’m considering hanging up the boots soon, but it’s been a good journey at this club. They've supported me a lot, and it’s a great group of guys to be around. Just disappointed with today’s game, though."

**You mentioned you might retire soon. Are you thinking about the end of this season or next?**

"Who knows? I was happy just to play a few games with the reserves this year, but I got pulled back up to the firsts. We’ve got a solid crew this year, but we didn’t show up in the first 20 minutes, which cost us 30 points. It’s tough to catch up in rugby after that."

**You had a decent start in the first half; were you happy with that?**

"Definitely! If we could maintain that level of performance for the full 80 minutes, we would have been in a good position. Sadly, the game lasts for 80 minutes."

**What’s next for you guys?**

"I’m not sure. I don’t really keep track of the schedule. I just show up for training and give my best."

**So you just follow the coaches' directions?**

"Exactly, I just show up where I’m needed."

**Do you have any special preparations, or is it the same routine?**

"I work quite a bit, so not much extra prep for me. You can probably tell by my physique! [Laughs]"

**I’ve seen worse!**

"Yeah, thanks!"

title: Australia: Victorian lockdown lifted
content:
At 11:59 PM on Tuesday, the Australian state of Victoria lifted its stay-at-home orders, including a five-kilometre (3.1-mile) travel limit, marking the end of a two-week lockdown.

Despite the easing of restrictions, masks will still be required in public spaces, and gatherings at private residences will remain limited. Individuals looking to book accommodation may only do so with members of their household, intimate partners, or a designated "single bubble" person. Public gatherings of up to ten people will now be permitted, and weddings and funerals can be held with a maximum of 50 attendees. Schools are set to resume on-site learning starting Wednesday.

On Tuesday, Victoria reported ten new COVID-19 cases, prompting Premier Daniel Andrews to remind the public that "COVID-19 is still with us." In a press release, his office emphasized the importance of ongoing vigilance against the highly transmissible Delta variant, advocating for continued COVIDSafe practices, including frequent check-ins, mask-wearing, and vaccinations for those eligible as the state cautiously reopens.

Premier Andrews stated, "We are in no way triumphant or boastful," while highlighting that Victoria has successfully managed two Delta outbreaks—an achievement he believes few jurisdictions worldwide can claim. He urged residents to take pride in this progress while remaining vigilant. Chief Health Officer Brett Sutton echoed these sentiments, emphasizing that the state is "on the cusp" of controlling the outbreak but cautioned that it is not yet time to declare victory.

Additionally, new restrictions have been imposed on cross-border travel, with specific local government areas in New South Wales being excluded from the travel bubble as of 11:59 PM Tuesday. Premier Andrews expressed regret over having to "lock out those four communities from Victoria," attributing the decision to the lack of stricter measures in Sydney and leaving open the possibility of further border changes.

title: Latrobe City, Australia records first COVID-19 case since January 12 with new Traralgon case
content:
**Victoria Records First COVID-19 Case in Over Seven Months**

Victoria, Australia, reported its first COVID-19 case in more than seven months on Sunday, linked to an outbreak in Melbourne. The case involves an individual who traveled to a funeral in the city. Jeroen Weimar, the Victorian government's COVID-19 response commander, confirmed that no one in the individual's household is at risk of infection.

This new case represents Latrobe City's first active COVID-19 instance since January 12. On Sunday, the state saw a total of 92 community transmission cases. There are currently two COVID-19 testing sites in Latrobe City: one at The Healthcare Centre at 185-189 Princes Drive and another at Australian Clinical Labs on 10-12 Grey Street in Traralgon.

On the same day, a drive-through testing site at Dorevitch Pathology in Latrobe Regional Hospital began operations at 12 PM, and a pop-up testing site was established at the Gippsland Regional Indoor Sports Stadium, both located in Traralgon.

Latrobe City Mayor Sharon Gibson emphasized the need for increased government support for additional testing stations and vaccination supplies. In an email to Wikinews, she stated, "I would like to see support from the Government for further Testing Stations to be opened across our City and additional Vaccination doses made available. We are willing to work with the relevant agencies to ensure this can be rolled out ASAP."

Independent state MP Russell Northe echoed this sentiment, urging more testing options for Latrobe City residents. He noted that many locals had been turned away due to high demand on Sunday, leaving some feeling upset and anxious.

On Sunday, Traralgon also recorded two COVID-19 exposure sites: Coles supermarket, which was exposed on August 22 from 11:45 AM to 12:05 PM, and the food court, which was exposed on August 27 from 11:10 AM to 11:15 AM. Two additional exposures were reported: at the same food court on August 22 between 12:25 PM and 2:45 PM and at Woolworths on Seymour Street on August 23 between 5:20 PM and 5:45 PM. Anyone who has visited these sites is urged to get tested and self-isolate until they receive their results.

Mayor Gibson urged anyone who has been to these exposure sites or has symptoms to get tested. “Now it is especially important to follow public health advice,” she said, wishing a swift recovery for the individual who tested positive. 

Federal MP also reminded residents of the importance of adhering to public health guidelines, stating, “If you have symptoms, please get tested. Thanks to our frontline staff who are working hard to keep our community safe.” 

Northe expressed hope that local health authorities could manage the situation effectively to prevent it from escalating, drawing parallels to other communities such as Shepparton. He acknowledged that the revelation of a new case in the region had surprised many, given the absence of COVID-19 for months. “The news [on Sunday] is very concerning, but I thank local residents who have responded by seeking testing promptly.”

title: South Gippsland, Australia local council candidate Sue Plowright speaks with Wikinews about environment, education, and other local issues
content:
**Title:** Local Council Candidate Sue Plowright Discusses Environmental and Educational Issues in South Gippsland, Australia

Since June 2019, the residents of South Gippsland, located at the southernmost tip of Australia, have been without an elected local council. Following a state government inquiry that uncovered "high levels of tension" within the council, administrators were appointed by the Victorian government in July 2019 to manage the shire. A local council election is now scheduled to occur by mail from October 5-22, 2021.

In light of these developments, Wikinews spoke with Sue Plowright, an independent candidate contesting for the Coastal-Promontory Ward, which encompasses towns such as Toora and Foster. The Coastal-Promontory Ward is responsible for electing three councillors to the South Gippsland Shire Council.

**What are your objectives as a councillor?**

As a councillor, I aim to achieve four primary goals during the new council's term. First, I want to leverage my skills in ethical governance to establish a trustworthy and effective council that upholds democratic values and accountability. South Gippslanders deserve representation marked by integrity, resulting in improved governance practices that can attract diverse funding for community projects, such as initiatives promoting sustainable tourism and regenerative farming practices.

Secondly, I am committed to transforming the conversation around climate change into a source of excitement rather than division. Under the Local Government Act 2020, councils are legally obligated to address climate change, but I believe we must go further. For example, organisations like the Landcare have demonstrated success over the past two decades through local initiatives. I propose that the council supports a declaration of a climate emergency and develops a community-led action plan, backed by necessary resources in subsequent budgets.

My third focus is on promoting youth engagement by advocating for the creation of a full-time youth officer or coordinator within the council. This role would facilitate connections among young people and local services, generating more opportunities for our youth.

Lastly, I am collaborating with a group known as Mayday Projects to address the affordable housing crisis affecting many regional areas, including South Gippsland. I provide further details on these initiatives in response to other questions.

**Do you think the two years of administrative governance since the council's 2019 dissolution have been excessive? Why or why not?**

From my perspective as a newcomer to the council in 2016, it became evident by 2019 that significant changes were needed. Frequent council resignations meant that elected representatives no longer reflected the community's choices from the 2016 election, leading to a cycle of dysfunction. While I believe democratic elections should always be prioritized, the two-year hiatus has offered South Gippslanders an opportunity to rethink and rejuvenate our democratic processes. I support this cause by running for office and encouraging others to do the same.

**What strategies are necessary for local businesses to recover from the impact of COVID-19?**

Navigating the challenges posed by COVID-19 can be likened to a batsman facing a bowler. Some businesses have adapted and thrived, while others have struggled. As someone who embarked on my own educational consultancy in mid-2019, I can empathize with the struggle; the onset of COVID-19 effectively halted my prospects. Business recovery will require a multifaceted approach, tailored to the unique needs of individual businesses. Strategies could include mentoring programs, the revival of local traders' associations, and lobbying for targeted training opportunities.

**What changes do you advocate for regarding environmental protection?**

Environmental protection involves a balance between encouragement and regulation. I favor proactive strategies that support long-term initiatives in our natural landscape, while also acknowledging the need for enforceable regulations. One critical reform is to extend funding timelines for environmental projects, which often currently receive short-term support. A comprehensive government review of project funding that takes into account the long-term nature of environmental work is necessary, and an active council can facilitate this.

**What makes you qualified for the role of local councillor?**

My qualifications for councillor stem from three pillars: experience, expertise, and energy. With over 35 years in various leadership and educational roles—including service as a social planner in a Shire Council—I have the breadth of experience that informs my understanding of community needs. My PhD in democracy, governance, and education provides a strong foundation for navigating the complexities of local governance. I am passionate about community service, evident in my leadership roles and initiatives supporting youth and women's safety.

**Are there specific projects you wish to promote in your community?**

I want to prioritize two key initiatives. First, the establishment of a dedicated youth officer or coordinator role is crucial. Many young people are disproportionately affected by COVID-related lockdowns, and we need to quickly provide opportunities for social interaction and fun. 

Second, addressing the affordable housing crisis in South Gippsland is urgent. I support the council's proposals to the State Government’s Big Build initiative and am actively collaborating with Mayday Projects to implement targeted actions that address the needs of local families facing housing challenges.

**How have you engaged with local voters during the COVID-19 lockdown?**

I began my campaign right before the current lockdown, utilizing both in-person meet-ups and social media to connect with voters. Given the restrictions, I transitioned to virtual engagement via Zoom meet-and-greet sessions, as well as informal online gatherings to capture diverse community input. I've also made my contact information widely available to encourage direct communication.

**Have you previously run for political office?**

Yes, I have previously run for political office twice. In 2008, I contested the Sandridge Ward, and in 2010, I stood for a restructured seat in the same local council. Initially affiliated with a political party, I became an independent in 2012, driven by a conviction that democracy should center on community voices rather than party loyalties. I remain committed to working collaboratively with the community, other councillors, and government agencies to represent the interests of South Gippsland effectively.

title: At least six injured after stabbing in New Zealand supermarket
content:
At least six people have been injured, including three who are now in critical condition, following a stabbing incident on Friday in New Zealand. Prime Minister Jacinda Ardern has described the attack as a "terrorist act against innocent New Zealanders," carried out by "a violent extremist."

The stabbing took place in the Auckland suburb of Lynmall, within the local shopping center. Police responded quickly, fatally shooting the assailant less than a minute after the attack began. Among the six reported injuries, three victims are in critical condition, one is seriously injured, and two others are in moderate condition.

The assailant, a Sri Lankan national who had lived in New Zealand since October 2011, had been a person of interest for national security agencies since 2016. Prime Minister Ardern noted that the attacker was inspired by the Islamic State, but emphasized that "it would be wrong to redirect any frustration to anyone beyond this individual. He is solely to blame, and no one else."

Ardern also revealed that she had prior knowledge of the man, although the specifics regarding his history with authorities remain confidential due to court orders. She confirmed that he had been under permanent police surveillance, stating, "We have utilized every legal and surveillance power available to us to try and keep people safe from this individual."

In response to the incident, Countdown stores in New Zealand opened later than usual yesterday, at 10 AM. The company's general manager of safety expressed deep sorrow over the violent act at the Lynmall store, saying, "Our hearts are heavy knowing what our team and customers have witnessed and experienced. Our thoughts are with those who were injured and their families, and we will be providing support to our Lynnmall team in particular."

title: Australia: Mat Morgan, Greens candidate in South Gippsland, talks climate, tourism, and local issues with Wikinews
content:
**Australia: Mat Morgan, Greens Candidate for South Gippsland, Discusses Climate, Tourism, and Local Issues with Wikinews**

Since June 2019, the community at the southernmost tip of Australia, South Gippsland, has been without a local council following a state government inquiry that identified "high levels of tension" within the council. Since July 2019, administrators appointed by the Victorian government have overseen the shire. However, a democratic council election is set to take place via postal ballot from October 5 to 22, 2021.

Wikinews spoke with Mat Morgan, a candidate for the Coastal-Promontory Ward, who is endorsed by the Greens. The ward encompasses towns such as Foster, Leongatha, and Mirboo North, and is responsible for electing three councillors to the South Gippsland Shire Council.

**What are your goals if elected as a councillor?**

As a councillor, my primary goals will be: 
1) Declare a climate emergency and implement a community-led climate action plan to combat climate change, reduce emissions, and invest in renewable energy sources.
2) Provide quality services that prioritize the health and wellbeing of our community while supporting small businesses, local arts, and tourism.
3) Safeguard our natural environment.
4) Combat gendered violence and all forms of discrimination, promoting respect and equality for everyone.

**Do you believe the two-year period of governance by administrators has been excessive, and why?**

The two-year absence of a democratically elected council has certainly presented challenges, particularly following the issues with the previous council. I believe South Gippsland is ready for a renewed governance structure with fresh perspectives.

**With many tourists attracted to the Coastal-Promontory area, what measures should be taken for business recovery post-COVID-19?**

Tourism businesses have been hit hard during the pandemic. To facilitate recovery, we must enhance our offerings when we reopen, including more camping sites and diverse activities to encourage visitors to explore our beautiful region. Revitalizing local music scenes, promoting our remarkable food and wine, and protecting our environment from ecological decline are essential steps.

**What environmental reforms do you envision?**

I advocate for a climate emergency declaration, accompanied by an actionable plan tailored to South Gippsland's needs. A successful model has been established in Bass Coast, and local climate action groups like the Prom Area Climate Action team are eager for genuine leadership to implement change. I am committed to providing that leadership.

**What qualifications make you a suitable candidate for local council?**

Local councils should reflect the diversity of their communities. I bring a fresh perspective, as I believe younger generations have been underrepresented at this level of governance. With my background in politics and philosophy, along with my commitment to the community, I aim to represent the interests of my ward rather than catering to entrenched vested interests.

**Are there specific community projects you wish to promote?**

There are numerous commendable initiatives underway, such as the community composter and the 24/7 library in Foster. I would advocate for increased accessibility, including more footpaths and bike trails, sealing roads like Mt Best Road, and creating wildlife corridors to reduce animal presence near highways.

**How have you engaged with local voters during the COVID-19 lockdown?**

I've been fortunate to work as a barista in Foster, allowing me to remain connected with the community throughout the lockdown. I regularly hear what residents hope for from their future council representatives. For those who prefer online engagement, I update my Facebook page daily at @MatMorganGreens.

**Why did you choose to run as a Greens candidate for local council?**

I support the Greens' policies and am grateful for their endorsement, which helps fund and promote my campaign. Transparency is vital to me, so I openly share my affiliation, unlike some candidates who may not disclose their party backing. I aim to bring transparency to our council's operations.

title: Australia: Wikinews interviews Les Harmer, South Gippsland local election candidate
content:
**Australia: Wikinews Interviews Les Harmer, Local Election Candidate for South Gippsland**

Nominations for the upcoming council elections in South Gippsland were announced on September 21. Voting will take place by mail from October 5 to 22. A total of 24 candidates have come forward to contest the elections across the council's three wards. Since August 2019, the shire has been under the governance of administrators appointed by the Victorian state government, following the council's dismissal due to a state inquiry revealing "high levels of tension" within the council.

Wikinews conducted an email interview with Les Harmer, one of the candidates in the Tarwin Valley ward, which elects three councillors to the South Gippsland Shire Council. This ward includes the towns of Tarwin Lower and Venus Bay.

**What do you hope to achieve as a councillor?**  
I aim to improve communication between the community and the council.

**Do you think the two-year period of administrative governance since the council's dismissal in 2019 has been too long? Why or why not?**  
No, it was necessary for things to settle down after the turmoil. I believe the Administrators have laid a stable foundation for new councillors to lead the council into the future.

**South Gippsland hasn't had a passenger railway service since the closure of the line to Leongatha in 1993. Do you believe these services should be reinstated? Why or why not?**  
Only if they are economically viable. We must be prudent with public resources; the days of accepting unprofitable ventures are behind us.

**What changes or reforms would you like to see regarding environmental protection?**  
The challenge lies in balancing aspirations with what can be achieved as a councillor. My personal goal is to advocate for more emphasis on renewable energy in long-term planning.

**What qualifies you to be a local councillor?**  
I possess a deep empathy for the local community and have management qualifications.

**Are there any specific projects in your local community that you would like to highlight or advocate for?**  
I believe we should work towards becoming an official tourist-friendly town, which would significantly benefit local businesses.

**How did you engage with local voters during the COVID-19 lockdown?**  
I maintained contact through emails, newspaper articles, and coffee meetings when permitted, ensuring ongoing connection with local groups I'm involved with.

**Have you previously run for political office before your current candidacy?**  
Yes, I ran for local council several years ago but was unsuccessful.

title: Rosemary Cousin, Greens candidate in South Gippsland, Australia, speaks to Wikinews about democracy, transport, forests and other local issues
content:
