title: Wikinews attends 2021 Texas Haunters Convention
content:
**Wikinews Reports on the 2021 Texas Haunters Convention**

Wikinews was present at this year's Texas Haunters Convention, which took place in Mesquite over the weekend.

The three-day event kicked off on Friday and showcased a diverse range of vendors, performers, and makeup artists, alongside many other specialists in the haunted attractions industry. Held at the Mesquite Convention Center, the convention attracted over 2,500 attendees, all eager to engage in Halloween-themed discussions and activities.

One of the notable classes focused on "Sliding," an acrobatic performance commonly featured in haunted attractions. The instructor demonstrated the use of modified boots, knee pads, and specially designed gloves equipped with various metal pieces and rods to create stunning sparking effects during performances.

In addition to practical demonstrations, speakers covered a variety of technical topics relevant to haunted attractions, including lighting design. Another presentation addressed the financial side of operating a haunted attraction, highlighting that such events in the U.S. collectively generate between $300 million and $500 million in ticket sales annually.

title: South Korean health authorities confirm first vaccination death
content:
South Korean health authorities confirmed on Monday the country's first official death linked to a COVID-19 vaccine. The deceased, a man in his thirties, passed away last Wednesday after being diagnosed with thrombosis with thrombocytopenia syndrome (TTS), a rare side effect associated with the vaccine.

The man, who received his vaccination in late May, began experiencing severe headaches and nausea nine days after his inoculation. During a press conference, health commissioner Jeong Eun-kyeong stated that investigations are underway into 224 reported deaths following vaccinations. Of these cases, 210 were found not to be related to the vaccine, while 13 are still under investigation.

Jeong urged individuals who have received any COVID-19 vaccine dose to be vigilant for symptoms of TTS, which may include headaches, blurred vision, vomiting, shortness of breath, and abdominal pain.

Currently, South Korea administers the Oxford-AstraZeneca and Pfizer COVID-19 vaccines, though the AstraZeneca vaccine is restricted to individuals over the age of 30 due to concerns regarding TTS. As of now, 7.9% of the population is fully vaccinated against COVID-19, and 29.2% have received at least one dose.

title: Australia: University claim 2021 Sunshine Coast Rugby Union A grade premiership
content:
The University team has claimed the 2021 Sunshine Coast Rugby Union A Grade premiership, narrowly defeating Noosa 10-6 at Australia’s stadium on Saturday.

Noosa took an early lead with a penalty goal from Jordan Mayhew just fifteen minutes into the match. University responded ten minutes later with a penalty from Matt Lieder. With fourteen minutes remaining, the home team scored the only try of the game, courtesy of their number nine, Jona Wesiniciba. Lieder successfully converted the try, extending the lead to seven points. Mayhew added a late penalty goal to bring Noosa within four points.

In the final moments of the match, Noosa pressured the University defense, closing in on the try line.

"I’ve lost so many games in that situation," said University coach Brad Tronc. "I just knew these boys would dig deep. I could see their body language, they were scrambling hard. Our bench made a difference; we operated as a 23-man squad rather than just relying on our starting 15. None of our reserves played before this match like they did, but our entire squad earned this win."

When asked about the influence of the home crowd, Tronc remarked, "That support made it feel like we had a hundred-man squad out there. It’s what it’s all about. The home advantage really got us through in the end."

title: Police reports indicate theft of automotive catalytic converters up across parts of US
content:
Recent media reports reveal that police across several regions in the United States are warning of a spike in automobile thefts, particularly targeting catalytic converters. Authorities in a Texas city reported skyrocketing theft rates, showing an alarming 312% increase as of last Friday. Catalytic converters are sought after for the valuable precious metals they contain, which play a crucial role in reducing harmful vehicle emissions.

The market value of one of these metals, rhodium, has surged over the past few months, with reports indicating that one troy ounce (approximately 31 grams) is currently worth between $23,000 and $27,000. Additionally, converters include other precious metals such as platinum and palladium, which further enhance their value. In Washington state alone, police have recorded 45 reported incidents of stolen catalytic converters this year.

To combat these thefts, law enforcement officials advise citizens to park their vehicles in garages or well-lit areas. They also recommend installing security cameras around parking locations. As an added precaution, attaching a sheet metal cover over the catalytic converter may help deter potential thieves.

title: 2020 Olympics opening ceremony takes place in Tokyo
content:
The opening ceremony of the 2020 Summer Olympics was held today at Tokyo's National Stadium in Japan. Japanese tennis player Naomi Osaka, 23, had the honor of lighting the Olympic flame. With a seating capacity of 68,000, only media representatives and 900 dignitaries were present in person due to ongoing pandemic restrictions. Originally scheduled for 2020, the games were postponed by one year because of the COVID-19 pandemic.

Athletes and healthcare workers carried the Japanese flag into the stadium, followed by a moment of silence to honor the victims of the pandemic and remember Olympic athletes who have passed away, including the Israeli athletes from the 1972 Munich Games. The Olympic cauldron, designed to resemble the sun, opened like a flower, symbolizing "vitality and hope." This was complemented by a stunning aerial display featuring a revolving globe made up of 1,824 drones, which was followed by a performance of John Lennon and Yoko Ono's "Imagine" by artists Angélique Kidjo and John Legend.

International Olympic Committee President Thomas Bach expressed, "Today is a moment of hope. Yes, it is very different from what all of us had imagined. But let us cherish this moment because finally we are all here together." Tokyo 2020 President Seiko Hashimoto added, "Here is a vision for the future, one that embodies 'unity in diversity,' one of peace and respect for one another."

Despite the festive atmosphere inside the stadium, there were protests outside expressing opposition to the Olympics taking place amid the pandemic. A recent poll conducted in Japan indicated that 32.1% of respondents believed the Olympics should be cancelled, with 87% expressing concerns about hosting the event during this crisis.

title: South Australia enters week-long lockdown to contain COVID-19 Delta variant spread
content:
South Australia has entered a one-week lockdown starting Monday, following the emergence of five active cases of the Delta variant of COVID-19. In announcing the lockdown, state officials emphasized that "we have no alternative but to impose some fairly heavy and immediate restrictions."

The first active case was reported on Sunday evening, involving an individual who returned from Argentina earlier this month. The fifth case, described by Premier Steven Marshall as "far more worrying," was linked to The Greek on Halifax restaurant, where this person dined at the same time as someone later confirmed to have the virus. Chief Public Health Officer Nicola Spurrier urged anyone who visited The Greek on Halifax to immediately quarantine and get tested.

Under the new regulations, residents are permitted to leave home only for five specific reasons: essential work, grocery shopping for necessary items, exercise with members of the same household within a limited distance of home, medical reasons (including COVID-19 testing and vaccinations but excluding elective and cosmetic surgeries), and caregiving.

Schools will be closed to all students except for the children of essential workers, with online learning commencing on Thursday. Additionally, face masks are now mandated for anyone leaving home. According to ABC News, further support for businesses is expected to be announced, as all non-essential retail will be required to close under the new guidelines.

title: Bomb techs erred in South Los Angeles explosion, says city police department chief
content:
**LAPD Bomb Squad Under Scrutiny After Fireworks Explosion Injures 17**

In a press conference held on Monday, Los Angeles Police Department (LAPD) Chief Michel Moore revealed that the department's preliminary investigation into a catastrophic fireworks disposal incident on June 30 identified the mishap as a result of an excessive amount of explosives placed in an explosives disposal vehicle. The explosion occurred on East 27th Street in South Los Angeles, injuring 17 individuals and damaging various vehicles and properties.

In response to the incident, five members of the LAPD’s bomb squad have been reassigned from their duties, according to Chief Moore.

The incident began when LAPD officers discovered over 32,000 pounds (approximately 14,500 kg) of illegal fireworks at a South Los Angeles residence. Bomb disposal technicians reportedly placed around 16.5 pounds (7.5 kg) of explosives into a "total containment vessel" (TCV) for detonation. However, the Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) later confirmed that technicians actually detonated 42 pounds (19 kg) of explosives. The containment vehicle failed to properly contain the explosion, resulting in injuries to 17 people and damage to 13 nearby businesses, 22 residences, and 37 vehicles.

The TCV's recommended capacity is 15 pounds (6.8 kg) for repeated use and 25 pounds (11 kg) for a single use, according to Chief Moore. The truck had been in service for a decade, marking its 42nd use during the June 30 incident.

The ATF has launched an investigation into the actions of the LAPD. They anticipate concluding their findings in the next one to two months.

Arturo Ceja III, the 26-year-old homeowner where the fireworks were discovered, was arrested by LAPD on suspicion of unlawful possession of destructive devices and child endangerment. Possession of fireworks is illegal within the City of Los Angeles and surrounding unincorporated areas. Ceja was released after posting bail set at $500,000 and is scheduled to return to state court in October.

Federal prosecutors have charged Ceja III with the illegal transportation of explosives without a license, alleging that he purchased the fireworks from Area 51, a dealer located in Nevada near the California border. He was released on a $25,000 bond pending arraignment, which is scheduled for August 2.

L.A. Councilmember Curren Price expressed outrage over the LAPD's handling of the situation, stating, "It’s clear there was negligence involved and this instance shows zero regard for the people that reside in our South LA community. Every individual that I have talked to, including myself, wonders if this would have been acceptable protocol in more affluent areas of the City."

In response to the incident, the city has opened a resource center for affected residents located on East 28th Street. Here, residents can file claims against the city and access mental health resources.

On Tuesday, L.A. City Attorney Hydee Felan reported that her office has received 56 claims related to the explosion. "We're trying to speed this up as much as we can [...] this is an all-hands-on-deck effort to ensure that anyone who suffered due to that explosion gets relief as quickly as possible, because they deserve it," she stated.

During a Tuesday meeting, callers urged the police department to provide reparations to affected residents and businesses. Chief Moore informed the commission that over 200 applications for claims seeking assistance had been submitted.

title: Australia: Wikinews interviews Reg Kidd, mayor of the City of Orange, about COVID-19 lockdown and local government
content:
**Australia: Wikinews Interviews Reg Kidd, Mayor of Orange, on COVID-19 Lockdown and Local Government**

Following a week-long lockdown imposed in three rural councils in New South Wales, Australia, Wikinews spoke with Reg Kidd, the Mayor of Orange, one of the areas currently affected after a COVID-19 case was confirmed at a local food factory.

As a result of the lockdown, Orange City Council, along with the other impacted areas, has been designated a COVID-19 hotspot. This status allows the councils to access various forms of support from the government, including the COVID-19 disaster payment, help with contact tracing, and personal protective equipment from the National Medical Stockpile.

Reg Kidd has been an Orange City Councillor for 28 years and became the city’s first popularly elected mayor in 2017 while running as an independent candidate. He has hosted talkback radio since 1989. In an email exchange with Wikinews, Kidd discussed the COVID-19 lockdown measures, the upcoming local government elections in New South Wales, and his motivations for a career in local government.

**Q: Do you think the New South Wales government has taken the right approach in managing the COVID-19 pandemic?**  
A: Yes, a lot of people like to play the "blame game," which often creates more issues! There have been only about 60 deaths in NSW since the onset of COVID-19. When you calculate that as a percentage of the population, it’s relatively low. More people have died from road accidents, heart attacks, and drugs.

**Q: How has the lockdown impacted the council's activities and meetings?**  
A: No, we have been live-streaming community meetings for some time now, and we conduct Zoom meetings, which have been very successful.

**Q: What motivated you to enter local politics?**  
A: I decided to enter local politics to give back to a community that has supported me immensely. I believe in being proactive and striving to be part of the solution rather than the problem.

**Q: Given the impacts of COVID-19 in New South Wales, do you think any changes should be made to how the upcoming local government elections (scheduled for September 4) are conducted?**  
A: Yes, they should be postponed until at least March next year. This change can be done without needing full parliamentary debate. Due to the shutdowns, traditional electioneering has become very challenging. We also have more pressing issues to address right now, particularly COVID-19 and vaccination efforts.

**Q: Is there a message you would like to send to local residents amid the COVID-19 lockdown?**  
A: Yes—let's work together and avoid the blame game. It’s essential to listen to proper expert advice, get tested, and make sure to get vaccinated. Please don’t fall for misinformation or media hype about the AstraZeneca vaccine. My family and I are finished with this struggle, and many expert medical professionals in Orange are frustrated by how some media outlets seem more invested in political narratives rather than real solutions.

title: According to recent study, deaths in India number roughly 4 million during COVID-19 pandemic
content:
In a recent study, researchers based in the United States estimate that excess deaths in India during the COVID-19 pandemic range between 3.4 million and 5 million from May 2020 to June 21, 2021. 

The calculations were derived from death certificates across seven states, combined with international age-specific infection rate estimates and antibody test data, as well as a consumer survey tracking reported deaths. While not all identified excess deaths can be directly attributed to COVID-19, this metric serves to gauge the pandemic's overall impact. 

The study authors indicated that the actual death toll "is likely to be far greater than the official count" and could "number in the millions." According to co-author Vikram Subramanian, the perception that India had avoided the worst after the first wave, which exhibited a more gradual increase in cases, fostered a culture of complacency due to underreported deaths. He noted that the second wave, marked by distressing imagery and experiences, prompted society to seek a clearer understanding of the death toll. Subramanian also pointed out that their figures only include data up to May and do not capture the entirety of June or any of July, suggesting that the true death toll may still be underestimated.

Official records indicate that India has reported over 414,000 COVID-19 deaths, ranking third-highest globally. However, there has been no formal record of excess deaths during the pandemic.

title: Algerian judoka suspended from Olympics for refusing to face Israeli
content:
Today, an athlete representing Algeria at the Tokyo 2020 Summer Olympics was suspended for refusing to compete against an Israeli opponent. Judoka Fethi Nourine cited his support for Palestine as the reason for his decision. Nourine was set to compete in the under-73 kg category and had also declined to face an Israeli competitor in a prior event held in Tokyo.

In a media statement, Nourine expressed, "We worked hard to reach the Olympics. But the Palestinian cause is bigger than all of this." His coach supported his decision, stating, "We made the right decision." This is not the first instance of athletes refusing to compete against Israeli opponents; countries such as Iran and Egypt have previously taken similar stands.

The International Judo Federation (IJF) subsequently revoked Nourine's accreditation and announced that he would be sent back home. In a statement regarding the withdrawal, the IJF emphasized its commitment to a strict non-discrimination policy, which promotes solidarity as a core principle rooted in the values of judo. A disciplinary commission is currently reviewing the situation to determine any additional sanctions.

title: Heavy monsoon rains kill over 100 in India, many thousands evacuated
content:
Heavy monsoon rains in Maharashtra, western India, have resulted in at least 110 fatalities and the evacuation of nearly 90,000 residents. Between Thursday and Friday morning, the region received nearly 60 cm (23 inches) of rain in just 24 hours.

Tragically, 42 of the deaths occurred in the village of Taliye, near Mumbai, where a significant landslide destroyed numerous homes. Maharashtra’s Chief Minister is scheduled to visit the village on Saturday and has convened an emergency meeting to address the crisis, calling for assistance for those affected.

In Mumbai, at least two people lost their lives and ten others were injured when a residential building collapsed due to the heavy rainfall. The death toll in the city has surpassed 30, including fatalities from landslides and electrocution. More heavy rains are anticipated, prompting the assistance of the Indian military and rescue teams as the toll continues to rise.

Additionally, in Goa, over 1,000 houses have sustained severe damage; however, no deaths have been reported in the state so far.

title: China resumes deportation of refugees back to North Korea
content:
In a recent article by Human Rights Watch, it was reported that over 1,100 North Koreans residing in China are at risk of being forcibly repatriated. The report highlights that around 50 defectors were recently returned to North Korea after being arrested by Chinese authorities.

An anonymous witness informed that “the Dandong customs office was opened specifically for today, and about 50 North Korean escapees were sent back to their home country on two buses.” The witness also noted that “dozens of police officers were stationed outside the customs office to prevent public access and ensure that no one was filming the process.”

Following the outbreak of COVID-19, North Korea completely closed its borders, which halted the repatriation of defectors. This recent repatriation marked the first since January 2020, when North Korean authorities closed the borders to safeguard the nation from the pandemic. Prior to this, such repatriation actions were commonplace for defectors who had crossed the Tumen and Yalu rivers into China.

The situation has drawn concern from the U.S., with a spokesperson stating that "we are particularly troubled by reports of nearly 50 North Koreans being forcibly repatriated." The spokesperson urged China to "fulfill its international obligations as a signatory to the 1951 Refugee Convention and its 1967 Protocol, as well as the UN Convention Against Torture."

Radio Free Asia reported that among the 50 repatriated individuals were former soldiers and pilots who had served in the North Korean military. Sending these individuals back to North Korea, where they may face imprisonment and torture, constitutes a violation of the United Nations' 1951 Refugee Convention, the 1967 Protocol, and the UN Convention Against Torture. Human Rights Watch's article indicated that approximately 1,170 North Koreans are currently held in various prisons across China's Jilin and Liaoning provinces, facing deportation after being charged with criminal offenses.

Despite the serious implications of this situation, China and North Korea maintain a friendly relationship; leaders from both nations exchanged greetings on July 11, as reported by state media. A bilateral border protocol signed in 1986 mandates the deportation of all defectors and other North Koreans illegally residing in China.

According to data from South Korea's Ministry of Unification, only two North Korean defectors reached South Korea between April and June of this year—the lowest number recorded since the ministry began tracking defector inflows. This decline in defector numbers is largely attributed to North Korea's strict border closures in response to the pandemic, which have effectively halted any movement in and out of the country, all while the regime continues to assert that it has no COVID-19 cases.

North Korean defectors typically transit through China on their way to South Korea or other safe countries, as crossing the Sino-Korean border is often easier than traversing the heavily fortified Korean Demilitarized Zone (DMZ). The nearest defector-friendly country accessible by land is Vietnam.

title: Floods in central China kill 25
content:
Severe flooding in a province in central China has resulted in at least 25 fatalities, with around 200,000 individuals evacuated as of Wednesday, as military personnel spearhead rescue operations. The floods triggered landslides, and the provincial capital was heavily inundated, affecting major thoroughfares.

Videos shared by passengers on the Zhengzhou Metro depicted water levels reaching neck height as they clung to handrails. At least twelve fatalities were reported from the metro system, alongside five injuries, with over 500 people rescued.

Additionally, four individuals lost their lives due to collapsing buildings and walls, prompting more than 20,000 residents to flee their homes. The flooding also devastated approximately 9,000 hectares of crops, leading to an estimated $11.3 million in damages.

The region has experienced persistent storms and heavy rain since July 17. Reports indicate that a staggering 622.7 mm (24.51 in) of rain fell within just 24 hours, significantly exceeding the 250 mm (9.84 in) threshold deemed extremely heavy. Between Saturday and Tuesday, Zhengzhou saw 617.1 mm (25.30 in) of rainfall, nearly matching its annual average of 640.8 mm (25.23 in).

Several factors have contributed to this deluge. Firstly, a weather system approaching southeastern China has been pushing substantial amounts of water vapor inland. Secondly, geographical features in the region are causing water vapor to converge and rise, intensifying the precipitation.

According to Zhang Ning, chief weather broadcaster for the Henan Meteorological Service, heavy rainfall is expected to continue through Wednesday night. However, from July 22 to July 26, only scattered thunderstorms are forecasted, with no significant precipitation anticipated.

title: Evergrande real estate firm makes missed September bond payment, avoids default
content:
China's property giant wired $83.5 million in interest owed on an offshore bond originally due on September 23, effectively averting default for the time being, as reported by Reuters and a Chinese newspaper. 

The transfer, made to a fiduciary account following a 30-day grace period, was facilitated after assurances from various Chinese government officials. During a forum in Beijing on Wednesday, Chinese Vice Premier Liu He described the financial risks as controllable. The chairman of the China Banking and Insurance Regulatory Commission (CBIRC) acknowledged the need to manage excessive debt while ensuring that the situation would be handled appropriately.

Once considered China's top real estate developer, Evergrande has accumulated about $305 billion in liabilities, equivalent to approximately 2% of the country's gross national product. The company's value has plummeted by 80%, attributed in part to dwindling resources. September data indicates that home sales in China by value dropped nearly 17% year-on-year, raising concerns that Evergrande's financial turmoil is contributing to a slowdown in China's GDP growth, which fell to a year-low of 4.9% in the third quarter. Two crucial negotiations for property sales, valued at $2.6 billion and $1.7 billion with rival developers China Vanke and Yuexiu, were reportedly suspended due to the lack of approval from the Guangdong provincial government overseeing Evergrande's restructuring.

News of Evergrande's wire transfer led to a surge in its shares, which rose by as much as 7.8% this morning after a two-week trading halt related to the anticipated sale of a 50.1% stake in Evergrande Property Services Group, offering some relief to bondholders. James Wong, portfolio manager at GaoTeng Global Asset Management, called the update "a positive surprise", suggesting, "If Evergrande pays this time, I don't see why it won't pay the next time." Jun Rong Yeap, commenting for Asia, stated that the report "overturned" the expectation that Evergrande would struggle to secure cash.

Additional missed payments are forthcoming on October 29 and November 11, following similar grace periods; when including yesterday's $83.5 million payment, nearly $280 million is owed to bondholders.

Stocks for many leading Chinese developers have plummeted: Reuters reported that Sinic Holdings has seen its stock price drop by 87.8% year-to-date and is currently classified as being in "restricted default" following a missed bond payment of $246 million due on October 18. Evergrande’s stock has fallen by 80.2%, while E-House, Kaisa Group, and others have also experienced significant declines in stock prices.

Estimates suggest that the real estate market in China comprises between 16% and 25% of the country's GDP. President Xi Jinping's strategy aims to transition the economy from debt-fueled growth to one focused on quality and sustainability. As part of this strategy, regulations were instituted to limit developers' borrowing capacity. A recent opinion piece by economist George Magnus highlighted concerns over China's "wild credit creation," which has contributed to high vacancy rates and the "financialization of housing."

title: Rust movie set accident leaves one person dead
content:
**Rust Movie Set Accident Results in One Fatality**

A tragic accident occurred on the set of the film *Rust* on Thursday, resulting in the death of cinematographer Halyna Hutchins and injuries to director Joel Souza.

The incident took place during the filming of a scene involving actor Alec Baldwin, who discharged a prop firearm. An insider report has indicated that a message circulated among crew members stated that the prop was believed to be safe.

Baldwin is currently cooperating with the investigation and has expressed his condolences to Hutchins' family. The sheriff's office in Santa Fe, New Mexico, is looking into "what type of projectile was discharged" and the circumstances of the incident. As of now, no charges have been filed. Souza was released from the hospital on Friday.

According to a sworn affidavit from investigators, Baldwin was given the prop and was informed by the assistant director that it was safe to use. Neither party was aware that the firearm was loaded.

title: Australia: Magnitude 5.9 earthquake detected in north-east Victoria
content:
An earthquake of magnitude 5.9 struck the Australian town of Mansfield in north-east Victoria on Wednesday at 9:15 am local time, with a depth reported by Geoscience Australia. About 15 minutes later, an aftershock measuring 4.0 occurred near the same area. Authorities noted that this earthquake is one of the largest recorded in eastern Australia since colonization.

The quake was widely felt across the country, with more than 15,000 people reporting their experiences on the Geoscience Australia website. ABC News indicated that tremors were felt in Victoria, New South Wales (NSW), South Australia, Tasmania, and the Australian capital, Canberra. In Melbourne's inner suburbs, some apartment buildings were evacuated, and social media reported instances of damage to buildings and roads. Local officials confirmed there was no tsunami risk.

Emergency services were deployed across NSW, from various centers in Sydney to locations as far as western NSW, in response to reports of tremors. Fortunately, no major structural damage was reported in the state.

Karen McGregor, an employee at a Mansfield store, described her harrowing experience: "The windows started shaking, the walls, and everything on the desk. It was really quite scary. We ran downstairs to the shop, and it felt terrifying down there. The windows were buckling. I just thought, 'Oh my God, is this place going to fall down?'" She mentioned that she had not heard of any injuries in the town.

From Washington, D.C., Australian Prime Minister Scott Morrison remarked that such earthquakes can be deeply unsettling since they are rare events in Australia. He confirmed he was in contact with Victorian Premier Daniel Andrews and assured that the federal government stood ready to assist Victorians as needed, potentially deploying disaster response teams.

Initially reported as a magnitude 6.0 quake, Geoscience Australia later revised it to 5.9 based on additional analysis. Adam Pascale, head of the Seismology Research Centre, suggested it might be around magnitude 5.8 and described the significant shaking felt in the northern suburbs of Melbourne that lasted about 15 to 20 seconds.

As for aftershocks, Pascale noted the likelihood of continued seismic activity, emphasizing that larger earthquakes typically generate both primary and secondary waves. Geoscientist Mark Quigley added that for an earthquake of this magnitude, it is reasonable to expect hundreds of smaller aftershocks, potentially reaching magnitudes of around 4.5.

title: Weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz wins the Philippines' first-ever Olympic gold medal
content:
On Monday, Filipina weightlifter Hidilyn Diaz secured the gold medal in the women’s 55 kg weightlifting category at the Tokyo Olympics, marking her fourth appearance at the Games. Diaz lifted a total of 224 kg (494 lb), tying the new Olympic record. She achieved this with a lift of 97 kg (214 lb) in the snatch and 127 kg (280 lb) in the clean and jerk.

Reflecting on her achievement, Diaz said in an interview, "I am 30 years old and I thought my performance would decline, but I was shocked I was able to do it." A statement from Harry Roque, the presidential spokesman of the Philippines, celebrated her victory, stating, "Congratulations, Hidilyn. The entire Filipino nation is proud of you."

China's Liao Qiuyun, the previous record-holder, claimed the silver medal with a total lift of 223 kg (492 lb), while Kazakhstan's Zulfiya Chinshanlo took home the bronze with a total of 213 kg (470 lb).

Diaz previously won the silver medal in the 53 kg category at the 2016 Olympic Games in Rio de Janeiro, Brazil, and earned a gold medal at the 2019 World Weightlifting Championships. Training in Malaysia during the pandemic, she faced COVID-19 travel restrictions that limited her return to the Philippines. Despite these challenges, she constructed a makeshift gym and trained using water bottles to prepare for the Olympics.

title: Philippine Armed Forces chief tests positive for COVID-19 in antigen test
content:
Lieutenant General Jose Faustino Jr., Chief of Staff of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP), has tested positive for COVID-19, as announced by AFP spokesperson Colonel Ramon Zagala during a press conference on Monday. The results from a confirmatory test are anticipated later the same day.

Colonel Zagala reported that the AFP chief is currently in good condition and has been placed in isolation in his quarters for safety reasons. Close contacts of Faustino have been informed of the situation and are also self-isolating.

Originally scheduled to address the press at 9 AM (PHT) on Monday, the meeting was canceled following the notification of the antigen test results.

Faustino took over as AFP chief on July 31, succeeding the retired General Cirilito Sobejana, who stepped down the same day. Prior to this role, Faustino served as the commander of the AFP Joint Task Force Mindanao.

This is not the first instance of an AFP chief of staff testing positive for COVID-19; in March 2020, then-General Gilbert Gapay also contracted the virus while serving in the position. Faustino was vaccinated against COVID-19 in the same month.

title: Two US congressmen fly into Kabul; trip reportedly unauthorized
content:
Two U.S. congressmen made an unannounced visit to Kabul's airport on Tuesday, seeking to gather information on the ongoing withdrawal of U.S. forces from Afghanistan. The congressmen, Democratic Representative Seth Moulton of Massachusetts and Republican Representative Peter Meijer of Michigan, conducted their visit without prior coordination with diplomats or evacuation commanders, a move that reportedly angered White House and Defense Department officials.

A press secretary stated that the two congressmen "certainly took time away from what we had planned to do that day." Three officials familiar with the situation told the Associated Press that the sudden appearance of Moulton and Meijer was not well-received by those managing the evacuation efforts.

In a joint statement, Moulton and Meijer explained their decision to keep the visit secret, emphasizing they aimed to avoid disrupting operations on the ground. They stated their purpose was to gather information rather than draw attention to themselves.

U.S. House Speaker Nancy Pelosi also issued a statement on Tuesday, urging members not to travel to Afghanistan at this critical time. She highlighted the need for the U.S. military and diplomatic teams to maintain their focus on ensuring the safe and timely evacuation of at-risk individuals.

President Joe Biden reaffirmed on Tuesday that his administration's deadline of August 31 for the withdrawal would remain unchanged. Moulton and Meijer have advocated for extending this deadline, arguing that the late start to the evacuation makes it likely that not everyone will be evacuated by September 11, despite their best efforts.

On April 14, President Biden announced plans to withdraw U.S. troops from Afghanistan by September 11, effectively concluding America's two-decade-long involvement in the conflict.

title: United States Indo-Pacific Commander meets with Philippine senior officials for 70th anniversary of Mutual Defense Treaty
content:
Admiral John Aquilino, head of the United States Indo-Pacific Command (US-INDOPACOM), arrived in Manila on Monday to meet with senior Filipino military officials, as reported by AFP.

Among the attendees at the meeting were Secretary of National Defense Carlito Galvez and Inspector General Lieutenant General Franco Nemesio Gacal of the Armed Forces of the Philippines (AFP). This visit marks the 70th anniversary of the Mutual Defense Treaty (MDT) between the United States and the Philippines.

Admiral Aquilino emphasized the U.S. commitment to the military alliance, stating, "We remain prepared to fight alongside and defend each other using all of our capabilities to preserve the region's peace and stability." 

Lieutenant General Gacal echoed these sentiments, describing the treaty as "the birth of our defense alliance." He represented AFP Chief Lieutenant General Jose Faustino Jr., who could not attend due to testing positive for COVID-19 and is currently in self-isolation.

The Mutual Defense Treaty was signed on August 30, 1951. The agreement consists of eight articles, ensuring mutual support in the event of an attack on either country’s territory, armed forces, public vessels, or aircraft.

This marks Admiral Aquilino's first visit to the Philippines as commander of US-INDOPACOM. He previously visited in August 2018 in his capacity as the commander of the U.S. Navy's Pacific Fleet, according to Manila Bulletin.

title: Tunisia's president dismisses prime minister, suspends parliament
content:
On Sunday, Tunisian President Kais Saied dismissed the country's Prime Minister, Hichem Mechichi, and announced the suspension of parliament in response to widespread nationwide protests. These demonstrations were fueled by public dissatisfaction over the economy and the government's handling of the COVID-19 pandemic, with significant criticism aimed at the largest parliamentary party, Ennahdha.

Saied declared that he would assume control until a new prime minister is appointed, and confirmed that parliament would remain suspended for 30 days, during which parliamentary members’ immunity would be lifted. He invoked Article 80 of the 2014 Tunisian constitution, which allows for the assumption of executive power in circumstances deemed as posing "imminent danger to the institutions of the nation."

The Speaker of Parliament, Rached Ghannouchi, stated that Saied did not consult with him or Mechichi prior to making these decisions, as required by the constitution. Although the constitution provides for a special court to resolve such disputes, it has yet to be established.

In response to the violent protests that have erupted across Tunisia, Saied convened an emergency meeting and subsequently announced the dismissal of Mechichi and the suspension of parliament. In a televised address, he stated, "We have taken these decisions [...] until social peace returns to Tunisia and until we save the state," adding that any further violence would be met with an armed response from the country's military.

In the capital, police enforced roadblocks on Avenue Bourguiba, and security forces were stationed around the parliament building to prevent access. Clashes ensued in Tunis, where police used pepper spray against protesters who were throwing rocks in opposition to Mechichi.

Ghannouchi, a prominent member of the Ennahdha party, condemned the president's actions as "a coup against the revolution and the constitution," asserting, "We consider the institutions to still be standing and supporters of Ennahda and the Tunisian people will defend the revolution." He indicated that parliament would continue to function despite its suspension.

Reports indicate that Ghannouchi arrived at the parliament building early Monday morning but was barred from entry by military personnel. Other parties within parliament also denounced the dismissal as a coup. According to Al Jazeera, tensions between Saied and Mechichi have escalated over the past year amid a severe economic crisis and ongoing challenges posed by the COVID-19 pandemic, which has claimed over 18,000 lives in Tunisia, a country of 12 million people.

title: 'Each makes the other more difficult to recover from': University of Sussex professor L. Alan Winters speaks to Wikinews on trade, COVID-19, Brexit
content:
**Title: "Impact of Brexit and COVID-19 on UK Trade: An Interview with Professor L. Alan Winters from the University of Sussex"**

Earlier this month, Wikinews interviewed L. Alan Winters, a respected professor of economics at the University of Sussex, to discuss the implications of the United Kingdom's decision to leave the European Union (EU) and the ongoing negotiations surrounding trade. Winters has extensively researched both Brexit and its impacts, and he is also the founding director of the UK Trade Policy Observatory (UKTPO).

With a career spanning over 15 years that includes key roles at the World Bank and as an advisor to various international economic organizations, Winters has authored several significant reports, including "COVID-19 Will Reinforce the Brexit Shock" and "The Costs of Brexit." He was honored with the title "Companion of the Most Honourable Order of the Bath" (C.B.) in 2012.

During our conversation, Professor Winters reflected on recent developments in UK trade policy and the challenges posed by both Brexit and the COVID-19 pandemic.

**Wikinews:** You expressed in your December 2020 report that Brexit would significantly impact UK-EU trade. Do you believe the government made a mistake in their negotiations with the EU?

**L. Alan Winters:** I have always opposed Brexit and maintain that it was a poorly conceived economic move. While the government argues it has regains some sovereignty, the execution of that sovereignty has remained unclear, and overall, I believe the UK would have benefited more from a closer relationship with Europe that would have minimized trade costs.

**Wikinews:** You noted earlier that the pandemic would exacerbate the economic shock from Brexit. Is that still true a year later?

**L. Alan Winters:** We've secured a trade agreement with the EU, but the haste in concluding that agreement has resulted in less favorable terms. The intertwining of government debt, which likely increased due to Brexit impacts, complicates the financial landscape for the UK. Disentangling the effects of Brexit and COVID-19 remains a complex task, but it's clear both crises will hinder recovery.

**Wikinews:** You previously suggested the challenges of recovering lost export markets during Brexit, enhanced by the pandemic's effects. Can you elaborate on that?

**L. Alan Winters:** Export markets are difficult to regain once lost, and the interplay between Brexit and COVID-19 creates additional challenges for recovery. If trade conditions deteriorate, as we have witnessed, regaining those markets becomes even less likely.

**Wikinews:** Many advocates propose that the UK can replace its EU trade with new agreements with countries like Australia and Canada. How feasible is that approach?

**L. Alan Winters:** I find that perspective unrealistic. The EU comprises roughly half of the UK's trade, and no other market can replicate that. Integration with the EU took years and provided deep trade agreements. While new FTAs can help diversify trade, they will unlikely compensate for the losses incurred from Brexit.

**Wikinews:** Fishing rights posed a significant point of contention during Brexit negotiations. How do you assess the agreement reached?

**L. Alan Winters:** The deal provides limited additional quota and still binds the UK to EU regulations. This means that while the UK has gained some control, it must navigate complex rules to maintain access to the vital EU market. The realities of exports in the fishing industry further complicate the situation.

**Wikinews:** Regarding recent trade agreements and statistics that claim they will create significant opportunities, what's your view?

**L. Alan Winters:** Claims about "newfound sovereignty" and significant increases in trade volumes often overlook the fact that many of these agreements are mere rollovers of past arrangements with the EU. The predicted economic impact from them is minimal.

**Wikinews:** Looking ahead, what implications do you foresee for UK trade negotiations and relationships following Brexit?

**L. Alan Winters:** It is crucial for the UK to build a constructive relationship within the global trade framework, particularly through the World Trade Organization (WTO). The focus should be on repairing multilateral trade systems instead of merely pursuing individual trade agreements.

**Wikinews:** In summary, what are your final thoughts on the UK's trade policy and recovery?

**L. Alan Winters:** Trade policy should prioritize stability, realistic agreements, and strategic relationships, particularly with neighboring countries. The end goal should be to create a trade environment that supports long-term growth while also grounding any policies in thorough domestic discussions. It is essential that the government takes a more sustainable and thoughtful approach to trade moving forward.

This conversation highlights the intricate relationship between Brexit and COVID-19, shaping the future of the UK's trade landscape and economic recovery.

title: Houston Astros to face Atlanta Braves in 2021 World Series
content:
The Houston Astros and Atlanta Braves emerged victorious in their respective championships last weekend, setting the stage for their showdown in the 2021 Major League Baseball World Series. The first game will take place on Tuesday in Houston, Texas.

On Friday afternoon, the Astros defeated the 5-0 in Game 6 of the American League Championship Series, held in Houston, thus clinching the American League pennant. Meanwhile, on Saturday in Los Angeles, California, the Braves secured their spot in the World Series by defeating the  in Game 6 of the National League Championship Series, ending the series with a four games to two victory. Both league championship series were conducted in a best-of-seven format.

This marks the Astros' third American League pennant win and their fifth World Series appearance in the past six years. In contrast, this will be the Braves' first World Series appearance since 1999. The defending champions, the Los Angeles Dodgers, held the trophy last year.

Similar to the league series, the 117th World Series will also follow a best-of-seven format. The Astros will have home-field advantage for the first two games, while the next three games will take place in Atlanta, Georgia. Should the series extend beyond that, any subsequent games will return to Houston.

title: UK pay freeze on public sector employees will end next year
content:
On Monday, Chancellor of the Exchequer Rishi Sunak announced in a media briefing that he will formally end the partial pay freeze affecting 2.6 million public sector workers, a measure introduced last November. This announcement, expected to be confirmed in his budget at noon on Wednesday, will also include a pay raise of 6.6% for these employees.

Sunak previously cited the drop in wages during the COVID-19 pandemic as the reason for the pay freeze, which largely affected teachers, police officers, civil servants, and other public sector workers, while excluding 2.9 million NHS staff and those earning under £24,000 per year. While a general pay increase is planned for spring next year, specific details are still pending consultation with independent advisers and pay review bodies. The Guardian reports that approximately 5.7 million public sector employees could see a wage increase.

Additionally, around two million minimum wage earners, some of whom fall within the aforementioned 5.7 million, may benefit from upcoming increases to the national minimum and living wages. According to reports from iNews and The Guardian, the National Living Wage for those over 23 is set to rise by 59p to £9.50 per hour starting next April, translating to an annual increase of about £1,000 for full-time workers, following recommendations from an independent advisory board. The National Minimum Wage for individuals aged 21 to 22 will rise by 82p to £9.18 per hour, while the Apprenticeship Rate will increase by 51p to £4.81 per hour.

However, Tom Waters, a senior research economist, noted that while full-time minimum wage workers would see their earnings increase significantly, those on universal credit could experience only a £250 rise in disposable income due to tax increases and reduced benefit eligibility. Shadow Chief Secretary to the Treasury and Labour MP Bridget Phillipson deemed the proposals "underwhelming," asserting that much of the increase would be offset by tax hikes, cuts to universal credit, and rising energy costs. UK inflation was reported at 2.9% for the year ending in September, according to official figures.

Phillipson contrasted Sunak's approach with that of a potential Labour government, which promises a "new deal for workers," a minimum wage of at least £10 an hour, and measures to combat exploitative practices. Meanwhile, reports indicate that Sunak is contemplating raising the National Living Wage to £10.50 an hour and lowering the qualifying age from 25 to 21 by the next general election in 2024, aligning or surpassing Labour's commitments.

During the media briefing, Sunak defended the previous pay freeze, attributing it to the economic impact and uncertainty caused by the pandemic, stating that these measures helped to protect livelihoods during a critical time. With the economy recovering, he asserted that it is appropriate for public sector workers, including nurses and teachers, to receive pay increases.

Prime Minister Boris Johnson had earlier expressed a vision for a "high-pay, high-skill economy" post-Brexit; however, experts suggest that it may take years for wage growth to keep pace with rising financial pressures.

Analysis from The Guardian highlights that those affected by the pay freeze earned nearly 8% less than their private sector counterparts, with the disparity widening to 0.6% among all public sector employees, including those exempt from the freeze. The Office for National Statistics reported private sector wages increased by 8.3% from June to August 2021, compared to just 2.5% growth in public sector wages.

title: 'The Administrators were a disaster for the Shire': Wikinews interviews Lindsay Love, Tarwin Valley ward candidate in South Gippsland, Australia
content:
**Nominations Announced for Upcoming Council Elections in South Gippsland**

Nominations for the South Gippsland Shire Council elections were officially announced on Tuesday. Voting will take place by mail between October 5 and October 22. A total of 24 candidates have stepped forward to contest positions across three wards of the council. The shire has been under the administration of officials appointed by the Victorian state government since August 2019, following the council's dismissal due to a state inquiry that highlighted "high levels of tension" within its ranks.

Wikinews recently interviewed one of the candidates, Lindsay Love, via email. Love is running for a position in the Tarwin Valley ward, which elects three councillors to the South Gippsland Shire Council and encompasses several local towns. In addition to addressing questions from Wikinews, Love shared her thoughts on the council's current state:

"The Council's satisfaction ratings have been alarmingly low for over a decade, spanning multiple council terms and the period of Administration. The one consistent factor has been the Administration itself. This suggests that to improve the culture, we must initiate change at the administrative level. The council needs to function more like a corporate board and provide clear directives to the CEO to implement meaningful change."

**Key Issues and Candidate Insights**

When asked about her goals as a councillor, Love emphasized the need for an open, transparent Administration that actively engages with the community: "I want to foster greater public input in decisions that affect residents’ lives."

On the duration of the administrative governance since the council's 2019 sacking, Love criticized the impact of the Administrators: "Their management has been detrimental to the Shire. While the pandemic may have compounded issues, we have lost the essence of 'local' in local governance."

Regarding the absence of passenger railway services in South Gippsland since 1993, Love expressed skepticism about the return of such services. "The Administrators had a chance to retain the railway and develop a rail trail but neglected that opportunity. Now that the line is gone, it’s highly unlikely a train service will return, especially with state priorities focusing on more prominent projects."

When discussing environmental protection, Love noted that while the responsibility largely lies with the state, effective local governance should maintain efficiency in administration and focus on core responsibilities.

Love highlighted her qualifications, citing her extensive involvement with local issues, diverse professional background—including experience as a farmer, business operator, and civil engineer—and a decade spent working in local government.

She also identified several specific projects she would advocate for if elected, including:

- Promoting the development of a vision for new community facilities.
- Advocating for a water supply to enhance community resources and support a bike trail from that area to Yanakie.
- Proposing the creation of a state Significant Mountain Bike Park around the reserves.
- Supporting accessible facilities for disabled individuals at local landmarks.

During the COVID-19 lockdown, Love maintained community engagement by monitoring council actions and issuing press releases that provided alternative perspectives to those from the council.

Though this is Love's first candidacy for council, she served as the secretary for the South Gippsland Action Group Inc., which worked towards reducing rates and improving hardship policies until the Administrators’ appointment stymied their efforts. She notes that she is running independently without group support.

title: Australia: Wikinews interviews David Liebelt, South Gippsland local election candidate
content:
**Title: Australia: Wikinews Interviews David Liebelt, Independent Candidate for South Gippsland Local Election**

Since June 2019, South Gippsland, located at the southernmost tip of Australia, has been without a local council. A state government inquiry uncovered "high levels of tension" within the council, prompting the Victorian state government to appoint administrators in July 2019. An election is set to restore the council, with voting to take place via mail from October 5–22, 2021.

Wikinews spoke with David Liebelt, an independent candidate running in the Coastal-Promontory Ward, which encompasses towns such as [insert town names] and elects three councillors to the South Gippsland Shire Council.

**What do you hope to achieve as a councillor?**

"As a councillor, my goal is to represent all residents of the Coastal Ward and the broader South Gippsland Shire. I believe I can advocate for the 'Quiet Majority', which includes employees, farmers, small business owners, tradespeople, retirees, and holidaymakers. We have been represented for too long by individuals with narrow agendas, and I will focus on local community issues rather than distractions from Federal and State Government. My priority will be ensuring resources are allocated effectively so that residents feel they are receiving value for money from the Council."

**Do you think the two-year period under administration has been too long, and why?**

"Yes, the two-year period of administration has been excessive, and I believe the Administrators have fallen short in listening to community concerns and needs. Many decisions were made against community wishes, leading to wasted resources on reviews and consultants without yielding beneficial outcomes."

**With the COVID-19 pandemic affecting local businesses, what measures do you think are needed for recovery?**

"The Prom isn't the only tourist attraction that has suffered due to COVID-19; we have also neglected other valuable sites in favor of it. I'm currently assessing the Council's $2 million community support package, which has largely not reached small businesses. Immediate support is needed for outdoor community activities that businesses wish to pursue. We need to streamline processes and reduce bureaucratic hurdles, allowing for innovative solutions rather than just compliance checklists."

**What changes and reforms would you like to see regarding environmental protection?**

"We need to acknowledge that our farmers are vital environmental stewards. Supporting them through rate relief for environmental initiatives is crucial. I advocate for the establishment of Habitat Corridors to connect wildlife communities and enhance biodiversity across the Shire, linking coastal reserves to the ranges through a comprehensive master plan."

**What qualifications do you bring to the role of local councillor?**

"I bring extensive experience in small business management, community involvement, and people management. My education in Economics, Finance, and Small Business, along with studies in Climatology and Coastal & Fluvial Geomorphology, equips me for this role. I pride myself on my listening skills, patience, and empathy. While not all decisions will be popular, I commit to delivering them with honesty."

**Are there specific projects you aim to advocate for in your community?**

"I will advocate for a better allocation of resources to small communities, ensuring value for ratepayers. This includes enhancing services at community and health centers, and improving support for the elderly to help them stay in their beloved communities. Additionally, I would push for the Masterplan of Habitat Corridors in collaboration with the farming community."

**How have you connected with local voters during the COVID-19 lockdown?**

"I reach out through local businesses and hospitality venues, while also utilizing social media as a vital tool for sharing ideas, advice, and information with the community."

**Have you run for political office before?**

"This is my first time seeking a political position; I have never run for office prior to this election."

title: US, South Korean special envoys explore reopening talks with North Korea at Seoul meeting
content:
On Sunday, U.S. and South Korean envoys convened in Seoul to explore avenues for reopening diplomatic discussions with North Korea and facilitating humanitarian aid to the country. This meeting follows a warning from the United Nations, indicating that North Korea is facing potential starvation as a result of the COVID-19 pandemic. The envoys also deliberated on a proposal from South Korea to formally conclude the Korean War, which has remained officially unresolved since the armistice in July 1953.

Before the meeting, U.S. Special Envoy for North Korea, Kim, expressed optimism for "productive follow-up discussions" after a previous meeting in Washington, D.C. the prior Tuesday. Sunday’s agenda included discussions surrounding the declaration of a formal end to the Korean War and the provision of humanitarian aid to North Korea to help facilitate renewed diplomatic engagement.

Following the meeting, Kim stated that the U.S. calls on North Korea “to cease destabilizing activities and instead engage in dialogue.” He reaffirmed that the U.S. is “ready to meet with the DPRK without preconditions” and emphasized that the United States does not harbor hostile intentions towards North Korea.

During a press conference on Friday, a U.S. official mentioned the importance of providing humanitarian aid to North Korea, suggesting an easing of sanctions related to the textile and seafood sectors. The official warned that continued border closures and limited trade could exacerbate food shortages, indicating that the region is “veering towards an emergency.”

In a separate press briefing the same day, a U.S. spokesperson reiterated that “[UN] Security Council resolutions regarding the DPRK remain in effect” while also highlighting ongoing efforts to ensure humanitarian aid reaches those most in need in North Korea.

This diplomatic initiative comes on the heels of North Korea testing a new type of submarine-launched ballistic missile (SLBM) last Tuesday. In response, Special Envoy Kim urged North Korea to “refrain from further provocations and engage in sustained and substantive dialogue.” The North Korean government, however, accused the U.S. of “overreacting.” South Korea had previously launched a new SLBM on September 15, while North Korea conducted a missile test, still in the early stages of development, on September 28.

title: Northern Marianas governor closes schools for ten days after three COVID-19 cases detected
content:
The Governor of the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands has ordered a ten-day closure of all schools and colleges in the region to help "mitigate community spread" following the detection of three new COVID-19 cases, two of which are linked to middle schools in the capital, Saipan.

In his statement, Governor Torres assured the educational community—comprising staff, parents, families, and students—that the government is prepared to take all necessary measures to protect the Commonwealth during this resurgence, emphasizing, "We have the tools in place to contain this." He noted the government’s success in managing the pandemic thus far.

Health officials confirmed that the two linked cases originated from Chacha Oceanview and Francisco M. Sablan middle schools in Saipan, while details regarding the source of the third case are still pending.

This recent outbreak marks a significant shift, as the Northern Mariana Islands had not experienced any community transmission of COVID-19 for over 200 days. With the inclusion of these three new cases, the total number of COVID-19 infections recorded in the Northern Marianas since March 2020 now stands at 294.

title: Australian Fair Work Commission rules that farm workers on piece rate entitled to minimum wage
content:
Australia's Commission ruled on Tuesday that farm workers paid per "piece" of fruit and vegetable harvested must receive the minimum wage for casual workers, set at $25.41 per hour under the Horticulture Award. 

In their unanimous decision, the Commission stated that the current pieceworker provisions within the Horticulture Award are inadequate, necessitating the inclusion of a minimum wage floor in clause 15.2, which pertains to the pay structure for piece rate workers. This change aims to ensure that the Horticulture Award fulfills its objective of establishing minimum wage standards.

The Australian Workers' Union (AWU) submitted an application to the Commission on December 15, 2020, advocating for all farm workers to be guaranteed at least the minimum wage outlined in the Horticulture Award. The application garnered support from numerous organizations, including the Australian Council of Trade Unions, the Australian Labor Party, the United Workers Union, and 88 Days and Counting, as well as from the state governments of Queensland, Victoria, and Western Australia.

AWU Secretary Dan Walton praised the ruling in a statement to ABC News, saying, "Too many farmers have exploited the piece rate system to pay workers below Australian standards. Now, even workers with limited English skills or connections in Australia will find it easier to determine if they are being underpaid." Walton called the decision "one of the great victories in our union’s 135-year history."

However, the ruling faced opposition from several groups, including The Australian Fresh Produce Alliance, Fruit Growers Tasmania, Lucaston Park Orchards, Payne’s Farm Contracting, and the National Farmers' Federation (NFF). According to the Commission and reported by ABC News, the NFF specifically criticized the ruling, arguing it could jeopardize farmers' livelihoods and contending that piecework is essential for maintaining productivity.

title: Write-in candidate leads in Buffalo, New York mayor election
content:
**Buffalo Mayoral Election Sees Write-In Votes Outpace Democratic Challenger**

In Tuesday's mayoral election in Buffalo, New York, write-in votes outperformed Democratic challenger India Walton, capturing 59 percent of the vote compared to Walton’s 41 percent, with all precincts reporting.

The incumbent mayor, a four-term official, did not qualify for the general election ballot after losing in the Democratic primary but mounted a robust write-in campaign against Walton, who was the only candidate listed on the general election ballot.

On Wednesday, Walton, a democratic socialist, conceded the race to her opponent. In a statement on Twitter, she expressed hope that the final vote count might narrow, but realistically acknowledged, "it seems unlikely that we will end up with enough votes to inaugurate a Walton administration in January." She emphasized the significance of her campaign, stating, "Our volunteer operation was unprecedented in Buffalo political history. We raised over one million dollars from thousands upon thousands of small-dollar donors."

Following the election, he criticized Walton’s concession remarks in an interview with CNN, arguing that the election results were a rejection of her political ideology. "I think it clearly is a rebuke of socialism," he claimed. "There were efforts from outside the city of Buffalo to influence our vote, but the community fought back, and we won."

As local elections officials begin the slow process of counting the handwritten votes, state law allows 25 days for a certified vote count to be finalized.

Meanwhile, the Erie County District Attorney's office is investigating alleged tampering involving poll inspectors who may have produced pre-stamped ballots. A spokesperson stated, "Our office was contacted by the Board of Elections regarding allegations of misuse of a stamp at one polling location. We cannot comment further while the matter remains under investigation." According to Erie County elections commissioners Ralph Mohr and Jeremy Zellner, the inspectors accused of tampering have been removed and replaced at the affected polling site.

title: 'A very giant struggle': North Korean leader Kim Jong Un's warning of oncoming economic difficulties
content:
During a meeting on Wednesday, North Korean leader Kim Jong Un cautioned officials about an impending "very giant struggle" in the economic sector, according to the ruling Party's newspaper. The meeting was held at the headquarters building and attended by senior party members and military officials, including key figures in the government.

The gathering was convened to discuss preparations for the upcoming fourth Plenary Meeting of the eighth Central Committee of the Workers' Party of Korea (WPK). Officials decided that the Plenary Meeting will take place in the last third of December and will include a review of Party activities along with other important topics on the agenda.

At the Politburo meeting, Kim Jong Un acknowledged the recent successes, stating that "the achievements we have made demonstrate that the overall measures aimed at laying a foundation for the country’s economic development and improving the living standards of our people have been actively pursued." He particularly praised advancements in the agricultural and construction sectors.

Looking ahead, Kim asserted that "next year will be a crucial one," emphasizing that the country needs to engage in a "very giant struggle" comparable to this year’s efforts. He urged that plans for the upcoming year should be "dynamic, progressive, scientific, and detailed, solidifying the groundwork for implementing the five-year plan."

The economy of North Korea has been significantly impacted over the past two years due to a combination of factors, including COVID-19 border closures, increased sanctions, and the aftermath of natural disasters such as typhoons and heavy flooding. Reports from UN agencies, as noted by Al Jazeera, indicate that food and electricity shortages are exacerbating the economic challenges faced by the nation.

title: Chinese police arrest escaped North Korean convict
content:
As reported by a state-run Chinese newspaper on Sunday, a man has been captured by law enforcement after a 42-day chase following his escape from prison. Identified by the Chinese name Zhu Xianjian, the 39-year-old had previously been arrested for illegal entry into China, theft, and larceny. His deportation back to North Korea was scheduled for 2023, following the completion of his sentence.  

Images and video of the capture were released alongside the report, showing Zhu being taken into a police vehicle near the lakeside house where he was apprehended. According to a video circulated by the state media, Zhu was shot in the leg while attempting to flee. A reward of 200,000 RMB (approximately 31,284 USD) had been offered for information leading to the defector's capture, as noted by Business Insider. Zhu had escaped from Jilin prison on October 18 by climbing onto a storage shed and then jumping over a wall.  

Zhu initially fled North Korea in July 2013 by swimming across a river that serves as a natural border between North Korea and China. Before his escape, he worked as a coal miner in North Korea.  

North Korean defectors face the threat of imprisonment and potential torture if caught in China. A bilateral border agreement established in 1986 between China and North Korea mandates the deportation of all Korean defectors apprehended by Chinese authorities back to North Korea.

title: Wikinews interviews RSL Australia for Remembrance Day 2021
content:
**Wikinews Interviews RSL Australia for Remembrance Day 2021**

Wikinews reporter J.J. Liu reached out via email to the Returned and Services League of Australia (RSL) to discuss the upcoming 102nd observance of Remembrance Day, which honors the end of hostilities in World War I (WWI) on November 11, 1918.

Originally referred to as "Armistice Day" during its first celebration in 1919, the day was renamed "Remembrance Day" after World War II (WWII) to honor not only those who died in that conflict but also in subsequent Australian military engagements, as stated on the RSL website. In 1997, Governor-General Sir William Deane issued a proclamation urging all Australians to observe a moment of silence.

According to the RSL website, 61,630 Australians lost their lives during WWI, between August 4, 1914, and March 31, 1921, making it the deadliest conflict in Australian history. From a population of five million, 416,809 Australians enlisted in the war, with approximately 155,000 sustaining injuries and 8,000 succumbing to post-war conditions.

The interview featured RSL Ambassador Pete Rudland, a veteran who served from 1989 to 2017 with deployments in Cambodia, Iraq, East Timor, and Afghanistan—where he was injured in a helicopter crash that claimed four lives.

**How has Remembrance Day changed over the years?**

Rudland remarked, "In the beginning, Remembrance Day had a profound impact on a significant portion of the global population, as many Australians were touched by the war. Over 60,000 Australians were buried in foreign lands, and the nation grieved collectively." 

He emphasized that the RSL offered a platform for families of the fallen to mourn and heal together, reflecting a shared experience of war. While modern conflicts may not affect the same number of Australians, the RSL remains dedicated to providing support for soldiers and their families, just as it did a century ago.

**What role should organizations play in Remembrance Day?**

"Remembrance Day is essentially a collection of stories about those who sacrificed everything for their beliefs," Rudland explained. "Organizations must ensure these stories and the lessons from them are preserved, especially as our demographics evolve. Ex-Service Organizations are the guardians of our collective memory."

**What role do you believe governments should take on Remembrance Day?**

"Politicians lead nations to war, but the impact is borne by soldiers and their families," he noted. "Governments should take the initiative on Remembrance Day, recognizing that soldiers do not decide to go to war; it is the responsibility of elected officials. Acknowledging significant days like ANZAC Day and Remembrance Day reinforces the bond between the military, government, and citizens."

**Why is Remembrance Day still important, over a century after the Armistice?**

"For Australians, WWI marked a pivotal moment where we defined ourselves as a nation, not just colonies," he reflected. "Australians take pride in what our young nation achieved, both domestically and on the battlefield. The sacrifices of soldiers and their families have shaped our history, making it crucial for contemporary Australians to grasp the connection between the past and present."

**What lessons from WWI are relevant to veterans' affairs today?**

Rudland emphasized, "War is complex, and its consequences extend far beyond the cessation of hostilities. The wounded need ongoing rehabilitation, and the families of those lost must feel their sacrifices were meaningful. This applies to all conflicts."

**Why should Remembrance Day be commemorated alongside ANZAC Day on April 25?**

"ANZAC Day represents the beginning of a legendary narrative in Australian history—a testament to triumph over adversity," Rudland stated. "Remembrance Day serves as a reminder of the profound human cost of WWI and the challenges faced by a young nation striving to establish its identity. Together, ANZAC Day and Remembrance Day encapsulate the collective journey of all Australians."

title: Top Indian general dies in helicopter crash
content:
On Wednesday, India’s Chief of Defence Staff, General Bipin Rawat, tragically lost his life in a helicopter crash in the hilly region near Coonoor, Tamil Nadu. The general was en route to the Defence Services Staff College (DSSC) along with 13 others, including his wife and several senior defense personnel. The aircraft involved in the accident was an Indian Air Force Mi-17V5 helicopter. The military later confirmed that all but one of the 14 individuals on board perished in the crash.

The helicopter took off from Sulur Air Force Base and was headed to the DSSC in Wellington, Tamil Nadu, where General Rawat was scheduled to address the college's faculty and student officers. At approximately 12:08 PM IST, the helicopter lost contact with the base, shortly before it crashed near a residential area occupied by tea estate workers on the outskirts of Nanjappachatiram, within Bandishola Panchayat.

Eyewitness Krishnaswamy described the scene to the BBC, saying, "Even the electric poles shook. Trees toppled. There was smoke everywhere, and flames raged above the trees. I saw just one person with my own eyes; he was burning and fell down." The victims were reportedly burned beyond recognition. The sole survivor, Group Captain Varun Singh, is currently receiving treatment at a military hospital in Wellington.
