title: Former Japanese princess Mako Komuro moves to New York with commoner husband
content:
Mako Komuro and her husband, Kei Komuro, arrived in New York yesterday to begin their new life together. Their relationship has faced significant criticism from the Japanese public due to its unconventional nature and the way it challenges longstanding social norms. The couple's arrival at Tokyo’s Haneda Airport attracted considerable media attention and involved tight security.

Mako, a former princess and niece of the Japanese emperor, relinquished her royal title to marry Kei, her college sweetheart. Although Japan is modern in many respects, the status of women and family values are often rooted in feudal traditions; Japanese royalty are prohibited from marrying "commoners."

New York was chosen as their new home because Kei has secured a position at a law firm, although he has yet to pass the New York bar exam. The Associated Press has reported that this detail has been seized upon by Japanese media to undermine his credibility, despite the fact that it is common for many to not pass a bar exam on their first attempt. Observers have noted parallels between the scrutiny faced by Mako and Kei and that of other public figures who challenge societal expectations.

title: 33-year old charged with murder of Dalibor Pantic
content:
A 33-year-old man has been charged with the murder of Dalibor Pantic, who went missing in April 2019 while living in Gippsland, Australia. The arrest was made by the Missing Persons Squad earlier this week.

The suspect appeared in court in Sale on Tuesday for a filing hearing. He did not seek bail and has been remanded in custody. A subsequent court appearance is scheduled for March 8 of next year.

Pantic was last seen at a farm in Perry Bridge on April 10, 2019. CCTV footage captured his sedan in Melbourne shortly after he vanished; however, authorities believe it was being driven by someone else. Despite extensive searches, no remains or traces of Pantic have been found, although his vehicle was located in May 2020.

Police reports indicate that Pantic was involved in the drug trade within regions including Lakes Entrance and Sale. Investigators revealed that Pantic's phone was found in the possession of individuals connected to the drug trade in the town of .

title: Grand jury indicts former White House advisor Steve Bannon for contempt of Congress
content:
Steve Bannon, a former political strategist for former President Donald Trump, has been indicted by federal authorities for contempt of Congress. This indictment follows Bannon's refusal to comply with subpoenas issued by the U.S. House of Representatives, which was investigating the January 6 Capitol riot. The House had voted last month to refer the matter to the Department of Justice for further action.

Bannon faces two counts of contempt related to his failure to appear for a scheduled testimony and for not producing subpoenaed documents. The inquiry has also indicated that former White House Chief of Staff Mark Meadows may face a referral to the Department of Justice for similar noncompliance.

If convicted, Bannon could face up to one year in federal prison and a fine of $100,000. However, contempt of Congress is a challenging charge to prosecute; the last successful conviction occurred in 1974 against a conspirator involved in Watergate. This marks the first time since 1983 that an individual has been charged with contempt of Congress.

title: Glasgow Climate Pact deal struck; nations to reduce coal usage
content:
The 26th UN Climate Change Conference (COP26) has concluded with the signing of the Glasgow Climate Pact, marking a significant milestone in global efforts to address climate change. This pact represents the first international agreement explicitly aimed at reducing coal usage, which accounts for approximately 40% of the world's annual emissions and is the most significant source of greenhouse gas emissions among fossil fuels.

However, BBC News reports that the commitments made during the conference may not be sufficient to limit global warming to 1.5 degrees Celsius. According to a 2018 study, the differences between limiting temperature rise to 1.5 degrees versus 2 degrees are profound. While 1.5 degrees would help mitigate the worst effects of climate change, a rise of 2 degrees would significantly worsen its impacts around the globe.

Initially, there were plans for a complete phase-out of coal; however, India's climate minister highlighted that this goal would be unrealistic for developing nations still grappling with developmental challenges and poverty eradication. This concern shifted the conversation from total elimination of coal to focusing on gradual reduction.

COP26 President expressed deep regret over the weakening of the pact, explaining that it was necessary to ensure the agreement’s overall viability. Switzerland's environment minister voiced her "profound disappointment," noting that the adjustments made to the pact would not bring the world closer to the 1.5-degree target, but rather complicate efforts to achieve it.

title: Merritt, British Columbia evacuated amid massive storm
content:
The city of Merritt in British Columbia is under an evacuation order as of Monday due to severe flooding caused by a massive storm affecting much of southern British Columbia. Floodwaters have overwhelmed bridges and rendered the water treatment plant inoperable.

Residents are urged to evacuate to nearby cities, specifically if they have connections in Kamloops or Kelowna. Those with even-numbered addresses should head to Kamloops, while residents with odd-numbered addresses are directed to Kelowna. Returning to Merritt is prohibited as of 4:00 PM local time.

Major routes east of Kelowna have been closed due to flooding and landslides. Additionally, the cities of Duncan and Victoria on Vancouver Island have been isolated from each other and the rest of the island due to flooding. A local state of emergency has been declared, and some residences in Duncan have been evacuated in response to the situation.

title: Younger brother of North Korean founding leader dies aged 101
content:
North Korean veteran statesman Kim Yong-ju, the younger brother of the country's founder Kim Il-sung, passed away from unknown causes around December 14, as reported by the state-run newspaper Rodong Sinmun. He held prominent positions, including Honorary Vice President.

In a brief article, the current leader, Kim Jong-un, expressed his condolences by sending a wreath, commemorating Kim Yong-ju's contributions to the nation. The article characterized Kim Yong-ju as someone who "devotedly struggled to implement the lines and policies" of the regime and played a role in advancing socialist construction and the development of the Korean-style state social system.

The announcement of Kim Yong-ju's death came just two days ahead of the ten-year anniversary of his nephew Kim Jong-il's passing. While he was initially seen as a potential successor to Kim Il-sung, Kim Yong-ju gradually "faded from the political scene," according to the Associated Press, with his last public appearance recorded in a television report in 2015, where he was seen casting his ballot.

Throughout his life, Kim Yong-ju received the Order of Kim Il-sung and the Order of the State, the two highest honors in the country, along with the title of Hero of the Republic, the highest honorary title in North Korea.

This event occurs shortly before the ten-year mark of Kim Jong-un's rise to power, a significant moment as it parallels the status of both his grandfather and father.

title: More than 75 dead as Typhoon Rai sweeps through Philippines
content:
On December 16, Typhoon Rai, locally known as Typhoon Odette, caused widespread devastation across the southeastern islands of the Philippines. Over 300,000 individuals were evacuated as the storm made landfall, resulting in roofs being torn off, concrete power poles being toppled, and significant disruptions to communication and electricity services. As of today, officials report that more than 75 lives have been lost due to the storm.

The island where the typhoon made landfall was described as "totally devastated" by the local governor. Typhoon Rai was classified as a powerful storm, and many areas were left without electricity or communication, as downed power lines and fallen trees rendered numerous roads impassable. Many buildings were severely damaged, leading to a widespread impact in the affected regions.

On December 17, authorities declared a state of calamity in the province of Bohol due to the extensive damage caused by the typhoon. The governor of Bohol also announced the same status for the province of Cebu. Concerns were raised about the potential disruption to the storage of Covid-19 vaccines and vaccine kits amid ongoing power outages. President Duterte indicated that he would tour the affected areas, including Bohol, Cebu, and others, to assess the situation firsthand. Access to food and clean water has become increasingly limited for those impacted by the storm.

Typhoon Rai also caused significant damage to Vietnamese-held islands in the region. An observation tower reported sustained winds of up to 180 km/h (112 mph) and gusts reaching 200 km/h (124 mph) on the afternoon of December 18, before being knocked down by the storm. Fortunately, no casualties were reported in the Vietnamese-held territories.

title: New Zealand raises interest rates in second straight month to 0.75%
content:
**RBNZ Increases Interest Rates in Response to Rising Inflation**

The Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ) raised its official cash rate (OCR) by 25 basis points to 0.75% during its final policy meeting of the year, responding to a consumer price inflation rate of 4.9% in the third quarter, the highest level recorded since December 2007.

The rate hike was largely anticipated by economists and market analysts; 21 out of 23 economists surveyed in a Reuters poll conducted from November 15 to 19 predicted the 25 basis point increase, while two forecasted a 50 basis point rise to 1%.

According to The Guardian, New Zealand's approach to managing COVID-19 involved significant fiscal and monetary stimulus, akin to strategies used by other major economies. This response has contributed to a record low unemployment rate and the highest inflation in over ten years. The combination of stimulus spending, low interest rates, and a housing shortage has resulted in home prices doubling over the past seven years, making New Zealand the least affordable country among OECD nations, as reported by Reuters.

The RBNZ highlighted that the "near-term rise in inflation [is being] exacerbated by higher oil prices, rising transport costs, and supply shortfalls," warning of the potential for broader price increases, according to ABC News. The central bank projects that rates could rise to 2.5% by 2023 and even higher by 2024, although median forecasts from a recent article suggest the OCR may only reach 2% by the end of 2023, below levels seen in 2014.

Recent predictions vary, with economist Ben Udy suggesting the OCR could hit 2% by mid-2022, while Westpac's acting chief economist, Michael Gordon, anticipates a peak of 3% by Q3 2023, including a 0.5% rate hike during the RBNZ's next meeting in February, as reported by The Guardian.

The announcement follows a previously anticipated rate hike in October, where the OCR was raised from 0.25% to 0.5%—the first increase in seven years—as part of the RBNZ's tightening cycle that was delayed due to the Delta variant outbreak and lockdown measures in Auckland. Senior market strategist Jason Wong remarked at the time, "We're on a path towards a series of rate hikes and the market is well priced for that."

RBNZ Governor Adrian Orr explained to reporters that the bank believes a gradual approach—taking steady steps of 25 basis points back to levels just above the neutral rate—is the most balanced strategy. While the bank considered various options, including a 50 basis point hike, it ultimately opted for the smaller adjustment.

Orr also addressed housing market concerns, cautioning that "homeowners who have recently entered the market with very high levels of leverage need to be particularly careful and must prepare for higher interest rates." He noted that previous taxation on property investors had not succeeded in curbing escalating house prices, which the RBNZ views as unsustainable and at risk of correction. While he defended the necessity of stimulus, he acknowledged the subsequent rise in household debt.

Globally, many countries are beginning to wind down pandemic-related stimulus measures. In the U.S., inflation recently surged to 6.2%, the highest in 31 years, prompting pressure on Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell to expedite the tapering of monthly bond purchases, as reported by the Associated Press. Both the Bank of England and the European Central Bank (ECB) are facing scrutiny over anticipated inflation pressures, according to Reuters and The Guardian.

ECB President Christine Lagarde cautioned the European Parliament on November 15 against unnecessary tightening of financial conditions, stating that such measures could hinder economic recovery. She emphasized that "if we were to take any tightening measures now, it could cause far more harm than good," as reported by Reuters.

In contrast, the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA) is holding firm that interest rates are not expected to rise until 2024. RBA Governor Philip Lowe indicated to an Australian Business Economists lunch last week that current data and forecasts do not support an increase in the cash rate for 2022, stating, "[t]he economy and inflation would have to turn out very differently from our central scenario."

Several central banks, including those in Norway, the Czech Republic, and South Korea, have already raised rates prior to New Zealand's move, with South Korea expected to announce another hike at its meeting today.

Following the RBNZ's announcement, the New Zealand dollar fell 0.6% as some investors anticipated a more significant hike. Additionally, both 2-year and 10-year government bonds declined by 10 basis points each.

title: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi promises repeal of three farm laws
content:
In a national address on Friday, Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi announced the government's decision to repeal three contentious farm laws, stating, "We have resolved to repeal all three farm laws and will initiate the constitutional process during the upcoming parliamentary session at the end of this month."

The laws, passed by Parliament in September 2020 and later assented to by the President, are collectively known as the Farm Laws. They include the Farmers' Produce Trade and Commerce Act, the Farmers' (Empowerment and Protection) Agreement on Price Assurance and Farm Services Act, and the Essential Commodities (Amendment) Act.

These bills were approved during the monsoon session of 2020, but faced backlash from farmers in Punjab and Haryana, who expressed concerns that the reforms would disrupt agricultural markets and leave them vulnerable to large corporations.

In his address, Modi urged the protesting farmers to return to their homes, noting that celebrations erupted among some farmers near the Ghazipur border following the government's announcement. However, a leader from the Indian Farmers' Union declared that protests would continue until the laws are fully revoked in Parliament.

The Indian National Congress, the primary opposition party, welcomed the government's decision. Former party leader expressed gratitude to the farmers, stating, "The country's farmers, through their efforts, have compelled arrogance to bow its head. Congratulations on this victory against injustice! Hail India, hail India’s farmers!"
